Temperatures were 34-40 degrees when it was not snowing, but dipped to 33-36 degrees in any snow showers. The snow varied in intensity from flurries to briefly heavy snow, although the snow showers and squalls were fast-moving. A few gusts to 20-30 mph were seen in any snow squalls as well.

Light wintry event on January 14

A few disturbances passing through the region on January 14th brought some light wintry precipitation to the area. Initially, a mixture of plain rain and sleet fell between 8-11AM before changing to plain rain. Temperatures were 33-36 degrees, but sleet was able to accumulate despite the marginal temperatures, mainly on colder surfaces.

Snow squalls and snow showers move through on January 30

A few scattered areas of snow showers and squalls moved through on January 30th, mainly between 11AM-5PM. Though temperatures were 35 – 38 degrees, they dropped to near 32 degrees in any snow. Snow varied in intensity, with snow becoming briefly heavy in any squalls. Some wind gusts of up to 20-35 mph were observed in the squalls. After snow passed, temperatures rose back into the mid 30s, allowing for repeated coatings into the afternoon. A few flurries lingered through 8PM.

Northern clipper brings brief snow/graupel on January 31

As a clipper system passed well to the north, a few areas of flurries and graupel moved through the region early on January 31st. The flurries and graupel mainly fell between 4-9AM. With temperatures between 29-33 degrees, some light accumulation occurred.

Developing system brings period of snow, flurries, and snow showers

As a developing system strengthened nearby the area, periods of rain mixed with and changed to snow, with snow mainly falling between 6-9AM on February 9th. Some areas saw a brief mixture with sleet before precipitation changed to snow. The snow fell with light intensity before tapering off. A few areas of returning flurries occurred through 10AM-1PM as well. Then, a few scattered snow showers passed through during the afternoon hours, mainly between 4-9PM. Temperatures during the event were initially in the 40s in rain but crashed to 32 – 36 degrees in snow and the succeeding flurries. By the afternoon snow showers, temperatures had fallen to 26 – 30 degrees. Strong winds followed the system, with gusts of up to 30 – 45 mph at times.

Scattered snow showers affect the area on February 16th

Scattered light to briefly moderate snow showers fell across the region on February 16th, mainly beginning between 12-3AM and continuing through 8-11AM. A few brief flurries began in some locations as early as 9PM on the 15th, but most accumulating snow occurred on the 16th. Temperatures during the snow showers were 31-34 degrees, with most accumulations occurring on colder/grassy surfaces.

Passing system changes rain to snow, then snow showers follow

As a disturbance moved through the area early on March 10th, precipitation began as rain. However, as cold air filtered in, rain mixed with and changed to sleet/snow between 7-10AM as temperatures rapidly fell from the 40s to 34-37 degrees. A few brief periods of light to moderate snow fell through 1PM, and temperatures rebounded to near 40 degrees after the snow. However, a few scattered snow showers followed and passed through during the afternoon, ending by 8PM. Most accumulations occurred on colder/grassy surfaces.

Fast-moving clipper brings brief snow/flurries December 13th

A quick-moving system brought a brief period of flurries or very light snow (or snow grains) to the region which fell between 7-11PM on December 13th. Temperatures were 27-31 degrees during any snow.

Wintry mix impacts the area on January 8th

A disturbance slid through the region on January 8th and provided a wintry mix of light slight, freezing rain, and freezing drizzle. The wintry mix developed as a mix of light freezing rain and sleet across the area between 12-3PM on the 8th with temperatures hovering between 29-32 degrees. The wintry mix eventually switched to just light freezing rain/drizzle by 3-4 PM and continued intermittently into the evening. A steadier wave of freezing rain/drizzle swept through during the evening hours, eventually tapering off and ending between 8-11 PM as temperatures rose to 32-37 degrees. Due to the prior stretch of cold weather, icing occurred even with air temperatures above freezing.

Very light snow falls overnight January 15

A quick, very light snow fell across a localized area during the nighttime hours of January 15. The snow fell between 8PM-12AM with temperatures between 28-31 degrees, resulting in some light accumulation mainly on colder surfaces.

Quick-moving cold front brings brief snow to the area January 30

A fast-moving system brought a few snow showers to the region on January 30th. Precipitation initially began as rain, but quickly mixed with and changed to snow between 4-9AM. Temperatures were marginal and were between 34-38 degrees. As a result, any accumulation was limited to colder/grassy surfaces. Strong winds picked up during the event as well, with sustained speeds of 10-25 mph and gusts up to 35 mph.

Wintry mix affects the area on February 4

A passing disturbance brought a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain to the area on February 4th. Areas of light snow overspread the region and fell mainly between 8-10am before beginning to mix with sleet and freezing rain. Temperatures hovered between 30-33 degrees during this time.  Eventually, a transition to all freezing occurred by 12pm, and freezing rain continued to fall into the afternoon with temperatures staying right around 32 degrees. Temperatures eventually warmed slightly to 33-34 degrees, but a few elevated surfaces continued to see icing issues until rain exited the region between 6-9pm.

Winter storm brings ice impacts to the region February 7th

A strong disturbance moving through the area with cold temperatures near the surface resulted in some icing from freezing rain on February 7th across the mid-Atlantic. As temperatures hovered between 30-32 degrees, a few scattered freezing rain showers developed and fell between 4-8AM. Then a break in activity occurred through mid-day, but a steadier period of freezing rain redeveloped and fell between 12-2pm. After 3-4pm, temperatures warmed to 33-35 degrees, which ended the icing threat. All rain exited the region by 6-8pm.

Scattered flurries and snow showers move through on March 16th

A few areas of flurries and brief snow showers moved into the region during the morning hours of March 16th, mainly between 5-9AM. Temperatures during the snow were 33-36 degrees and any accumulation occurred largely on colder and grassy surfaces.

Quick system brings a few areas of flurries and light snow to the region

As a fast-moving system pushed through the area, a few flurries and briefly light periods of snow were able to fall on January 5-6. While a few areas of flurries were seen during the afternoon hours of the 5th, temperatures were 33-37 degrees and minimal accumulation was observed. It was not until between 9PM-12AM on the 5th and 2-4AM on the 6th that a better area of flurries and light snow moved through with temperatures falling to 32-34 degrees, providing some brief, light accumulation. The snow was light and fluffy in nature.

Rain changes to snow on March 19th

A passing disturbance brought rain to the area during the early hours of March 19th. However, as cold air filtered in, rain mixed with and changed to snow across the region between 1-4AM. Intermittent light snow continued falling through 5-8AM, occasionally mixing with rain. Temperatures throughout the snow were 34-38 degrees, and most accumulation occurred on colder/grassy surfaces.

Snow squalls pass through the area March 3

A few snow showers and squalls moved through the area early on March 3rd,  mainly between 12-8AM. The snow fell with variable intensity, becoming briefly moderate to heavy in any squalls. With temperatures between 32-36 degrees, accumulations of snow mainly occurred on colder/grassy surfaces.

Coastal system brings snow to the region on December 15th

A quick-moving coastal system brought a period of light to occasionally moderate snow on December 15th. Snow fell between 12-6PM with temperatures between 25-30 degrees.

Disturbance moving through the region brings snow on January 29-30

A disturbance passing through the area brought areas of snow between January 29-30. The snow began falling as early as 8-11PM as intermittent flurries or even some sprinkles or light rain with temperatures between 34-38 degrees. However, any rain changed to all snow after midnight, and temperatures fell to 31-33 by sunrise on the 30th. A steadier area of snow arrived after midnight, producing some briefly locally moderate to even heavy snowfall during the pre-dawn hours before tapering off and ending between 4-7AM.

Rain mixes with and changes to snow on March 6-7

As a coastal storm began to develop near the area, a few rain showers moved into the region during the evening hours of March 6 with temperatures between 36-40 degrees. However, these rain showers quickly mixed with and changed to snow between 7-10pm (with some sleet initially mixing in as well but any mixing with sleet was brief). Temperatures fell to 32-34 degrees within the snow, and it fell with light to moderate intensity. Rain began to mix back in with the snow at times during the morning hours of the 7th, mainly after 2-5AM as temperatures rose back up to 34-38 degrees. Intermittent mixing with snow continued through 8-11AM before precipitation tapered off and ended.

Clipper system brings a widespread snowfall on December 30

A quick-moving clipper brought snow to the area on December 30th. Snow broke out across the region between 2-5AM, and continued through 10AM-1PM with temperatures between 17-22 degrees. The snow fell either as flurries or light snow during the morning. A few scattered flurries returned during the evening hours, mainly 4-9PM. Temperatures rose to 27-31 degrees during the returning flurries. Some additional coatings occurred during these returning flurries.

Powerful coastal storm brings snow and strong winds to the area on January 3-4

A coastal storm strengthened rapidly off the coast and brought snow to the region on January 3-4. Snow began to break out between 10PM on the 3rd and 1AM on the 4th. The snow mainly fell with light intensity though some more moderate bands developed close to the Chesapeake Bay. While it was steady at first, the snow became more intermittent going into the late morning and mid-day before it tapered off by 11AM-2PM. However, a few flurries lingered as late as 4-6PM. Temperatures throughout the storm were 22-27 degrees. Strong winds developed during the storm as well, and strengthened throughout the time snow was falling. Sustained speeds of 15-25 mph and gusts of up to 25-35 were seen during the snow. These strong winds continued after the storm.

The strong winds led to blowing and drifting snow, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher than normal drifts.

Snow impacts the area on January 17

A slow-moving disturbance pushed a round of light to briefly moderate snow into the region during the morning hours of January 17th. Snow broke out gradually between 1-4am and fell intermittently before quickly developing into a bout of steadier snow. This burst lasted into part of the morning rush before tapering back to flurries and ending through 6-9am. Temperatures fell to 28-32 degrees as snow began falling, and dipped into the mid 20s after the snow ended.

Initial period of wintry mix on March 20th.

Morning rain on the 20th began to mix with sleet at times beginning 11AM – 1PM as temperatures settled to 31 – 34 degrees. This mix continued through the afternoon and evening, briefly mixing with snow at times too. After 9PM, this wintry mix tapered too mainly drizzle and pockets of freezing drizzle as temperatures held near 32 degrees. A brief lull in precipitation followed shortly after Midnight as drier air moved in.

This report reflects any wintry precipitation through around Midnight. Another steadier period of snow developed during the early morning of the 21st, which will be covered in a separate report.

Strong storm brings a wintry mix of snow and sleet on February 17

A strong system passed through the region on February 17th. As the system arrived, precipitation was initially light and intermittent, which allowed for a mix of plain rain, sleet, and snow. However, as intensity increased and precipitation became steadier, a transition to all snow occurred. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times during the afternoon and early evening. However, snow mixed back with combinations of sleet and plain rain before it ended, with even some periods of heavy sleet occurring. All precipitation tapered off and ended between 6-9pm. Temperatures throughout the event were 34-37 degrees.

Coastal storm brings snow to the region on January 7

As a coastal storm passed by the region on January 7th, areas of flurries began to develop between 3-6AM. The flurries were intermittent at first, but eventually developed into a steadier, light snow during the mid to late morning hours. Toward mid-day, a band of more moderate snow passed through the region before tapering back t. Snow ended across the region between 1-4PM. Temperatures during the snow were 18-24 degrees. The snow was light and fluffy in nature and because of sustained winds at 5-15 mph (and gusts of up to 20-30 mph after the storm ended), some blowing and drifting of snow occurred.

Coastal storm brings first snowfall of the season December 9th

A developing coastal system brought the first snow of the season across the area, beginning on December 9th. Snow broke out across the region generally between 7-10AM on the 9th, initially as flurries with temperatures in the mid-30s. However, as snow became steadier and increased in intensity, temperatures dipped to 29-32 degrees. Periods of light to moderate snow continued throughout the day before tapering off and ending between 7-10 PM. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Powerful Nor’easter brings mixed precipitation on March 13-14

A strong mid-March Nor’easter brought areas of heavy snow and sleet to the region on March 13th-14th. Light to moderate snow began breaking out across the region between 5-8PM on March 13th, quickly becoming steady before midnight. Snow became moderate to heavy at times overnight, with rates of up to 1-2” per hour. However, snow began to mix with sleet as early as 9-11PM, and even changed over to steady, heavy sleet at times during the overnight hours. An extensive period of heavy sleet amounted to around half of the total accumulation. With sleet being generally three to four times denser than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow pack relative to the overall accumulation.  Freezing rain mixed in with the snow/sleet at times as well, mainly after 12AM. Further weight was added to the overall accumulation on the ground with the addition of freezing rain. The steadiest precipitation began to taper to mixed sleet/snow showers toward 8-11AM. Intermittent light snow showers and flurries then lingered through 4-7PM. Temperatures throughout the event were steady between 29-32 degrees. Strong winds picked up toward the end of the event, with sustained winds between 10-25 mph and gusts of up to 30-45 mph at times continuing after the event.

**Accumulation in the “Total” column are representative of combined non-compacted snow and sleet accumulation per standard snow measurement guidelines. Accumulation listed under “ice” indicates any additional ice accretion from freezing rain only, if applicable.

Steady snow returned on March 21st.

After a brief lull overnight, a light wintry mix of freezing drizzle, light sleet and snow returned between 4 – 6AM on the 21st. After 6AM, this turned to all snow, and became moderate to heavy through the morning and midday with snowfall rates around 1” per hour. Snow lightened in the afternoon and ended 4 – 7PM. Just a few flurries returned around Midnight. Temperatures through the event were 32 – 35 degrees, resulting in a wet snowfall.

Late November Snow Showers

Intermittent snow showers moved into the area between 7:00 and 10:00 PM November 20th. These snow showers and flurries continued off and on through 4:00 to 7:00 AM November 21st. Temperatures began 33 - 36, but fell into the upper 20s by the end of the event. Northwest winds were very strong at times, gusting to 35 - 40 mph.

Brief Snow Shower

A brief snow shower moved through the area between 8:00 and 10:00 PM December 15th. Temperatures ranged from 18 - 22 degrees during the evening. Strong northwest winds gusting to 40 - 50 mph caused some blowing and drifting of the snow.

Pockets of Rain and Freezing Rain

A mix of rain and freezing rain moved through the area between 8:00 PM December 17th and 1:00 AM December 18th. Temperatures ranged from 31 - 34 degrees. Due to the preceding cold, patchy ice was able to develop on pavements even where air temperatures were slightly above freezing.

Brief Snow Squall Moves Through the Area

A snow squall moved through the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM December 30th. The snow was briefly heavy. Temperatures began in the upper 30s and lower 40s, but fell to 33 - 36 during the snowfall.

Rain Changes to Snow Showers

Rain ended as a bit of wet snow from 8:00 to 10:00 PM January 4th. Temperatures began in the near 40, but fell into the lower 30s by the end of the event. The snow mixed with rain and sleet at times, especially in the lower elevations.

Strong Coastal Storm Brings Mixed Precipitation

A mix of rain and snow showers developed between 3:00 and 6:00 AM January 23rd. These snow showers continued off and on through the daytime hours with temperatures in the mid 30s. During the evening hours that same day, a steady rain entered the area. This steady rain continued into the overnight, mixing with some sleet at times. Any wintry precipitation changed to plain rain during the morning hours of January 24th. Temperatures were steady between 35 - 39 during the rain and sleet.

Few Snow Showers March 19th

A few snow showers moved through the area between 3:00 and 7:00 AM March 19th.Temperatures ranged from 32 - 34 degrees.

Light Snow Flurries December 14th

A few flurries and snow showers moved through the area between 4:00 and 8:00 AM December 14th. Temperatures ranged from 20 - 24.

Weak System Brings Light Snow December 18th

After a few pre-dawn flurries, a few light snow showers moved through the area between 12:00 and 3:00 PM December 18th with temperatures ranging from 30 - 32. Most of the precipitation tapered off during the afternoon, with just a few lingering flurries or sprinkles in spots. Temperatures warmed above freezing during the late afternoon and evening, changing any leftover precipitation to plain rain.

Flurries and Brief Snow Shower December 15th

A few flurries and a brief snow shower moved through the area between 8:00 PM December 15th and 12:00 AM December 16th. Temperatures ranged from 23 - 27 degrees.

A mix of freezing rain and sleet entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM December 23rd with temperatures in the mid 20s. Freezing rain continued through the afternoon, before ending 5:00 to 7:00 PM that evening. Temperatures rose to 33 - 35 by the end of the event. Quick Hitting Storm System Brings Wintry Mix

A period of light snow moved through the area between 5:00 and 8:00 PM January 8th with temperatures ranging from 33 - 36 degrees. The snow briefly mixed with rain and sleet at the onset.

Upper Level Disturbance Brings Snow Shower February 6th

A few flurries and snow showers moved through the area between 10:00 AM and 1:00 PM February 6th. Temperatures ranged from 24 - 28 degrees.

Brief Wintry Mix Changes to Rain February 25th

A light mix of sleet and rain moved through the area between 5:00 and 8:00 AM February 25th with temperatures ranging from 34 - 37 degrees. Any precipitation changed to plain rain after 8:00 AM as temperatures warmed into the upper 30s.

Heavy Rain Mixes with Wet Snow March 2nd

A heavy, wind-driven rain mixed with wet snow between 8:00 PM March 2nd and 12:00 AM March 3rd. Temperatures ranged from 34 - 37 degrees during the mix. Northerly winds were extremely gusty through the period, reaching 55 - 65 mph at times.

Periods of Wintry Mix Change to Rain April 15-16th

A light mix of snow and sleet moved into the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM April 15th with temperatures ranging from 32 - 35 degrees. A wintry mix of sleet, snow, and rain continued into the evening, before changing to plain rain between 10:00 PM that evening and 1:00 AM April 16th. Brief Period of Rain, Sleet, and Wet Snow April 19th

A brief period of rain, sleet, and wet snow moved through the area between 7:00 and 10:00 AM April 19th with temperatures ranging from 34 - 37 degrees.

Snow Showers and Snow Squalls March 3rd

A few snow showers and squalls moved through the area between 7:00 PM March 3rd and 12:00 AM March 4th. Temperatures were steady in the low 20s. Strong northwest winds gusted to 35 - 45 mph at times.

Rain Ends as Period of Wet Snow February 2nd

Periods of rain changed to snow between 4:00 and 6:00 AM February 2nd. The snow continued through 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM that same day. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell into the upper 20s by the end of the event.

Post-Coastal Storm Snow Showers March 14 - 15th

A period of light snow moved through the area between 10:00 PM March 14th and 4:00 AM March 15th Temperatures ranged from 32 - 34 degrees.

Snow Showers March 25th

Scattered snow showers (mixed with rain at times) moved through the area between 11:00 PM March 24th and 6:00 AM March 25th. Some additional, non-accumulating snow showers and flurries continued into the afternoon. Temperatures ranged from 33 - 36 degrees.

Snow Changes to Wintry Mix December 22nd

Intermittent periods of light snow entered the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM December 22nd with temperatures in the upper 20s. The snow began to mix with rain and freezing rain between 6:00 and 8:00 PM that evening as temperatures climbed into the mid 30s. A cold north wind brought sub-freezing temperatures back into the area by 10:00 - 11:00 PM, changing any precipitation to freezing rain and causing any wet surface to quickly freeze up. The freezing rain and drizzle tapered off by 12:00 - 2:00 AM December 23rd with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s.

Note: The freezing rain and ice that occurred later on December 23rd will be covered in another report.

Clipper System Brings Light Snow December 30th

A steady light snow moved through the area from 12:00 to 6:00 PM December 30th. Temperatures were steady between 15 - 19 degrees throughout the event.

Brief Period of Snow

A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM December 5th. The snow continued at varying rates through 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM, before changing to rain and sleet. All preciptitation ended between 12:00 and 2:00 PM that afternoon. Temperatures began 30 - 32 degrees, but rose into the mid to upper 30s by the end of the event.

Ocean Effect Snow January 15th

Light snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 AM January 15th. The steady light snow continued through 9:00 to 11:00 AM that same morning. Temperatures ranged from 10 - 15 degrees throughout the event.

Strong Storm System Brings Rain and Snow

A steady rain changed to a period of wet snow between 7:00 and 11:00 PM December 29th. Temperatures began 40 - 44 degrees, but fell to 33 - 35 degrees as precipitation changed to snow. After the snow ended, temperatures fell to near 32 degrees overnight, causing any lingering wet/slushy surface to freeze.

Rain and Sleet Changes to Snow February 22nd

A light mix of sleet and rain showers developed between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM February 22nd with temperatures in the upper 30s. The rain/sleet changed to snow between 2:00 and 4:00 PM that afternoon as temperatures fell to 32 - 34 degrees. The snow came to an end between 6:00 and 8:00 PM that evening. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Periods of Light to Moderate Snow March 4 - 5th

A period of light to moderate snow moved through the area between 11:00 PM March 4th and 7:00 AM March 5th. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell to 32 by the end of the event.

Yet Another Early April Snow Event

Snow entered the area between 12:00 and 2:00 PM April 6th. The snow was briefly moderate to heavy at times, before tapering off between 3:00 and 5:00 PM. The snow mixed with rain towards the end of the event. Temperatures began in the upper 30s, but fell to 32 - 35 during the snow. Due to warm ground temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on non-paved surfaces.

Fast Moving Storm Brings April Snow

A steady snow entered the area between 7:00 and 9:00 AM April 2nd. The snow became moderate to heavy at times during the mid-morning, before ending between 12:00 and 2:00 PM that same day. Temperatures ranged from 31 - 34 degrees. Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Periods of Snow Change to Sleet and Freezing Rain

A steady snow entered the area between 9:00 and 11:00 PM December 11th. The snow was fairly light to start, but gradually became heavier during the early morning hours of December 12th. The snow changed to a mix of sleet and freezing rain between 5:00 and 7:00 AM, before ending as plain rain 9:00 to 11:00 AM that morning. Temperatures began 28 - 30, but rose to 34 - 37 by the end of the event.

Long Duration Winter Storm Impacts the Areas

Snow moved into the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM on February 7th. The snow continued to fall, moderately to heavy at times, through the early afternoon hours, before changing to a mix of rain, freezing rain, and sleet. Periods of light rain and drizzle continued through 4:00 to 7:00 AM on February 8th. Temperatures began 34 - 37, but fell rapidly into the 20s during the early morning hours on the 8th, allowing wet surfaces to become icy.

Light snowfall on the 6th.

Flurries began after 3AM, with a steadier light to briefly moderate snow beginning 5 - 6AM, and ending during the morning of the 6th between 930 - 1030AM. temepratures held 23 - 27 during the event, resulting in a fluffy snowfall.

Clipper System Brings Snowfall

Periods of snow entered the area between 3:00 and 6:00 PM January 31st. The snow continued to fall, moderately at times, through 5:00 to 8:00 AM February 1st.  Temperatures were steady between 24 - 29 degrees during the event.

Coastal System Brings Period of Snow March 22nd

Light rain and snow entered the area between 11:00 PM March 21st and 1:00 AM March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 35 - 39 degrees. The precipitation quickly changed to all snow, becoming moderate at times after sunrise. During the snow, temperatures fell to 32 - 34 degrees. The snow came to an end between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM that same day.

Rain Changes to Snow February 15 -16th

Rain changed to snow between 8:00 and 11:00 PM February 15th. A steady light to moderate snow continued through the overnight, before ending 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM February 16th. A few scattered snow showers and flurries continued into the early afternoon. Temperatures began between 34 - 36 degrees, but fell into the upper 20s by the end of the event.

Snow Ends as a Wintry Mix January 17th

A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 5:00 and 7:00 AM January 17th. The snow continued through the morning hours, becoming moderate at times. As the snow became lighter during the afternoon and evening, the snow began to mix with a bit of freezing rain and sleet. All precipitation came to an end between 8:00 and 10:00 PM that evening. Temperatures were steady between 31 - 33 degrees throughout the event.

Low Pressure Brings Wintry Mess February 7th

A steady snow entered the area between 10:00 and 11:00 AM February 7th with temperatures ranging from 30 - 32 degrees. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times before changing to sleet and freezing rain between 2:00 and 3:00 PM that afternoon. Freezing rain quickly changed to plain rain after 4:00 - 5:00 PM as temperatues rose into the mid to upper 30s. The changing of precipitation types made this a very dense accumulation that was heavier than normal.

Strong Low Pressure System Brings Long Duration Wintry Mix

A light mix of rain and snow entered the area between 8:00 and 11:00 AM March 31st. The mixture quickly changed to all snow with temperatures falling to 32 - 34 degrees. The snow began to mix with sleet and rain between 5:00 and 9:00 PM that evening. Precipitation transitioned to mostly rain during the overnight hours with temperatures rising into the upper 30s. The rain changed back to snow between 8:00 and 11:00 AM April 1st with temperatures falling to 34 - 36 degrees. The snow came to an end between 4:00 and 7:00 PM that evening.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow January 29 - 30th

A steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 PM January 29th. The snow continued into the overnight and through sunrise, falling moderate at times durinr the mid to late morning hours. The snow came to an end between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM that day. Temperatures began between near 32 degrees, but fell to 21 - 23 degrees by the end of the event.

Christmas Day Winter Storm

A mix of light rain and snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 AM December 25th with temperatures in the mid 30s. Much colder air rushed into the area between 6:30 and 7:30 AM, changing precipitation to all snow with temperatures falling into the low to mid 20s. Any lingering wet or slushy areas quickly turned to ice. The snow became very heavy, with rates reaching 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands, before tapering off 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM. Northerly winds became very gusty towards the end of the event, with gusts reaching 35 - 45 mph.

Periods of Snow February 10-11th

Periods of snow moved into the area between 11:00 PM February 10th and 2:00 AM February 11th. The snow continued through 7:00 to 10:00 AM February 11th. Temperatures were steady between 17 - 22 degrees throughout the event.

Coastal System Brings Snow

A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 4:00 and 7:00 AM March 10th. The steady snow continued into the afternoon, before turning briefly heavy at times. The steadiest snow came to an end between 8:00 and 11:00 PM, but intermittent snow showers and squalls continued through 2:00 to 5:00 AM March 11th. Temperatures ranged from 28 - 32 degrees for most of the event, but fell into the teens by the early morning hours on the 11th.

Coastal System Brings Heavy Snow

A steady snow entered the area between 4:00 and 7:00 AM February 12th with temperatures in the low 20s. The snow mixed with, and changed to rain for a period of time during the afternoon as temperatures rose into the mid 30s. The rain changed back to snow during the overnight hours, before ending between 7:00 to 10:00 AM February 13th. Temperatures fell back into the mid 20s by the end of the event. Northwest winds became gusty during the morning of the 13th, which caused some blowing and drifting snow.

Period of Moderate to Heavy Snow Changes to Wintry Mix

A steady snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 AM December 17th with temperatures in the low 20s. The snow became heavy at times after sunrise, before ending as a mix of rain and freezing rain between 12:00 and 2:00 PM that afternoon. Temperatures rose to 32 - 34 degrees by the end of the event. As colder air moved back into the region later that afternoon, temperatures fell back below freezing causing ice to redevelop.

Periods of Moderate to Heavy Snow February 17 - 18th

Steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 9:00 PM February 17th. The snow quicky became moderate to heavy at times during the evening, with rates reaching 1" per hour. The snow continued through the overnight, before ending between 6:00 and 8:00 AM February 18th. Temperatures ranged from 31 - 34 degrees throughout the event.

Coastal System Brings Widespread Snowfall December 9 - 10th

A steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM on December 9th, quickly becoming moderate to heavy at times during the afternoon, with snowfall rates reaching 0.5 - 1.0" per hour. The snow lightened up a bit after sunset, but continued to fall steadily through the evening hours. Most of the snow tapered off between 1:00 and 3:00 AM December 10th, but a few flurries lingered through sunrise. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell to 30 - 32 degrees for most of the snowfall.

Rain Changes to Heavy Snow March 7 - 8th

After few rain and snow showers during the early morning hours on March 7th, a steady light to moderate rain entered the area through the afternoon. As colder air moved into the area, the rain changed to snow between 7:00 and 9:00 PM that evening. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times during the overnight, before lightening up a bit after sunrise on the 8th. Snowfall rates reached 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands. Light to occasionally moderate snow lingered during the daytime of the 8th, ending 12:00 - 3:00 PM. Temperatures settled to 31 - 34 degrees during snowfall, and winds gusted 30 - 45 mph.

Major Nor'easter Impacts the Area

Intermittent periods of snow moved into the area between 4:00 and 7:00 AM March 14th with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s. The snow became steadier and heavier by late morning (snowfall rates reached 2-3" per hour), before changing to sleet and rain between 1:00 and 4:00 PM. As the precipitation changed to sleet and rain, temperatures rose into the upper 30s. The rain ended as a brief period of snow between 7:00 and 11:00 PM that evening. Temperatures fell back below freezing by the end of the event, allowing the snowpack to refreeze. NE winds gusted to 45 - 55 mph at times.

Coastal System Brings Moderate to Heavy Snowfall

A steady snow entered the area between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM January 7th. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times, before ending 1:00 to 3:00 AM January 8th. Snowfall rates reached 1" per hour in the heaviest bands of snow. Gusty winds of 25 - 35 mph caused some blowing and drifting snow. Temperatures ranged from 16 - 20 degrees during the snowfall.

Coastal Storm Brings Blizzard Conditions February 9th

A steady snow entered the area between 7:00 and 9:00 AM February 9th. The snow became heavy during the early afternoon, with snowfall rates reaching 2 - 3" per hour in the heaviest bands. In addition, strong northwest winds of 40 - 50 mph caused significant blowing and drifitng of the snow. The snow lightened up during the early evening, before ending 7:00 - 10:00 PM. Temperatures began near 32, but fell into the upper teens and lower 20s by the end of the event.

Strong Coastal Storm Brings Blizzard-Like Conditions

A steady snow moved into the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM January 4th. The snow quickly became heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours, with rates reaching 2-3" per hour. As the snow became heavier, northwest winds began gusting to 40 - 50 mph, causing significant blowing and drifting snow. The steady snow and strong winds continued through the evening hours, before tapering off between 8:00 and 10:00 PM. Blowing and drifitng snow continued through the overnight hours, well after the falling snow ended. Temperatures were steady between 25 and 30 degrees throughout the event. 

Note: The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th.

Initial light rain showers began as early as 12AM, before becoming a steady snow by 2 - 4AM on the 13th as temperatures settled from the upper 30s to near 32 degrees. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 7AM - 7PM when snowfall rates of 1 - 2" per hour occurred. The main area of snow ended by 11PM, though intermittent light snow lingered until 2 - 5AM on the 14th. Temperatures during snowfall were mainly 30 - 32 degrees, and winds gusted 30 - 50 mph, resulting in blizzard conditions.

Additional snow showers fell on November 20th through pre-dawn of the 22nd.

After the band of rain that changed over to steady to heavy snow during the pre-dawn to early morning hours of November 20th, occasional lake effect bands of generally light snow & flurries (mixed with rain/sprinkles towards the coastline) quickly developed behind it from 8 - 11 AM. Throughout the daytime of the 20th, temperatures were in the mid-to-upper 30s inland, and upper-30s to low-40s towards the coast. At night, temperatures were capable of hovering in the mid-30s, dipping closer towards freezing under steadier bursts of lake effect snow showers that occurred in far northern Fairfield near the Litchfield border, as well as far southwestern Fairfield county near White Plains, NY. In addition, winds were able to gust 35 - 45 mph under these steadier snow showers. For the rest of the day on the 21st into the early morning of the 22nd, only light snow showers and flurries occurred. Temperatures from the 21st-22nd hovered around 32 degrees across northern Fairfield, then 33 - 38 degrees in southern Fairfield. The last of the flakes dissipated between 4 - 7 AM.

Light rain showers mixed with a few pockets of sleet and even a little wet snow further inland began between 7 - 10 PM on December 6th. The last of any light rain showers/drizzle mixed with a few sleet pellets dissipated between 4 - 6 AM on the 7th.

Snow squalls moved through between 7 and 9 AM on December 15th. After a brief break, a few isolated flurries & very light snow showers returned between Noon and 2 PM. Temperatures held 19 - 24 degrees throughout the event with wind gusts of 35 - 50 mph.

Periods of freezing rain and drizzle returned during the overnight of Dec. 17th-18th.

Periods of freezing rain moved into the area between 7 and 10 PM on December 17th with temperatures ranging from 32 to 35 degrees. Pockets of freezing rain and drizzle continued through 12 and 3 AM on the 18th before changing to plain rain with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s.
After a primarily rain event on December 29th, a brief shot of sleet (even a little snow within the inland areas) occurred before ending from 5 - 8 PM. Temperatures were in the upper-30s to low-40s.
A few pockets of sleet pellets fell with any rain showers that moved through between 8 - 11 AM on January 2nd. Temperatures held 33 - 38 degrees throughout the event.

Brief shot of sleet pellets & pockets of freezing rain on February 7th.

While mainly rain occurred during the morning of the 7th, at the onset between 5 - 8 AM, there were a few pockets of sleet & freezing rain with temperatures of 32 - 35 degrees. Any lingering pockets of freezing rain diminished by the afternoon as temperatures warmed into the mid-to-upper 30s.
Periods of light snow developed between 9 - 11 PM on February 10th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 2 - 5 AM on the 11th. Temperatures held 25 - 29 degrees throughout the event.

Intermittent flurries & snow showers began between 9 AM - Noon on March 15th. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 22 - 27 degrees during the duration of the snow showers & flurries.

Scattered wintry mix showers of snow, sleet, and rain occurred between 12-10 PM on March 18th. Temperatures at the onset were in the mid-30s, rose to late day highs in the upper-30s to low-40s, then settled back down to 32-37 degrees by the end of the event.

A very late season wintry event occurred from March 31st - April 1st.

The first began between 4 - 7 AM on the 31st as rain mixed with some pockets of sleet with temperatures in the mid-30s. While precipitation was primarily rain for much of the daylight hours on the 31st with temperatures in the upper-30s, a few places would occasionally witness a few additional sleet pellets mixing in thoughout the day. Winds gusted 30 - 40 mph. A transition back to all rain & drizzle occurred between Midnight - 3 AM on the 1st as temperatures continued to hover in the mid-to-upper 30s.

A bit of wintry mix at the start/end of a mainly rain event from December 12th-13th.

Light rain (mixed with some snow and sleet at the onset in elevations above 600 feet) began between 6 - 8 AM on the 12th with temperatures of 35 - 39 degrees. Rain continued into the daytime as temperatures soared to a high in the low-40s. At night, however, colder air began to funnel in behind the system, resulting in a changeover to light snow, sleet and flurries from 7 - 9 PM. Temperatures fell near to just below freezing not long after the changeover. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 1 - 3 AM on the 13th. Temperature settled to 19 - 24 degrees by the end of the event.

A warm front brought light snow and flurries to the region on December 18th.

Light snow and flurries began between 2 - 5 AM on the 18th. Any lingering flakes dissipated from 6 - 8 AM. Temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Low pressure brings a wintry mix, then long-duration icing event December 22-23.    

Intermittent  flurries & sleet pellets entered the area between 11 AM and 2 PM on the 22nd with temperatures of 33 - 38 degrees. The flurries and sleet pellets changed over to freezing rain during the evening as temperatures dipped to 29 - 32 degrees. Although there was a bit of a lull overnight, there were some pockets of freezing fog and freezing drizzle. Freezing rain returned to the area between 2 and 5 AM on the 23rd. The freezing rain continued through the afternoon, before ending 5 to 8 PM that evening. Temperatures rose to 33 - 38 by the end of the event. The long duration of freezing rain caused repeated periods of icing.

Brief period of snow early on February 6th

A band of snow showers moved across the area between 9:30 - 11:30 AM Feb 6th. Most of the snow showers were light, but there were brief bursts of moderate snow. Temperatures were between 26 - 29 degrees.
Scattered light snow showers & flurries developed between 1 - 4 PM on February 9th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Scattered wintry mix showers of freezing rain with pockets of sleet & snow began between 3 - 6 AM on February 14th. The last of the showers dissipated from 6 - 8 AM. Temperatures at the onset of 27 - 32 degrees rose near to just above 32 degrees by the end.

Powerful coastal system brought occasional snow and sleet from March 2nd-3rd.

Snow and sleet began to mix in at times with the rain from 4 - 7 AM on March 2nd. This variable wintry mix switched back and forth between rain and snow/sleet throughout the day, and was dependent on the intensity of precipitation as well as elevation. While the main system exited from 5 - 7 PM, a few flurries and occasional light snow showers lingered as late as 11 PM - 2 AM going into the 3rd. Temperatures throughout the event hovered in the mid-to-upper 30s. Winds were exceptionally strong as well, frequently gusting 45 - 65 mph.

Scattered snow showers began between 10 PM on the 4th - 1 AM on the 5th. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 1 - 4 AM. Temperatures generally held 33 - 36 degrees, but were capable of falling near to below freezing (29 - 32 degrees) during the steadier showers.

Periodic scattered snow/sleet/rain showers began between 5 - 8 AM on March 9th. The last of the wintry mix showers dissipated completely from 4 - 7 AM on the 10th. Temperatures at night were 27 - 32 degrees, then rose upwards of 35 - 40 degrees during the middle of the day.

Scattered snow squalls & intermittent light snow occurred from March 14th-15th.

Scattered snow showers and squalls worked in between 3 - 6 PM on the 14th. Although the squalls exited completely from 6 - 9 PM, some lingering areas of intermittent flurries & very light snow persisted until 12 - 3 AM on the 15th. Temperatures fell from 34 - 39 degrees at the onset to near 32 by the end of the event.

Rain featured pockets of wet snow during the early morning of Nov. 20th

Rain began to swing into the area between 9:30 PM on the 19th and 1:30 AM on the 20th. Temperatures in the low-to-mid 50s quickly plummeted into the mid-to-upper 30s between 1:30 and 4:30 AM as pockets of wet snow mixed in. The last of the rain/snow mix ended between 4:30 - 7:30 AM as temperatures continued to hover in the mid-to-upper 30s.

Note: This storm exhibits snowfall totals from the band of rain that changed over to a rain/snow mix during the pre-dawn to early morning hours of the 20th. Additional snowfall from any lake-effect snow showers during the day on the 20th into the morning of the 21st will be featured as a separate event, as applicable.

Flurries, snow showers, and embedded snow squalls occurred on January 8th.

Scattered flurries, snow showers, and even a few embedded snow squalls developed between 1 - 4 PM on January 8th. The last of the flakes completely dissipated from 6 - 9 PM. Temperatures held 16 - 21 degrees throughout the event, though the higher elevations did continue to drop into the low-to-mid teens during the evening.

Periods of rain gradually mixed with, then changed over to snow February 1st-2nd.

Periods of rain from the evening of February 1st began to mix with snow from 1 - 4 AM on the 2nd as temperatures settled into the mid-30s. A changeover to all snow occurred by 4/5a before quickly ending from 5 - 7 AM. Temperatures dipped to 26 - 31 degrees by daybreak. Although the main system had already exited, a few flurries & isolated snow showers lingered as late as 11 AM - 1 PM as temperatures continued to plummet to 23 - 27 degrees.
Period of snow (mixed with rain at times) began between 8 - 11 AM on the 6th. The last of the wet flakes dissipated from 1 - 4 PM. Temperatures held in the mid-to-upper 30s.

A wintry mix of rain, sleet, and snow impacted the coast on December 5th.

A wintry mix of snow and rain with a few pockets of sleet entered the region between 3 - 5 AM. Those directly along the coast saw more rain than snow/sleet, while those not much farther inland saw more snow/sleet at the onset compared to rain. Precipitation changed to primarily rain from 5 - 7 AM, although there were some lingering pockets of sleet all the way through 9 - 11 AM. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event.

January 17th winter storm brought rain and snow.

A light to moderate rain arrived between 1 - 3 AM on the 17th with temperatures in the mid-30s. A gradual changeover to snow occurred from west to east from 10 AM - 1 PM. The last of the flakes dissipated from 3 - 5 PM. Temperatures hovered around 32 degrees by the end of the event.

A coastal storm brought sleet and freezing rain from January 23rd-24th.

With temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s, steady rain moved into the area during the late afternoon on the 23rd. As the rain became heavier, temperatures cooled to 33 - 38 degrees. This then began to mix with sleet primarily for the inland areas 8PM-11PM. Localized icing was had as well during the evening, particularly again for the inland areas as temperatures occasionally dipped near 32 degrees. The mix continued into the new day on the 24th. However, it would lighten up between 2AM-5AM, tapering to light rain & drizzle with a few sleet pellets during the early morning hours. During the pre-dawn hours of the 24th, winds were strong, gusting at 35-45 mph. The second round of scattered precipitation arrived between 8 - 11 AM. These scattered showers fell primarily as rain, though a few heavier showers were able to mix some pockets of sleet down. The last of these rain showers with pockets of sleet dissipated from 9 PM - Midnight on the 24th. Temperatures held in the mid-to-upper 30s (upper-30s to low-40s directly at the coast) throughout the second wave of precipitation.

Note: The snow/sleet totals are a representative average of the given zip code due to elevation differences & localized intensity. Accumulations were prominent on mainly colder, grassier, & elevated surfaces.

A wintry mix of freezing rain, sleet and snow occurred on January 8th.

A mix of light freezing rain, sleet, and snow began between 2 and 4 PM on the 8th. The wintry mix quickly changed over to all snow before the last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 28 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

Light snow changed over to a little sleet/freezing rain, then plain rain Dec. 11th-12th.

Light snow overspread the area from 4 - 7 PM on December 11th with temperatures of 32 - 35 degrees. A brief lull occurred between 9 PM - 1 AM going into the 12th before precipitation returned as a brief wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain before transitioning to all rain from 1 - 4 AM (predominantly rain directly at the coast with much of the wintry mix falling not much father inland). Temperatures by the end of the event rose quickly into the upper-30s to low-40s.

A shot of snow quickly changed over to a bit of sleet, then freezing rain and rain.

A shot of light to moderate snow began between 8 - 10 AM on February 7th with temperatures of 26 - 31 degrees. The snow quickly changed over to sleet and freezing rain before transitioning to all freezing rain from 11 AM - 1 PM. As temperatures began to rise above the freezing mark, a changeover to all rain occurred from 3 - 5 PM.

Due to the multiple precipitation types, accumulations were denser and therefore heavier than normal.

Snow, sleet, and rain mix from December 24-25

Scattered snow, sleet, rain and even some pockets of freezing rain developed between 8 - 11 PM on the 24th with temperatures of 30 - 35 degrees. Showers continued into the early morning hours of the 25th until steadier precipitation of snow and sleet moved in between 5 - 9 AM. Behind the main system, just a few lingering mixed sprinkle/flurries and rain/snow showers occurred before ending completely by Noon. Temperatures warmed back into the mid-to-upper 30s. Winds also gusted up to 30 - 40 mph through the morning.

Light snow developed between 11 PM on the 13th and 1 AM on the 14th. While the steadiest snow ended from 7 - 9 AM, a few lingering flurries lasted through Noontime. Temperatures held 21 - 26 degrees throughout the event.

Quick-hitting coastal system brought some snow to the region on December 15th.

Light snow began between 1 - 4 PM on the 15th with temperatures of 26 - 29 degrees. Snow was briefly moderate near the New York border during the late afternoon to early evening hours. The last of the flakes fell between 9 - 11 PM with temperatures settling to 21 - 25 degrees.

A light snow event occurred on January 14th.

A period of light snow began between 2 - 5 PM on January 14th. The last of the flakes tapered off from 9 - 11 PM. Temperatures held 26 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

A clipper system brought light to even moderate snow to the area on the 30th.

Light snow began between 7 - 9 AM on the 30th with temperatures of 14 - 17 degrees. The snow fell moderate in intensity closer to the New York border during the afternoon before lightening up before sunset. The last of the flakes dissipated from 4 - 6 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose slightly to 19 - 22 degrees.

Fluffy light to moderate snow enveloped the region on January 6th.

Periods of light to moderate snow developed between 12 - 2 AM on January 6th. The last of the snow exited from 8 - 10 AM. Temperatures held 26 - 31 degrees slightly inland, and 27 - 32 degrees directly at the coast, throughout the event.

A bit of snow helped to end the month of January.

Light to occasionally steady snow began between 11 PM on the 29th and 1 AM on the 30th with temperatures of 29 - 32 degrees. The snow ended completely between 9 - 11 AM. Temperatures by the end of the event settled to 26 - 30 degrees.

Periods of snow from a clipper system occurred from January 31st.

Periods of light to moderate snow developed between 10 AM and Noon on January 31st with temperatures of 25 - 30 degrees. Snow fell briefly heavy during the mid-afternoon across New Haven County. During the late afternoon directly at the coast, temperatures rose just above freezing before quickly falling below again after sunset. The last of the flakes dissipated from 8 - 10 PM. Temperatures settled to 26 - 29 degrees by the end of the event.

Yet another potent system brought snow, ice to the area Feb 12th-13th.

A fluctuating mix of light snow, sleet, freezing rain, and rain developed between 5 - 8 AM on February 12th with temperatures of 25 - 30 degrees. After 1 - 3 PM, the wintry mix transitioned to mainly plain rain/drizzle with pockets of freezing rain & drizzle as temperatures hovered near to just above 32 degrees. In-between the light and intermittent precipitation overnight, a narrow but steady band of snow showers worked across New Haven county border from 3 - 5 AM on the 13th. While the last of any plain & freezing drizzle dissipated completely from 5 - 8 AM, wind gusts of 50-70 mph resulted in blowing and drifting during the daytime. Temperatures by the end of the event were 32 - 36 degrees.

Late March storm brought steady snow & even some pockets of sleet to the region.

Intermittent light snow with pockets of sleet began between 3 - 6 AM on the 21st, but took until mid-morning to truly become steady and widespread everywhere, even falling moderately at times. The snow continued into the overnight, ending competely from 4 - 7 AM on the 22nd. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the majority of the event, though did dip a degree or two below freezing under the steadiest snow within the interior.

Periods of steady, moderate snow impacted the state on March 10th.

Light snow began between 4 - 6 AM on March 10th with temperatures of 32 - 36 degrees. The temperature quickly fell near to slightly below freezing (29 - 32 degrees) as snow became steadier during the pre-dawn hours. Snow fell moderate at times during the morning hours. While the main batch of snow lightened up and ended between 1 - 3 PM, a few localized flurries & even snow squalls continued through 6 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose back up to 33 - 36 degrees. However, winds increased going into the overnight, with gusts of 30 - 40 mph. As a result, blowing and drifting occurred well after the snowfall ended as temperatures plummeted into the teens.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to the preceding warmth and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less, and subject to considerable variations.

Heavy snow, then sleet & freezing rain occurred on December 17th.

Light to steady snow developed from 1 - 4 AM on December 17th with temperatures of 25 - 30 degrees. Snow became heavy around and after sunrise, then lightened up mid-morning. The snow mixed with a bit of sleet, then changed over to freezing rain from 9 - 11 AM. The steadier precipitation exited from 11 AM - 12:30 PM, but was soon followed by scattered mixed sleet and freezing rain showers through 1 - 3 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose to 32 - 36 degrees, but preceding cold temperatures before the event allowed pavements to ice even with air temperatures above freezing.

First coastal storm of the season brought snow from December 9th-10th.

Light to moderate snow began between 7 - 10 AM on the 9th with temperatures of 32 - 35 degrees. By Midday, snow was falling steadily, resulting in temperatures to dip to 29 - 32 degrees and stay there for the rest of the event. Snow began to lighten up considerably towards Midnight, ending as flurries between 11 PM - 2 AM.

Potent winter storm impacted the region on January 7th.

Light snow overspread the area between 8 and 11 AM on January 7th. Snow quickly turned steady towards Noon, falling moderate to heavy at times throughout the afternoon. Snow gradually lightened up during the early evening hours, wrapping up completely from 9 PM - Midnight. Temperatures held 19 - 24 degrees throughout the event. In addition, winds gusted 25 - 35 mph, especially towards the end of the event. These wind gusts continued into the 8th, resulting in blowing and drifting.

A quick thump of snow occurred overnight from February 17th-18th.

Light snow began between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th with temperatures of 33 - 36 degrees. The snow fell moderate to even heavy at times between 6 and 11 PM, allowing temperatures to dip near to just below 32 degrees. Light snow continued into the early pre-dawn hours of the 18th before ending from 1 - 4 AM on the 18th. Temperatures by the end of the event were 32 - 35 degrees.

Early April snow impacted the southwestern portion of the state on the 2nd.

Light snow began between 4 - 6 AM on the 2nd with temperatures of 35 - 40 degrees. As the snow became steady to even heavy, especially between 5 AM & Noon, temperatures quickly plummeted to 27 - 32 degrees. Thereafter, the snow lightened up before ending Noon - 2 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose back into the mid-to-upper 30s.

Third coastal system for March brought heavy snow and gusty winds.

Light snow mixed with a little rain at the onset developed between 9 PM - Midnight on the 12th. The snow fell briefly moderate to heavy at times between 6 - 9 AM on the 13th. The snow lightened up and became intermittent from Noon - 2 PM, but did not taper off completely until 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 33 - 38 degrees throughout the event. Winds were gusty as well, at 25 - 40 mph.

Another Nor'easter pounded the western section of the state March 6th-8th.

Intermittent light snow showers & flurries began to work in from 9 PM - Midnight on the 6th with temperatures of 34 - 38 degrees. These snow showers began to pick up in frequency from 1 - 3 AM on the 7th as temperatures dipped to 32 - 37 degrees. Moderate to even heavy bands of snow finally pushed in from 10 AM - 1 PM, briefly mixed with rain until intensity was able to overcome the marginal temperatures and allow for all snow. Even lightning and thunder was reported at times under these very heavy bands that produced 1-3"/hr rates. The snow lightened before exiting from 2 - 5 AM on the 8th. It was windy, as well, with gusts of 30 - 40 mph.

A powerful coastal system impacted the state on January 4th.

Periods of light snow began between 2 - 4 AM on the 4th with temperatures of 23 - 28 degrees. The snow became moderate to heavy around to just after sunrise with temperatures dipping to a low of 19 - 24 degrees. Winds began to kick up with these heavier bands, as well, with gusts of 30 - 40 mph, resulting in blowing & drifting. Near-blizzard conditions were witnessed as visibilities dipped to a quarter mile or less for much of the daytime with snowfall rates of 1-3"/hr. Especially out near New Haven, lightning and thunder could be seen from over the waters. The heavier bands exited around sunset, resulting in a light and increasingly intermittent snow to continue as winds gusted to 40 - 50 mph. Any lingering flurries dissipated from 7 - 10 PM. Temperatures rose slightly back to 23 - 28 degrees. Winds continued to stay gusty into the overnight, resulting in blowing and drifting even into the daytime of the 5th.

The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

A late-season Nor'easter pummeled the state on March 14th.

Light snow began between 10 PM on March 13th and 1 AM on March 14th with temperatures of 28 - 32 degrees. The snow quickly became steady to heavy snow during the pre-dawn, with 1-3" per hour rates, particularly for inland areas of Fairfield & New Haven counties. The snow mixed with sleet between 7 - 10 AM, transitioning over to primarily sleet at the coast not long after. These periods of sleet resulted in ~1" inch of sleet accumulation. With sleet being generally three to four times more dense than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow/sleet pack relative to the overall accumulation. In addition, similar areas that saw sleet also transitioned to rain & drizzle with pockets of freezing rain & drizzle Midday and into the afternoon, particularly across New Haven county as high temperatures were 31 - 36 degrees. The wintry mix transitioned back to all snow during the evening hours before ending as intermittent light snow & flurries from 7 - 10 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event settled down to 25 - 30 degrees (20 - 25 interior). During the event, winds gusted 50 - 60 mph, resulting in significant blowing & drifting of the snow pack.

Accumulation in the "Total" column are representative of combined non-compacted snow and sleet accumulation per standard snow measurement guidelines. Accumulation listed under "Ice" indicates any additional ice accretion from freezing rain only, if applicable. In addition, there were tight gradients from low-to-high from coastal locations to inland locations even within zip codes due to the transition from snow to sleet to rain/freezing rain. Therefore, totals are a representative average of said zip codes.

A potent coastal storm brought heavy snow to the region on February 9th.

Light to moderate snow overspread the area between 3 - 6 AM on February 9th with temperatures of 33 - 36 degrees. Snowfall quickly became heavy thereafter, resulting in temperatures to quickly drop near to slightly below freezing. The snow did not lighten up until the early afternoon. The combined heavy snowfall and wind gusts of 35 - 45 mph resulted in visibilities to be reduced to 1/4 mile or less at times, as well as blowing & drifting. There were even reports of thunder and lightning, particularly across New Haven county. Snowfall rates were 1-3"/hr during this time period. Light snow persisted throughout the afternoon before ending completely between 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures fell to 21 - 25 degrees by the end of the event. Gusty conditions continued into the overnight hours as temperatures fell into the teens, resulting in prolonged and significant blowing and drifting long after the storm ended.

First Wintry Weather of the Season Arrives on November 20th  

Rain overnight transitioned to a snow/sleet mix between 11PM – 2AM on November 20th. The mix was scattered for a couple of hours, ending by 7AM. Occasionally, rain was had in this mix as well. During the event, temperatures were 34-38 degrees.

A Line of Snow Showers for December 15th

Between 9AM-1PM on December 15th, a band of snow arrived. The snow only lasted for an hour or two as it passed south throughout the area, which had snow squalls embedded in them. Winds were strong during the event, gusting at 30-45 mph. Temperatures were 21-25 degrees as well, making it feel like 5-10 degrees.

Lake Effect Snow Showers Reach the Region on December 30th

Snow flurries overspread the area starting between 11AM-1PM on December 30th. Snow was generally in the form of flurries, except for an hour or so between 430PM – 730PM, which brought a heavier intensity snow for many places. After 730PM, the snow concluded. Most of the event was 32-37 degrees, though during the midday, it was near 40.

Wintry Mix on February 12th

Between 3 and 6 AM on February 12th, rain with some pockets of freezing rain, developed in the area. Temperatures were 32 - 36 degrees. Towards 6 - 8 AM, temperatures cooled to 30 - 33 and the mixture of precipitation trended to combinations of snow, sleet and freezing rain. Between 12 and 3 PM, temperatures warmed into the mid-30s and all precipitation changed to plain rain.

Arctic Front Brings Snow Squalls on March 3rd

With temperatures starting 35-39 degrees, an area of snow showers and flurries moved across the boroughs between 530PM-930PM on March 3rd. Embedded within the snow showers were squalls that produced heavy snow and brief whiteout conditions. Moreover, with the squalls, temperatures dropped into the upper 20s to lower 30s as an arctic front passed. Winds were also strong during this time, gusting at 30-40 mph. After snow showers exited, temperatures fell into the lower 20s overnight with mainly clear skies.

Scattered flurries and snow showers briefly occurred between 4 - 8 AM on December 11th. Temperatures were between 31 - 34 degrees during the event before rising into the upper 30s to 40 degrees by mid-day.

Wintry mix on January 8th

A weak system moved into the area between 3 - 6 PM on the 8th, which brought a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain. Steadier precipitation changed to all snow for a time, especially after sunset. Temperatures were between 27 - 31 degrees during the event.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Snow, Rain and Wind on March 2nd

A very strong coastal storm brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. A good portion of the precipitation fell as rain (which began late on March 1st). Starting 7 - 9 AM on March 2nd, rain mixed with and at points changed to combinations of snow and sleet. This mixture of precipitation continued through the afternoon, until the steady precipitation tapered down to flurries and sprinkles between 5 and 8 PM. When wintry precipitation was falling, the temperature was between 33 and 38 degrees. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong. Gusts were frequently 40 - 50 mph, with some spots exceeding 60 mph at times.

Light snow on March 4th and 5th

Flurries and snow showers began as early as 7 PM on the evening of the 4th, with more widespread light snow developing mainly between 10 PM - 3 AM into the 5th. While most of the snow had finished by then, additional flurries and brief pockets of light snow did continue to fall at times across the East End until 8 - 10 AM. Temperatures were between 31 - 35 degrees under the steadiest snow.

Evening snow showers and flurries on March 14th

Flurries began as early as 4 - 5 PM, followed by scattered snow showers mainly between 6 PM and 12 AM on March 14th. While most precipitation was light, a few showers did become heavy and steady at times. Snow quickly tapered down to flurries by midnight, eventually diminishing shortly afterwards. Temperatures were initially in the upper 30s to near 40 degrees before cooling between 33 and 37 degrees during snowfall.

Brief wintry mix on March 20th

Pockets of sleet, mixed with some rain and brief snow, occurred between 4 and 9 PM on March 20th. Temperatures were between 36 and 40 degrees, with most accumulation found on colder/grassy surfaces. Temperatures continued to hold in the mid-to-upper 30s after sleet ended.

Snow to wintry mix and rain on February 7th

A light to moderate snow overspread the area between 7 - 9 AM on February 7th, quickly mixing with sleet as temperatures were initially between 30 - 32 degrees. Snow then changed to mainly freezing rain by 11 AM - 12 PM as temperatures held near 32 degrees. Temperatures then slowly warmed above freezing by 1 - 3 PM, ending any icing. Marginal temperatures and mixed precipitation led to accumulations that were denser than normal.

Sunday Snow on December 11th

With temperatures in the mid-30s, snow moved in from 3PM – 5PM on December 11th. The snow was light, but consistent for a few hours, ending between 7PM-9PM. During the end time, temperatures dropped down to around 32.

Storm brought rain to snow on January 17th

A steady rain moved into the area overnight on the 17th with temperatures initially in the mid-to-upper 30s. This eventually mixed and changed to snow by 7 - 9 AM as temperatures settled between 32 - 36 degrees. Snow then remained light to moderate, eventually tapering off to flurries 1 - 4 PM.

Snow for the Business Day on January 31st

Between 830AM-1030AM on January 31st, snow began. The snow was moderate during the late morning until around noon, turning into light snow afterwards. Snow was then consistent for much of the afternoon, ending during the beginning of the PM rush hour, between 330PM-530PM. During the event, temperatures were just below freezing, at 27-31 degrees.

Clipper system on December 30th

Light snow flurries associated with a clipper developed between 8 - 10 AM on the 30th. Snow became steadiest through mid-day before quickly tapering off by 2 - 4 PM. Temperatures held between 19 - 23 during snowfall.

Note: Areas that saw returning showers or flurries during the evening of 12/30 will be addressed in a separate storm summary.

Light clipper system on December 14th

A clipper system brought snow between 12 - 3 AM on the 14th. Light to moderate snow continued through the pre-dawn hours, becoming intermittent with just flurries at times, especially toward and around dawn. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 8 - 11 AM. Temperatures were generally between 23 - 28 degrees during the event. Winds also gusted up to 25 - 30 mph at times after snow ended, leading to some blowing snow.

Second Half of Saturday Snow for January 14th

Between 2PM-4PM on January 14th, snow moved in, with temperatures around the freezing mark. The snow was light to moderate during the afternoon, turning into light snow everywhere after 7PM. The snow was then consistent for much of the evening, but ended from west to east between 930PM-1130PM. Pockets of freezing drizzle were seen while the storm ended as well. While the snow moved away, temperatures were lower than the start, at 28-32 degrees.

Workweek Ends with Snow on January 6th

Between 1130PM – 130AM on January 6th, snow moved in from the NJ/NY border, on northeast. Moderate intensity snow was seen in spots through 3AM, lightening up everywhere afterwards. After 4AM, snow became off and on, staying as such past sunrise. Then, during the AM rush, between 8AM-10AM, the snow shifted out of the area, ending the snowfall. Temperatures were below freezing while it was snowing, at 27-32 degrees.

Coastal system on January 29 - 30

Pockets of light snow and flurries began as early as the late evening on January 29th, before becoming steady during the pre-dawn on the 30th. Snow then remained light to moderate through the morning, eventually tapering off to flurries by 6 - 9 AM. Temperatures were initially 33 - 36 degrees before settling between 28 - 32 degrees during snowfall. Due to prior mild temperatures, pavement accumulation was variable, and generally less than those of colder and grassy surfaces.

Coastal storm brought accumulating snow on December 15th

Snow quickly developed between 1 - 3 PM on the 15th, and became steady for the evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. The snow came to an end west to east 7 - 9 PM. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the upper 20s, but settled into the mid 20s as snow became steady.

Nor'easter brought accumulating snow on March 13th

Light rain began late in the evening on March 12th, mixing and changing to snow after 12 AM on the 13th. Periods of light to moderate snow then followed into the early morning hours, becoming heavy for a time between 6 and 9 AM. Snow then became lighter after 11 AM, mixing with rain at times before completely ending by 1 - 3 PM. Temperatures were mainly between 33 and 37 degrees throughout the storm.

March Snow Storm

Snow developed between 6 and 8 AM on March 10, when temperatures were 33 - 38 degrees. Snow intensity increased to a moderate to heavy intensity fairly quickly, as temperatures settled to 30 - 32 degrees. Steady snow continued into midday, though transitioned to intermittent snow showers from west to east between 11 AM and 1 PM, before all snow tapered off by 5 PM. Following the steady snow, the temperature rose into the mid and upper 30s, but fell back below freezing at night.

Note 1: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to marginal temperatures and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less, and subject to considerable variations.

Note 2: Snow falling later on the 10th will be covered in a future report.

Periods of steady, heavy snow on February 17 - 18

Snow overspread the area between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th, quickly becoming steady during the evening. Moderate to heavy snow fell between 7 and 10 PM, with the steadiest falling at rates of up to 1-2" per hour. This then tapered to off to snow showers and flurries toward midnight (with a brief changeover to light rain in spots). All precipitiation ended by 2 AM on the 18th. Temperatures held steady between 30 - 34 degrees during the event.

Accumulating Snow Then Wintry Mix on December 17th

Snow developed across most of the region between 1 and 4 AM with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s. After varying intensities early on, snow fell moderate to heavy intermittently closer to sunrise, with 1" per hour rates at times. As temperatures inched to near the freezing mark, snow mixed with and changed to combinations of sleet and freezing rain between 7 and 10 AM. Further warming into the mid-30s (and the end of steady precipitation) brought an end to the icing by midday, with many places tapering off as plain rain.

First widespread snowfall of the season on December 9th

A coastal system moving up the coast brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow first began between 8 - 10 AM as temperatures cooled from the mid-30s to between 30 - 34 degrees. As snow quickly became steadier toward mid-day, it also became moderate in intensity at times, especially between 11 AM - 4 PM. Snow then remained light and steady into the evening, eventually diminishing by 10 PM - 12 AM into the 10th with a few flurries lingering after. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Long duration event featuring a wintry mix on March 7th

A wave of precipitation on the morning of March 7th was followed by a coastal system that developed later in the day before exiting during the evening. The first batch of precipitation was a mix of light snow and rain that began shortly after 12 AM on the 7th. This mixture then continued before abruptly transitioning to moderate to heavy snow between 12 and 3 PM as the coastal system developed. The heaviest snow was accompanied by thunder and snowfall rates up to 1" per hour at times. Snow then continued into the evening, mixing with rain again before ending between 8 - 10 PM with just a few lingering flurries. Temperatures were generally between 33 and 37 degrees throughout the event. Additionally, winds gusted between 35 - 45 mph during the heaviest precipitation which resulted in drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Fast last season system on April 2nd

Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 3 and 5 AM on April 2nd. Snow quickly became steady and heavy at times, especially around daybreak. Some of the heavier snow fell at up to rates of 1-2" per hour. Snow then tapered off between 9 and 11 AM, with flurries lingering until noon. Temperatures were between 32 and 36 degrees during snowfall before warming into low 40s in the afternoon.

Intense Storm Brings Heavy Snow, Wind & Mixed Precipitation

Even though there were some flurries late in the evening of March 13, steadier, accumulating snow developed between 12 and 3 AM on March 14, when temperatures were 30-32 degrees. Starting 6-8 AM, coastal sections of New York City begin to mix with sleet and rain as the temperature warmed to 33-36 in spots. This mixed precipitation, including some pockets of freezing rain, became increasingly widespread through the morning as precipitation intensified. Snowfall rates of 1-2” per hour were common, along with heavy sleet which made for a heavy, dense accumulation. As colder air returned during the afternoon, the wintry mix quickly changed to all snow again 1-3 PM and temperatures went back into the upper 20s to near 30. Colder air returned late in the day which changed the wintry mix and rain back to snow 3-5 PM, before precipitation tapered off 5-7 PM. In addition to the precipitation, winds were frequently 15 – 30 miles per hour, with gusts above 40 miles per hour at times, leading to blowing and drifting of snow as well.

Storm System Brings A Cold Snow on January 7th

With temperatures 20-24 degrees, snow started up from 730AM-930AM on January 7th. Temperatures would stay at 20-24 degrees for the rest of the event as light snow quickly gave way to periods of moderate to heavy intensity (0.5” – 1.0”+ / hr) snow during the late morning into the afternoon. Wind gusts of 25-35 mph were seen as well during the afternoon, accompanied by a dry, powdery snow which resulted in blowing and drifting. Then, between 9PM-11PM the snow tapered off, though pockets of blowing and drifting persisted a bit longer.

Major late season nor'easter on March 21st and 22nd

Flurries and spotty sleet began between 1 and 4 AM on March 21st, becoming steadier after 7 - 8 AM as a nor'easter moved in. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy and continued throughout the rest of the day, with sleet mixing in at times until the mid-afternoon. The heaviest of snow fell at rates up to 1-3" per hour. While snow lightened up after midnight on March 22nd, it did not completely end until 5 - 8 AM. Temperatures were initially in the mid-30s before settling between 30 and 34 degrees for the duration of the storm.

Wintry Mix Quickly Turns to Crippling Snow on February 9th

Between 2AM-4AM on February 9th, a mix of sleet and rain started up. As the early morning went on, sleet/rain transitioned to snow/sleet and then all snow from 4AM-6AM. After 6AM, all snow fell. The snow was intense throughout the morning. 1”-2” per hour rates, accompanied by thunder snow was the case as wind began to gust 25-35 mph. After 1130AM-1230PM, the snow diminished in intensity. However, the winds became even stronger, with sustained winds in the 20s and gusts 30-45 mph. Then, between 230PM-430PM, the snow storm ended. Do note, that significant blowing and drifting snow occurred both during and well after the event. Temperatures were around 40 at the start time, falling below freezing everywhere after 6AM. Temperatures were then in the mid-20s while the snow ended in the afternoon, falling to around 20 overnight.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow to Region

Initial sporadic snow developed across the area as early as 12 - 2 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the upper 20s to around 30 degrees. After a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady by 4 - 7 AM as temperatures cooled into the mid-20s where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Snow was moderate to heavy, which at times fell at the rate of 1 - 2 inches per hour through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 3 - 6 PM. In addition to the heavy snow were strong winds which were sustained at 15 - 30 mph, but gusted 45 - 55 mph at times. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.
