After a coastal system affected Long Island earlier on January 30th, additional flurries and snow showers returned after 5 - 6 PM. Temperatures were initially 32 - 35 degrees before cooling falling into the mid-20s during the evening. Snow showers and flurries then diminshed by midnight. 

Note: Snow that occurred before 5 PM with the coastal system was covered in a previous report.

Rain to snow event on February 2nd

Periods of rain developed during the evening on February 1st, with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s. Rain continued into the early morning of the 2nd, mixing and changing to a steady wet snow by 4 - 6 AM as temperatures quickly cooled between 29 - 32 degrees. Snow was light to moderate in intensity, eventually ending by 7 - 9 AM. Temperatures continued to cool between 25 - 29 degrees through the morning with gusts up to 30 - 35 mph. Flurries and brief snow showers returned across the East End between 11 AM - 2 PM, with any lingering flurries ending by sunset.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Occasional Snow and Sleet on March 2nd

A very strong coastal storm brought heavy precipitation to Long Island on March 2nd. While the majority of the precipitation fell as rain (which began late on March 1st), precipitation mixed with and even changed to combinations of snow and sleet at times during the day. The mixing with snow and sleet began as early as 7 - 10 AM, and persisted at times through the day. Most of the steady precipitation tapered down between 6 and 9 PM, though some pockets of light rain and wet snow persisted until 12 - 2 AM on March 3rd. In addition to the wintry mix of precipitation, winds were quite strong, gusting frequently up to 40 - 50 mph, with some spots exceeding 65 mph at times. At times of mixed precipitation, temperatures were mostly 33 - 37 degrees.

Morning snow showers on March 9th

After a few pre-dawn flurries on March 9th, scattered snow showers developed between 5 and 8 AM. These then tapered off to flurries by 9 - 10 AM. Temperatures were between 28 - 32 degrees during the event.

Brief wintry mix on March 20th

Pockets of sleet, mixed with some rain and brief snow, occurred between 4 and 9 PM on March 20th. Temperatures were between 36 and 40 degrees, with most accumulation found on colder/grassy surfaces. Temperatures continued to hold in the mid-to-upper 30s after sleet ended.

Overnight Lake Effect Snow on November 20th and 21st  

Snow flurries started up between 10PM-12AM on the 20th. The snow then turned into light snow after 3AM, ending by 530AM everywhere. During this time, temperatures were 32-36 degrees.

Sunday Snow on December 11th

With temperatures in the mid-30s, snow moved in from 3PM – 5PM on December 11th. The snow was light, but consistent for a few hours, ending between 7PM-9PM. During the end time, temperatures dropped down to around 32.

Wintry Mix on February 12th

Between 5 and 8 AM on February 12, combinations of snow, sleet, rain and freezing rain developed over the area with temperatures around 32. Within an hour or two of starting, precipitation trended towards snow, sleet and freezing rain as temperatures cooled to 30 - 32. Warmer air then returned to the area between 12 and 3 PM resulting in a change to plain rain between 12 and 3 PM.

Morning wintry mix on February 7th

Snow mixed with some sleet overspread Long Island between 8 - 10 AM on February 7th. With temperatures between 30 - 35 degrees, pockets of freezing rain quickly developed through the morning outside of the East End which changed to all rain due to temperatures in the mid-30s. Any wintry mix otherwise changed to rain by 11 AM - 1 PM as temperatures warmed well into the 30s and even 40s during the afternoon. Even though accumulations were not that high, they were more dense than normal due to marginal temperatures and mixed precipitation.

Evening snow showers and flurries on March 14th

Scattered snow showers and flurries developed across Long Island between 5 and 11 PM on March 14th. These became briefly heavy and steady times before tapering down to flurries through midnight on the 15th. Temperatures were between 32 and 37 degrees during the event.

A Line of Snow Showers for December 15th

Between 9AM-1PM on December 15th, a band of snow arrived. The snow only lasted for an hour or two as it passed south throughout the area, which had snow squalls embedded in them. Winds were strong during the event, gusting at 30-45 mph. Temperatures were 21-25 degrees as well, making it feel like 5-10 degrees.

Light snow on March 4th and 5th

Flurries and snow showers began as early as 7 PM on the evening of the 4th, with more widespread light snow developing mainly between 10 PM - 3 AM into the 5th. While most of the snow had finished by then, additional flurries and brief pockets of light snow did continue to fall at times across the East End until 8 - 10 AM. Temperatures were between 31 - 35 degrees under the steadiest snow.

Snow for the Business Day on January 31st

Between 830AM-1030AM on January 31st, snow began. The snow was moderate during the late morning until around noon, turning into light snow afterwards. Snow was then consistent for much of the afternoon, ending during the beginning of the PM rush hour, between 330PM-530PM. During the event, temperatures were just below freezing, at 27-31 degrees.

Second Half of Saturday Snow for January 14th

Between 2PM-4PM on January 14th, snow moved in, with temperatures around the freezing mark. The snow was light to moderate during the afternoon, turning into light snow everywhere after 7PM. The snow was then consistent for much of the evening, but ended from west to east between 930PM-1130PM. Pockets of freezing drizzle were seen while the storm ended as well. While the snow moved away, temperatures were lower than the start, at 28-32 degrees.

AM Snow Arrives on January 6th

Between 1230AM-230AM on January 6th, light snow moved in from southwest to northeast across Long Island. The snow was consistent for the rest of the overnight, with periods of moderate intensity (0.5” – 1.0”/hr) snow between 330AM-630AM in spots, especially along the North Shore. Snow continued past sunrise, ending during the AM commute, between 8AM-10AM. While it was snowing, temperatures were 27-31 degrees.

Light clipper system on December 14th

A clipper system brought snow between 12 - 3 AM on the 14th. Light to moderate snow continued through the pre-dawn hours, becoming intermittent with just flurries at times, especially toward and around dawn. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 8 - 11 AM. Temperatures were generally between 23 - 28 degrees during the event. Winds also gusted up to 25 - 30 mph at times after snow ended, leading to some blowing snow.

Mixes of snow and rain on February 17 - 18

With temperatures initially in the mid-to-upper 30s, sprinkles and flurries began falling between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th. Steady precipitation then overspread Long Island by 7 - 8 PM, with combinations of snow and rain falling through midnight as temperatures cooled between 32 - 35 degrees. Any lingering mixed showers and flurries ended by 2 - 5 AM on the 18th.

First widespread snowfall of the season on December 9th

A coastal system moving up the coast brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow first began between 9 - 11 AM as temperatures cooled from the mid-30s to between 30 - 34 degrees. As snow quickly became steadier toward mid-day, it also became moderate in intensity at times, especially between 10 AM - 3 PM. On and off light snow then continued into the evening, eventually diminishing by 11 PM - 1 AM with lingering flurries into the pre-dawn hours on the 10th. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Clipper system on December 30th

As a clipper moved on the morning of the 30th, light snow flurries developed between 8 - 10 AM. These were spotty with some areas seeing lulls before steadier snow developed toward mid-day, becoming moderate to even heavy at times between 11 AM - 3 PM. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures held between 18 - 21 degrees during snowfall.

Note: Areas that saw returning showers or flurries during the evening of 12/30 will be addressed in a separate storm summary.

Coastal storm brought accumulating snow on December 15th

Snow quickly developed between 1 - 3 PM on the 15th, and became steady for the evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. The snow came to an end west to east 8 - 11 PM. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the upper 20s to near 30, but settled to 24 - 28 degrees during the steady snow.

Intense Storm Brings Snow, Wind & Mixed Precipitation

Even though there were some flurries late in the evening of March 13, steadier, accumulating snow developed between 12 and 2 AM on March 14, when temperatures were 27-32 degrees. Starting 5-7 AM, snow began to mix with sleet and rain. By Noon, many areas were seeing mostly rain with just some occasional sleet with temperatures in the mid and upper 30s. Portions of the North Shore, however, continued to experience combinations of heavy sleet, rain and even freezing rain. Colder air returned late in the day which changed the wintry mix and rain back to snow 3-5 PM. Most of the remaining snow ended by 7 PM, though a few pockets remained until nearly 10 PM as the temperature dropped into the mid and upper 20s. In addition to the precipitation, winds were frequently 15 – 30 miles per hour, with gusts above 40 miles per hour at times.

Accumulating Snow Then Wintry Mix on December 17th

Snow developed across most of the region between 1 and 4 AM with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s. After varying intensities early on, snow fell moderate to heavy intermittently closer to sunrise, with 1" per hour rates at times. As temperatures inched to near the freezing mark, snow mixed with and changed to combinations of sleet and freezing rain between 7 and 10 AM. Further warming into the mid-30s (and the end of steady precipitation) brought an end to the icing by midday, with many places tapering off as plain rain.

March Snow Storm

Low pressure brought snow to the region on March 10th. Snow developed between 6:30 and 8:30 AM, when temperatures were 32 - 36 degrees. Snow intensity increased to a moderate to heavy intensity fairly quickly, as temperatures settled to 30 - 32 degrees. Steady snow continued into midday, though transitioned to intermittent snow showers from west to east between 12 and 3 PM, before all snow tapered off 4 - 7 PM. Following the steady snow, the temperature warmed to 32 - 35 but fell back below freezing in the evening.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to marginal temperatures and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less, and subject to considerable variations.

Fast last season system on April 2nd

Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 4:30 and 6 AM on April 2nd. Snow quickly became steady and heavy at times, especially around daybreak. Some of the heavier snow fell at up to rates of 1-2" per hour. Snow then tapered off between 10 AM and 12 PM. Temperatures were between 30 and 34 degrees during snowfall before warming into low 40s in the afternoon.

Coastal storm on January 29 - 30

Pockets of light snow and flurries developed as early as 7 - 10 PM on January 29th, quickly becoming steady by and after midnight on the 30th. Snow became moderate to heavy during the pre-dawn hours, with some of the heaviest falling at rates of 1-2" per hour. This then trended back to a light to moderate snow toward daybreak, eventually tapering down to flurries by 11 AM - 1 PM (the Twin Forks continued to see flurries through 3 - 4 PM). Temperatures were initially in the low-to-mid 30s before settling between 26 - 31 degrees during snowfall.

Note: Returning snow showers during the evening of January 30th will be covered in a separate report.

Long duration event featuring a wintry mix on March 7th and 8th

A wave of precipitation on the morning of March 7th was followed by a coastal system that developed later in the day before exiting on the 8th. The first batch of precipitation was a mix of light snow and rain across the region between 1 and 7 AM on the 7th, followed by a few lulls in precipitation afterwards. A steadier mix of rain, snow, and sleet then began after 9 AM with the coastal system. This mix switched to a heavy snow as early as 12 PM, although areas toward the East End did not change over until 3 - 6 PM. The heaviest snow was accompanied by thunder and snowfall rates up to 1-2" per hour. Combinations of rain and snow continued into the evening before eventually tapering off between 1 and 4 AM on March 8th. Temperatures were generally between 32 and 37 degrees throughout the event. Additionally, winds gusted between 35 - 45 mph during the heaviest precipitation which resulted in drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Nor'easter brings heavy snowfall on March 13th

After rain brief fell late in the evening on March 12th, precipitation changed to snow around midnight on the 13th. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the pre-dawn as heavy bands developed across Long Island. These bands produced snowfall rates up to 1-3" per hour. In addition, winds also gusted up to and over 35 - 40 mph, which resulted in blowing and drifting snow. The heavy snow gradually trended lighter after 10 AM, ending for most between 12 - 3 PM. However, heavy bands of snow continued to linger across the Twin Forks until 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures were between 31 and 36 degrees throughout the storm.

Storm System Brings A Cold Snow on January 7th

With temperatures 20-24 degrees, snow started up from 730AM-930AM on January 7th. Temperatures would stay at 20-24 degrees for the rest of the event as light snow quickly gave way to periods of moderate to heavy intensity (0.5” – 1.0”+ / hr) snow during the late morning into the afternoon. Wind gusts of 25-35 mph were seen as well during the afternoon, accompanied by a dry, powdery snow which resulted in blowing and drifting. Then, between 9PM-11PM the snow tapered off, though pockets of blowing and drifting persisted a bit longer.

The February 9th Blizzard

From 330AM-530AM on February 9th, snow, starting as rain locally at the onset began, with temperatures 35-39 degrees. Snow was light at first, but became heavy after 8AM-11AM as temperatures fell below 32 degrees. From this time until the mid-afternoon, snowfall rates of 1”-2” per hour were common. Winds were gusty after midday as well, with sustained winds of 25-35 mph and gusts up to 50mph. Snow lightened up between 2PM-5PM, ending 6PM-9PM. Blowing and drifting snow was significant and prolonged, even after the snow tapered off. Temperatures during the early evening were in the low 20s, falling into the teens overnight.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow to Long Island

Initial sporadic snow developed across Long Island as early as 12 - 2 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the upper 20s to around 30 degrees. A few spots across the Twin Forks briefly mixed with rain near 32 degrees during this time before cooling. Otherwise, after a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady by 5 - 7 AM as temperatures cooled into the middle 20s where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Snow was moderate to heavy, which at times fell at the rate of 2 - 3 inches per hour through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 4 - 7 PM, though pockets of snow persisted in spots until nearly Midnight, especially across the Twin Forks. In addition to the heavy snow, winds were very strong, sustained at 15 - 30 mph and gusted up to 45 - 60 mph at times resulting in blizzard-like conditions. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Significant late season nor'easter on March 21st and 22nd

Intermittent mixes of flurries, sleet, and rain began during the pre-dawn hours on March 21st, with temperatures initially in the mid-to-upper 30s. Precipitation quickly became steady after 8 - 9 AM as temperatures cooled to 30 and 34 degrees and held throughout the storm. Snow continued to mix with sleet at times until the mid-late afternoon, becoming moderate to heavy. Very heavy bands of snow developed across Long Island by the evening, of which fell up to rates of 2-5" per hour. Snow then trended lighter after midnight on the 22nd, although pockets of moderate snow continued to fall at times before completely ending by 7 - 10 AM.

A strong cold front changed rain to some snow and sleet on November 19-20

Areas of light rain associated with a strong cold front arrived during the evening on the 19th with temperatures that started in the 40s. As colder air filtered in, rain mixed at times with steady sleet and wet snow by 8-11 PM with temperatures that had settled to 32-36 degrees. Mixed precipaition was brief and tapered off between 11 PM and 1 AM on the 20th. After precipitation ended, temperatures became steady in the mid-30s.

Snow showers on December 9-10

Scattered snow showers and flurries developed between 1 and 4 PM on the 9th with temperatures that began in the mid-to-upper 30s. These continued intermittently into the overnight hours; however, a few more organized snow showers fell between 11 PM and 4 AM on the 10th. Any lingering flurries tapered off by 5 AM. Temperatures cooled into the mid-to-upper 20s.

A storm system produced a wintry mix early on December 12

Between 12 and 2 AM on the 12th, a steady combination of freezing rain and plain rain (mixed in spots with sleet and snow intially) began with temperatures from 30-34 degrees. While the icing threat ended in most locations by 4-6 AM as temperatures warmed above freezing, some localized spots held on to icy conditions through daybreak. Temperatures continued to rise to 35-40 degrees as rain tapered off around mid-morning.

A storm system produced a wintry mix on December 29

With temperatures that started between 29 and 33 degrees, an area of rain (mixed initially with snow/sleet in northern parts of the county) produced brief icing between 6 and 9 AM on the 29th. The icing threat ended as temperatures quickly rose to 35-40 degrees.

A disturbance produced a wintry mix on January 2

With temperatures that started between 30 and 34 degrees, light rain and pockets of freezing rain (mixed initially with sleet in spots) produced brief icing between 4 and 9 AM on the 2nd. The icing threat ended as temperatures rose into the mid-to-upper 30s through the remainder of the morning.

A disturbance produced a wintry mix across the area on January 14

Between 11 AM and 2 PM on the 14th, scattered flurries, light snow and sleet began with temperatures of 32-36 degrees. This wintry mix continued intermittently over the next few hours before transitioning to areas of light rain, freezing rain and freezing drizzle towards sunset with temperatures that cooled to 30-34 degrees. Any lingering precipitation ended for good between 8 and 11 PM. Temperatures slowly settled to 25-30 degrees overnight.

A disturbance produced snow showers on March 3

With temperatures between 35 and 40 degrees, flurries and scattered snow showers developed over the area from 2-5 PM on the 3rd. A few of snow showers contained bursts of heavy snow; however, most accumulations remained on colder surfaces. Temperatures cooled down into the upper 20s and lower 30s while the snow was falling. During the event, winds increased and gusted to 30-40 mph at times. By 7-9 PM, the last of the flurries and snow showers tapered off. Temperatures cooled to 18-23 degrees at night.

System brings snow/sleet December 24th into 25th

Light snow and sleet showers moved in on the evening of December 24th between 6 – 8 PM, however these showers quickly began to mix with rain, and became completely rain by 9 – 10 PM with temperatures that were 34 – 38 degrees. Then following overnight rain, another batch of mixed snow/sleet moved through between 4 – 6 AM. Finally, as the system exited flurries and scattered snow showers moved through on the morning of December 25th between 7:30 – 9 AM with temperatures that had dropped to 32 – 35 degrees. Winds following the event were quite strong, with gusts 40 – 50 mph.

A quick-moving system produced a wintry mix on January 8th

Light sleet and freezing rain moved in on the afternoon of January 8th between 12 – 2 PM with temperatures that were 24 – 29 degrees. Any sleet that mixed in initially quickly changed over to all freezing rain which continued through the evening before ending 7 – 10 PM. Temperatures that were steady during the event slightly cooled overnight to 19 - 24 degrees.

Flurries and light snow showers on the morning of January 16th

With temperatures 24 - 28 degrees, intermittent flurries and light snow showers moved into the area between 3 – 6 AM on the early morning of January 16th. This activity came to an end by 8 – 10 AM the same day with temperatures that gradually rose into the mid-30s by the afternoon.

Any additional accumulations from the storm overnight into January 17th will be handled in a separate report.

Brief wintry mix changes to rain on February 4th

Between 10 AM and Noon, a period of mixed snow, sleet and rain moved into the area before quickly changing to all rain between 12-2 PM. Temperatures were 33 - 36 degrees. The rain ended 8-10 PM and the temperature fell to 32 degrees in some spots late in the night.

Disturbance brings snow showers March 25

On the morning of March 25th between 5 - 8 AM, scattered snow showers moved into the area with temperatures that were initially 28 - 32 degrees. The flurries and snow showers continued generally intermittently, aside from a few better, albeit brief bursts of snow.  The activity exited the area by 11 AM - 1 PM with temperatures that had risen above freezing, specifically 43 - 47 degrees.

Cold front brings rain and snow February 1 - 2

Overnight February 1st into the 2nd between 3 - 6 AM temperatures dropped to 32 - 35 degrees as rain gave way to brief snow as the front exited. In the wake of the front, flurries and intermittent snow showers began to affect the area 7 - 8 AM before ending by 10 AM - 12 PM on February 2nd with temperatures that had further fallen to 22 - 26 degrees. Due to initially marginal temperatures, elevation played a significant role in accumulations.

Periods of Light Snow and a few Heavier Snow Showers on March 15th

Flurries and occasional light snow developed 3-6 AM with temperatures 17-23 degrees. It was not until 11 AM - Noon when snow became widespread. It snowed for the afternoon with temperatures in the 20s and while most of the snow was light, there were a few heavier squalls that moved through. The snow showers tapered by early evening and ended completely 6-9 PM. Winds during the event were gusty, at times reaching 20-35 MPH out of the Northwest

Storm brings a wintry mix February 7th

Snow and sleet showers moved into the area on February 7th between 5 – 7 AM with temperatures that were 25 – 29 degrees. Any snow/sleet was relatively short lived as the precipitation changed over to steady freezing rain between 7 – 10 AM. As the freezing rain progressed temperatures gradually warmed above freezing by 1 – 3 PM, bringing an end to additional ice accretion. Following the end of freezing rain, periods of moderate to heavy rain continued through the early evening with temperatures that climbed into the mid-upper 30s.

Snow showers on January 30

Between 12 and 3 PM on the 30th, flurries and scattered snow showers began with temperatures that started in the mid-to-upper 30s. A few of the snow showers, particularly between 2 and 7 PM, produced brief steady snow, which quickly cooled temperatures into the upper 20s and lower 30s. From 9 PM to Midnight, flurries and snow showers that lingered into the evening tapered off for good. Temperatures settled into the low-to-mid 20s overnight.

A storm system produced a wintry mix across the state on December 17

Flurries and scattered areas of light snow began as early as 1-4 AM on the 17th with temperatures that were in the low-to-mid 20s. Soon thereafter, the snow became steady for a brief time before changing to sleet and then freezing rain around daybreak. Periods of freezing rain continued into the early daylight hours before tapering off between 10 AM and 1 PM with temperatures that warmed to 32-34 degrees. For the remainder of the afternoon and into the evening, areas of fog and patchy drizzle developed. Intermittent rain showers were observed as well. Temperatures that remained steady during the period allowed for icy areas to persist. Even those at 33-34 degrees had icing issues due to colder ground surfaces that resulted from a preceding arctic air mass. The icing threat ended during the pre-dawn hours on the 18th as temperatures quickly warmed into the 40s and 50s.

Brush with a coastal storm brings snow on March 12 – 13

Flurries and intermittent snow showers (initially mixed with light rain) started to impact the area on the 12th between 5 – 8 PM with temperatures that were 33 – 36 degrees. The snow showers became steady during the late evening with temperatures that dropped to near 32 degrees. The period of snow continued at light to briefly moderate intensity during the early overnight before tapering back to lighter and more scattered activity by 1 – 4 AM. A few final flurries ended 5 – 8 AM on the 13th with temperatures that bottomed out just below 32 degrees.

Brush with a coastal storm and daytime disturbance January 30

A few light snow showers moved in on January 30th between 1 - 3 AM with temperatures that were 33 - 36 degrees. This light activity tapered off between 4 - 6 AM, before a return of light to moderate snow between 7 - 9 AM with temperatures that remained just above freezing. Snowfall was steadiest during the early afternoon, before coming to an end between 4 - 7 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 26 - 29 degrees.

Due to warm antecedent conditions pavement accumulations were variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

A late season storm brings a mix of snow, sleet, and rain April 2

Rain on the early morning of April 2nd began to mix with sleet and snow by 3 - 5 AM with temperatures that were in the mid 30s. The snow, sleet and rain mix became primarily snow and sleet around sunrise with temperatures that fell to near 32. The event ended soon thereafter, by 9 - 11 AM with temperatures that peaked in the low 40s during the afternoon. Due to marginal temperatures, pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Wintry mix on March 20 with some significant sleet accumulation

Snow moved into the region between 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM on March 20th.  Moderate snow at the onset quickly changed over to a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and patchy freezing rain through midday. There were some significant periods of sleet during the afternoon, which led to a dense accumulation on all surfaces. The wintry mix continued into the evening hours until the precipitation mostly moved out of the area between 8:30 – 10:30 PM. Any patchy drizzle that lingered was very brief and isolated. Temperatures started 33 – 36 degrees and then fell to 28 – 32 during the majority of the wintry precipitation. This report covers precipitation that occurred through midnight March 21st, an additional period of precipitation occurred on March 21st that will be covered in a separate report.

Storm brings rain, then snow on January 17

Rain began to mix with snow on the early morning of January 17th between 12 - 2 AM with temperatures that were 32 - 34 degrees. Any rain/snow mix changed over to all snow after 2 - 3 AM, continuing at light to moderate rates through the morning as temperatures dropped below freezing. Snow ended between 10 AM - 12 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 24 - 29 degrees and remained well below freezing for the remainder of the day.

Clipper brings snow on December 13 – 14th

Light snow overspread the area on December 13th between 8 – 10 PM with temperatures that were in the low-mid 20s. The snow increased in intensity and became moderate at times quickly following the onset of snow. Later the snow became a bit more intermittent and showery in nature during the early morning hours on December 14th, before ending as a final steady round of light to moderate snow which pushed through 5 – 8 AM.

A coastal storm produced snow on January 7

Between 8 and 10 AM on the 7th, a dry and powdery snow began with temperatures in the upper teens to low 20s. The snow was steady at times thru the remainder of the morning and into the early afternoon before tapering off between 2 and 5 PM. After the snow ended, temperatures cooled into the lower teens overnight. During and after the event, winds gusted at times to around 20 mph.

Quick hitting snow on December 15th

On the early afternoon of December 15th, steady snow quickly overspread the area between 12 – 2 PM, with temperatures that were 25 – 29 degrees. Soon after starting, the snow rapidly increased in intensity, with moderate to heavy snow impacting the area during the afternoon. Subsequently the snow quickly exited the area 5 – 7 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 22 – 26 degrees.

A disturbance produced light snow on January 5-6

Periods of light snow began between 8 and 11 PM on the 5th with temperatures that ranged from 27-32 degrees. The snow fell steady at times into the pre-dawn hours on the 6th before dissipating between 3 and 6 AM. Temperatures had settled into the mid-to-upper 20s by daybreak.

A period of heavy snow the evening of February 17th

Between 4-6 PM, snow started across the area and it rapidly became moderate to heavy in intensity. Snow continued through evening until ending 9-11 PM. As and after the snow stopped, patchy drizzle and fog remained into a portion of the early overnight. Temperatures throughout the event were 31-33 degrees.

A winter storm produced snow on February 9

Periods of rain that began after midnight eventually mixed with a bit of sleet and then changed to snow between 3 and 6 AM on the 9th. Temperatures that began in the low-to-mid 40s cooled to 32-34 degrees once the transition to all snow was complete. The snow was moderate to heavy at times for the next few hours with snowfall rates up to 1 inch per hour before ending from 9 AM-12 PM. Temperatures that leveled off from 25-30 degrees during the daylight hours continued to cool 17-22 degrees at night. Winds increased thru the end of the event with gusts of 30-40 mph during the day and overnight. This produced area of blowing and drifting snow into the 10th.

Clipper brings snow on December 30th

Snow overspread the area between 4 – 7 AM on the morning of December 30th with temperatures that were 14 – 19 degrees. Not long after starting, between 7 – 8 AM the snowfall rate became moderate to heavy. The moderate to heavy snowfall rates during the morning tapered off to lighter snow by 11 AM – 1 PM, followed by flurries and light snow showers. Intermittent flurries and generally light snow showers exited between 4 – 7 PM on December 30th with temperatures only rising to 24 – 28 degrees. Temperatures overnight on the 30th into the 31st dropped into the mid-teens.

Morning snow followed by afternoon and evening snow showers/squalls on March 10

It was a mild overnight from the 9th heading into the 10th with temperatures falling from 57-62 degrees on the 9th down to 36-41 degrees by 6 AM on the 10th. It was between 6-9 AM that steady snow (mixed initially with rain) developed across the area while temperatures fell to 31-35 degrees. Steady snow persisted through the morning hours before winding down and ending between 12-2 PM. Temperatures settled to 30-32 degrees thru the end of the event, and once the event ended, only rose back into the mid-to-upper 30s with breezy conditions. Close on the heels of the snow and generally between 2:30 and 9:30 PM, additional snow showers and squalls impacted the area. Some of these squalls produced heavy snow for a brief period and led to additional accumulations, generally between a coating-1.0". Increasing northwest winds that gusted to 25-30 mph ushered in very cold air dropping temperatures into the mid-to-upper teens at night.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to marginal temperatures and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less and subject to considerable variations.

A potent early season winter storm on December 9th

Flurries and intermittent light snow developed on the morning of December 9th between 8 and 10 AM with temperatures 32 – 35 degrees. The snow subsequently became steadier, and fell at a moderate rate through the early afternoon with temperatures that quickly fell below freezing, specifically 27 – 32 degrees. The snow continued into the evening between light and moderate rates, before ending completely between 10 PM and 12 AM, with temperatures that remained below freezing. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Potent Nor’easter brings wind and snow on January 4th

Light, intermittent snow overspread the area between 12 – 3 AM on January 4th with temperatures that were 22 – 25 degrees. The snow gradually increased in intensity to moderate rates by 5 – 8 AM, with periods during the late morning reaching 0.5 to 1.0” per hour. Moderate snow tapered back to lighter rates during the afternoon, before ending 4 – 6 PM aside from a few stray flurries, with temperatures that had fallen to 18 – 22 degrees. Wind gusts increased to 35 – 45 mph during the day producing significant blowing and drifting snow that lasted well after snow had ended.

The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Powerful Nor’easter Brings Rain, Snow and Wind on March 2nd

Overnight rain subsequently changed over to snow, between 9 - 11 AM as the potent coastal storm developed on March 2nd with temperatures in the upper 30s. The snow fell heavily during the afternoon, with snowfall rates around 1 inch per hour, producing extreme reductions in visibility. Snow tapered down to lighter snow and flurries by the evening, before completely ending between 10 PM to midnight. While wintry precipitation was falling, temperatures fell marginally to 32 - 36 degrees. The storm brought long duration, damaging wind gusts commonly 40 - 50 mph, with a few gusts over 60 mph, resulting in near blizzard conditions.

A significant coastal storm produced heavy mixed precipitation on March 13-14

Other than initial flurries, light snow developed over the area between 10 PM and Midnight on the 13th with temperatures starting from 28-32 degrees. Over the next few hours, snow became steady with snowfall rates up to 1.0 inch per hour and temperatures that settled to 25-29 degrees. With temperatures that remained steady, the snow changed to sleet and pockets of freezing rain from 3-5 AM, which became increasingly heavy towards daybreak. An extensive period of very heavy sleet took place, which amounted to a 2.0-4.0 inch sleet accumulation. With sleet being generally three to four times more dense than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow/sleet pack relative to the overall accumulation. From 7-10 AM, sleet began to mix with snow once again; however, this mixture lightened and became scattered thru 10 AM-12 PM. In addition, winds increased through the morning and became strong with gusts of 25-35 mph. Any lingering precipitation ended as snow between 3 and 5 PM as the temperature slightly warmed to 27-32 degrees. Winds remained gusty overnight as temperatures fell into the mid-to-upper teens.

Accumulation in the "Total" column are representative of combined non-compacted snow and sleet accumulation per standard snow measurement guidelines. Accumulation listed under "Ice" indicates any additional ice accretion from freezing rain only, if applicable.

Nor’easter brings intense, wet snow March 6 - 7

Rain on the night of March 6th began to mix with, and then quickly changed over to wet snow between 10 PM and midnight. The snow fell steadily at moderate rates during the early morning hours of March 7th. The wet snow waned somewhat during the late morning, before snowfall rates dramatically increased between 11 AM and 1 PM. During the early afternoon on the 7th the snowfall rates became very heavy, reaching 1-3” per hour, even producing lightning and thunder. This intense snow band tapered back to lighter snows by 3 - 4 PM, before completely ending by 4 - 5 PM. Temperatures that were 32 - 36 degrees for the duration of the event fell to 28 - 32 degrees at night. Due to the wet, heavy snow, there were numerous downed trees and power outages. Also, banding of snow and small differences in elevation were important factors in the significant variability of snowfall totals.

Late-season coastal storm produced some heavy snow March 21st – 22nd

A light wintry mix of rain, snow, and sleet developed across the region between 12 – 2 AM on the 21st.  Mixed precipitation changed over to snow shortly after sunrise, becoming moderate to heavy at times.  Snow continued through the day, falling at rates of up to 1 – 2 inches per hour.  The intensity of snow decreased near sundown, with light snow tapering off to a few lingering flurries between 1 – 4 AM on the 22nd.  Temperatures started at 33 – 35 during precipitation onset, falling to 28 – 32 during snowfall.

Temperatures were generally 30 - 33 degrees in snow with wind gusts to 25 - 35 mph.

Strong Coastal Storm Brings Blizzard-Like Conditions

A steady snow moved into the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM January 4th. The snow quickly became heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours, with rates reaching 2-3" per hour. As the snow became heavier, northwest winds began gusting to 40 - 50 mph, causing significant blowing and drifting snow. The steady snow and strong winds continued through the evening hours, before tapering off between 8:00 and 10:00 PM. Blowing and drifitng snow continued through the overnight hours, well after the falling snow ended. Temperatures were steady between 25 and 30 degrees throughout the event. 

Note: The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th.

Initial light rain / snow showers began as early as 12AM, before becoming a steady snow by 2 - 4AM on the 13th. Snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 7AM - 7PM when snowfall rates of 2 - 4" per hour occurred. The main area of snow ended by 11PM, though intermittent light snow lingered until 2 - 5AM on the 14th. Temperatures during the event began 33 - 37 degrees, then settled to 29 - 32 degrees throughout. Winds gusted to 25 - 35 mph.

Brief freezing rain on the 29th.

After overnight low temperatures of 22 - 26 degrees, a few brief and light freezing rain showers fell between 6 - 9AM with temperatures 30 - 32 degrees. Steadier rain moved in during the morning, but temperatures warmed to 33 - 34 degrees by that time and continued to rise through the 30s during the day as periods of plain rain fell.

Brief snow showers and squalls on the 15th.

Two rounds of snow showers and locally heavier squalls moved through the area on the 15th. The first occurred between 12 - 2PM, lasting 30 minutes or less. After a quiet period, another round of snow showers, locally heavy fell between 7 - 10PM, again generally lasting less than 1 hour. Temperatures through the day were 15 - 20 degrees, with wind gusts to 30 - 45 mph.

Freezing rain overnight of the 17th to 18th.

After snow ended earlier in the day, a few spotty freezing rain showers returned as early as 9 - 10PM on the 17th. Temperatures were still 25 - 30 degrees at this time. Steadier freezing rain then arrived after Midnight and continued into the morning on the 18th. Temperatures gradually rose during this time, and rose above 32 degrees at various times across the area. While a few spots warmed earlier, the majority of the area only warmed above 32 by 7 - 9AM, with plain rain to follow into the morning and midday.

Brief freezing rain to rain on the 26th.

A few sprinkles and sleet pellets initially fell during the afternoon of the 26th. The main period of freezing rain then occurred between 8 - 11PM, with temperatures near 32 degrees. Temperatures then rose through the night with patchy fog and a few plain rain showers.

Brief wintry mix on the 3rd.

Beginning 12 - 2AM on the 3rd, occasional brief freezing rain and sleet showers fell. This continued on and off into the early morning, ending by 7 - 10AM. Temperatrures were 31 - 34 degrees during this period. Plain rain followed later in the day with temperatures in the mid-upper 30s.

Rain to snow showers on the 22nd.

Occasional rain showers fell during the afternoon of the 22nd, beginning to mix with brief sleet and eventually turned to snow showers during the evening. This generally began between 5 - 8PM and ended by Midnight. Temperatures settled to 34 - 36 during that time, then overnight lows cooled to 29 - 32.

Afternoon Snow Showers

Flurries and scattered snow showers moved across parts of central and southern New Hampshire between 2 - 7 PM on December 16th.  Temperatures were mainly in the low to mid 20s.

Freezing Rain For Southern New Hampshire

As overnight snow exited the area, precipitation returned as freezing rain 4 - 7 AM on December 23rd.  The freezing rain fell at varying intensities on and off through the day before ending or changing to plain rain 3 - 6 PM later on the 23rd.  Temperatures started out in the mid to upper 20s early on the 23rd then climbed to 32 - 35 degrees later in the afternoon as the precipitation ended.

Some Daytime Light Snow

A period of light snow and flurries fell across parts of central and southern New Hampshire between 10 AM - 3 PM on December 30th.  Temperatures ranged from 5 to 15 degrees across the area.

Afternoon Light Snow

A period of light snow moved across southern New Hampshire between 2 - 7 PM on January 8th.  There was some sleet and rain mixed in as well.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degrees.

Overnight Snow Shower

Scattered flurries along with a brief snow shower streaked across the area between 2 - 4 AM on February 4th.  Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s.

Morning Snow Showers

Flurries along with a few light snow showers moved across the area between 9 AM - Noon on February 6th. Temperatures were in the mid to upper 20s.

Overnight Snow Showers

A period of light snow showers fell across the area between 9 PM, February 9th and 2 AM, February, 10th.  Temperatures ranged 25 - 30 degrees.

Evening And Overnight Snow Showers

Intermittent flurries and scattered snow showers streaked across the area between 4 - 9 PM on March 9th.  This was followed by another round of light snow showers between 3 - 6 AM on March 10th.  Temperatures ranged 31 - 34 degrees.

Overnight Snow Showers

Occasional flurries and scattered light snow showers moved across the area between 11 PM of March 14th and 4 AM of March 15th.  Temperatures ranged 31 - 34 degrees.

Daytime Snow Showers

Flurries and along with a few rain and snow showers fell during the afternoon hours of April 10th.  This was followed by a band of scattered snow squalls that moved across the area between 5 - 7 PM later on the 10th.  Temperatures were in the upper 30s to near 40 degrees during the afternoon, but fell to 33 - 35 degrees by evening.  Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Morning Wintry Mix

A period of snow, mixed with sleet and rain at times, moved across southern New Hampshire between 8 - 11 AM on April 19th.  Temperatures ranged 33 - 36 degrees.  Due to warmer ground temperatures, accumulations were mainly confined to colder and non-paved surfaces.

Snow showers and squalls late on the 3rd.

As an arctic front moved through, brief snow showers and locally heavier squalls fell between 7 - 11PM on the 3rd. Any heavier snow during this period generally lasted 15 minutes to 1 hour. Temperatures sharply fell as well, beginning around 30 degrees then cooling through the 20s and eventually teens, and winds began to gust to 20 - 35 mph.

Significant Ice Across Southern New Hampshire

First, a period of very light snow and sleet fell across the area between 2 – 6 AM on January 22nd with temperatures ranging 30 – 32 degrees.  After warming above freezing, intermittent plain rain and drizzle continued throughout the day.  However, temperatures fell into the 28 - 32 degree range later in the evening of the 22nd.  This allowed for periods of light freezing rain (mixed with sleet at times) to fall into the early morning hours of January 23rd.  After a break, steady freezing rain entered the area between 8 – 10 AM with temperatures remaining 28 - 32 degrees. The freezing rain continued into the early afternoon, falling heavily at times. The heavy intensity of the rain resulted in multiple rounds of re-icing and significant ice build up. The precipitation gradually changed to plain rain between Noon - 2 PM later on the 23rd as temperatures climbed into the mid 30s.

A Brief Wintry Mix

A period of light snow, sleet, and rain fell across the area between 3 - 6 AM on March 2nd. Temperatures ranged 32 - 35 degrees during the wintry mix before changing to rain.

Periods of light snow and flurries

A light mix of rain and snow showers developed across the area between 10 AM - Noon on November 13th.  The precipitation continued on and off through the afternoon as it eventually changed to mainly all snow, esepcially towards sunset.  The light snow ended between 7 - 9 PM later that evening, but additional flurries fell into the overnight with little additional accumulation.  Temperatures were in the mid 30s when the precipitation began, then fell to near freezing as the snow ended.  Most accumulations were confined to colder/grassy and non-paved surfaces.

Some Daytime Light Snow

A period of light snow and flurries fell across the area between 9 AM - 3 PM on December 29th.  It was very cold as temperatures ranged between 0 to 10 degrees.

Morning Wintry Mix

A mix of mainly light sleet and freezing rain developed across the area between 3 - 5 AM on April 15th.  The wintry mix fell intermittently through the morning before tapering off 9 - 11 AM later on the 15th.  Temperatures ranged 27 - 30 degrees.

First wintry weather of the season.

Rain turned to a brief wintry mix with sleet, then all snow beginning 6 - 8PM on the 20th. Light snow was most widespread through 10PM, with flurries and occasional snow showers lingering until 1 - 4AM on the 21st. Temperatures during this time cooled from the mid-30s to near 30 degrees.

Wintry mix to rain on the 10th.

Beginning 6 - 7PM, light snow arrived mixed with sleet at times. By 9PM, this mix turned to mainly freezing rain, ending by 11PM across the area. Temperatures during this period began 30 - 32, then rose to 34 - 37 by the end. Plain rain showers followed after.

Brief period of snow on the 24th.

Snow began between 11AM - 12PM on the 24th, lasting 1 - 2 hours. By 2PM, snow began to mix with sleet and rain, before ending as a few plain rain showers after 4PM. Temperatures settled to 32 - 34 degrees during the wintry weather, then rose and held in the mid-30s into the evening and night.

Period of wet snow on the 25th.

Rain showers moved in late morning on the 25th. As precipitation intensified, this turned to a period of snow beginning 1130AM - 1PM. A wet snow lasted for a few hours, ending by 4PM. Temperatures settled to 33 - 35 degrees during this time, resulting in most accumulation on colder surfaces.

Overnight Light Snow

Periods of light snow and flurries fell across the area between Midnight and 6 AM on March 5th.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 33 degrees.

Overnight Snow Showers

After some flurries during the evening of March 24th, snow showers developed across the area between 11 PM - 1 AM.  The snow showers fell intermittently through the overnight before ending 6 - 8 AM on March 25th.  Temperatures ranged 30 - 34 degrees.  There were some additional snow showers that returned during the afternoon later on the 25th.

April Morning Snowfall

A steady, light snow developed over the area between 6 - 8 AM on April 2nd.  The snow fell through the morning, briefly moderate at times, before ending 11 AM - 1 PM.  Temperatures ranged 29 - 33 degrees.  Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Light snow early on the 6th.

Flurries began after Midnight, and turned to steadier light snow between 1 - 2AM on the 6th. Light snow continued into the morning hours, ending by 9 - 10AM. Temperatures during the event were 21 - 25 degrees, resulting in a fluffy snow.

Period of Snow the morning of February 1st

After a few scattered flurries and light snow showers developed between 1-4 AM, widespread snow started 3-6 AM. This period of steady, but light snow continued until 9-11 AM. Temperatures were 26 - 30 degrees.

Another light snow event on the 7th.

Light snow began between 3 - 5AM on the 7th and continued into the morning hours. It ended 8 - 10AM, mixed with drizzle in spots with temperatures steady at 31 - 33 degrees.

A Wintry Mix For Southern New Hampshire

Areas of light snow developed across the regions 3 - 6 AM on December 18th.  The snow fell on and off through the day before mixing with and changing to sleet and freezing rain during the evening hours later on the 18th.  The wintry mix came to an end by Midnight on December 19th.  Temperatures were in the low to mid 20s when the snow began, then climbed into the low 30s before the precipitation exited the area.

Overnight Rain To Light Snow

Rain showers developed over the area around Midnight on February 2nd.  However, as a cold front pushed across the region, the rain changed to snow between 2 - 4 AM.  Periods of light snow continued into the morning before ending 7 - 9 AM later on the 2nd.  Temperatures were in the low 30s when the rain changed to snow, then fell into the mid and upper 20s as the snow tapered off.

Morning Light Snow

Periods of light snow and flurries fell across the area between 4 - 10 AM on March 22nd.  Temperatures ranged from 30 - 34 degrees.

New Years Eve Snow and rain.

Periods of light snow began between 6 - 8PM on the 31st and continued into the overnight. By 12 - 2AM, most places changed to rain, before ending by 4AM. With temperatures 31 - 35 during the event, the region saw variability in snowfall with hills seeing more than valleys. By daybreak, the sky cleared and temperatures settled back near 32 degrees.

Snow showers and squalls on the 10th.

Light snow from a southern system grazed the area on the 10th, beginning 9 - 11AM and ending by 2PM. This was quickly followed by scattered snow showers and locally heavier snoq squalls, and continued at times into the evening before ending by 8 - 10PM. Temperatures during the event were mainly 28 - 32 degrees, then sharply cooled into the evening and overnight as winds began to gust to 25 - 35 mph.

A Period Of Snow, Then Sleet And Rain 

Snow arrived across the area between 6:30 - 7:30 AM on February 25th. The snow continued for about 1 - 2 hours before mixing with rain and sleet at times. By 11 AM, the mixed precipitation turned to all rain. Temperatures during the wintry part of the event event held 30 - 33 degrees, then climbed into the mid 30s by early afternoon.

Snow on December 22nd.

An initial period of light snow occurred between 5 - 8AM. After a brief break, snow returned between 9 - 10AM, then ended by 12 - 1PM. Temperatures through the event were 28 - 32 degrees. Patchy fog then followed into early overnight.

More April Snow

Snow developed across the area between 11 AM - 1 PM on April 6th.  The snow fell moderate to even briefly heavy at times before tapering off between 4 - 6 PM later in the afternoon.  Temperatures were in the mid to upper 30s when the snow began, then fell to 32 - 34 degrees during the snowfall.  Due to warm pavement temperatures, most of the snow accumulation occurred on colder, non-paved surfaces.

Overnight Wintry Mix

A mix of sleet and freezing rain developed across the area between 8 - 10 PM on April 15th.  The wintry mix fell intermittently through the night (also mixed with snow at times) before changing to just rain between 5 - 7 AM on April 16th.  Temperatures ranged 29 - 33 degrees.

Snow falls across southern New Hampshire 2/22/2018

Precipitation moved into the region between 12:00 and 2:00 PM on Feb 22nd, starting as a rain-snow mix before quickly changing over to snow. Snow fell moderately at times with snow rates of up to 0.5" per hour, with snow ending between 4:00 and 5:00 PM. Temperatures during the event hovered between 29 and 32 degrees.

Strong Nor'easter brings long duration wintry mix.

With an onshore flow off the ocean, a few flurries and brief snow showers fell during the late morning into the afternoon of the 23rd with temperatures around 32 degrees. The main, steadier and heavier area of precipitation arrived during the evening, between 8 - 10PM. This brought significant sleet, mixed with snow and freezing rain at times through the overnight and resulted in a very dense accumulation. By the morning of the 24th, this tapered to freezing drizzle with temperatures near 32 degrees. Temperatures rose and held 33 - 36 degrees the remainder of the day, with intermittent drizzle, and a few rain and sleet showers that lasted into the early overnight. Winds gusted to 30 - 45 mph through the event.

Snow, Then A Wintry Mix

Snow developed across the area between 3 - 6 AM on December12th as low pressure approached New England.  The snow continued through the morning before mixing with and changing to sleet and some freezing rain between 1 - 3 PM.  The sleet and freezing rain then changed back to a another period of snow before ending 5 - 7 PM later on the 12th.  Temperatures were in the mid and upper 20s when the snow began then rose to near 32 degrees as the snow changed to sleet and freezing rain.

Light snow into the start of February.

Occasional flurries began during the late afternoon of the 31st. Steadier snow then arrived between 7 - 9PM and continued light to briefly moderately through the overnight hours. By 9 - 11AM on February 1st, snow ended. Temperatures during the event were 23 - 27 degrees.

Snow early on the 11th.

Snow began just before Midnight, between 10 - 11PM on the 10th and continued into the morning of the 11th, light to occasionally moderately. By the midday, snow became more intermittent, ending by 12 - 3PM. Temperatures during the event were 10 - 17 degrees.

Light snow on the 7th.

Snow began between 11AM - 1PM on the 7th. Snow, light to briefly moderate continued through the remainder of the day into the early overnight, ending 12 - 2AM on the 8th. With temperatures 15 - 20 degrees, snow was light and fluffy again. Because of this, as winds began to gust to 15 - 25 mph later in the event, some blowing and drifting occurred.

Snow on December 5th.

Snow began between 6 - 7AM on the 5th with temperatures in the mid-upper 20s. Snow continued light to moderately through the midday and early afternoon, before ending 1 - 3PM. A few places briefly ended mixed with rain as temperatures rose near 32 degrees.

Another round of snow on the 15th to 16th.

After briefly mixing with rain at the onset, snow began between 7 - 9PM on the 15th. Periods of light snow continued through the overnight, before mainly ending 7 - 9AM on the 16th. Temperatures during this time settled from 32 - 35 degrees to 26 - 30 degrees. Occasional flurries lingered during the daytime of the 16th as wind gusts increased to 15 - 30 mph at times.

Long duration wintry event.

After beginning briefly as sleet and rain, snow began between 5 - 7PM on the 17th. A wet snow continued into the overnight, and with temperatures 32 - 34 degrees, snow totals were variable within subtle elevation differences. The first period of snow lightening up by 3 - 5AM, though periods of light snow lingered through the day of the 18th, occasionally mixed with freezing drizzle as temperatures settled to 30 - 32 degrees. By the evening this tapered to flurries and occasional freezing drizzle, which ended by 12 - 3AM on the 19th with temperatures in the upper 20s.

More Snow For New Hampshire

Snow developed across southern New Hampshire between 4 - 7 AM on December 22nd as low pressure and a warm front approached New England.  The snow fell at varying intensities (along with a few breaks) through the day and into the evening (mixed with sleet at times) before tapering off between 7 - 10 PM later on the 22nd.  This was followed by a period of light sleet then freezing rain that developed after 4 AM on December 23rd and continued into the morning, but this will be covered in another Certified Snowfall Total report.  Temperatures were in the low to mid teens when the snow began, then climbed into the mid and upper 20s by the time the snow ended.

Long duration snow to wintry mix.

Initial flurries and on and off light snow began between 12 - 3AM on the 7th. Steadier, moderate snow then arrived between 7 - 9AM and continued through the day as temperatures settled to 25 - 30 degrees. By the evening, after 5PM sleet began to mix with snow at times as temperatures further cooled to 20 - 25 degrees. By 10PM, the wintry mix turned to mainly sleet and freezing rain, which ended 5 - 7AM on the 8th.

Another snow event, briefly ending as a mix.

Snow began between 10PM - 11PM on the 11th and continued into the morning of the 12th with moderate snow between 4 - 8AM. Towards 8AM, snow began to mix with brief sleet, then a period of freezing rain before ending by 10 - 11AM. Temperatures at the start of the event were in the upper 20s, then gradually rose to 32 - 34 by the end.

Another December snow event on the 17th.

Light snow began between 230 - 330AM on the 17th. Snow became moderate to heavy at times during the morning and midday. As snow ended between 1 - 3PM, it briefly ended mixed with freezing drizzle and sleet. Temperatures at the beginning of the event were 10 - 14 degrees, then rose to into the low 20s by the end.

The freezing rain that followed overnight of the 17th to 18th will be covered in a separate storm event.

Snow to Wintry Mix Event.

Snow began 10:30 - 11:30AM on the 7th and quickly turned moderate to heavy. This snow continued through the afternoon, before turning to a wintry mix of brief sleet, then freezing rain by 3 - 5PM. Freezing rain, heavy at times continued into the evening before ending as light snow again between 8 - 10PM. Temperatures through the event held 26 - 31 degrees. The changing of precipitation types made this a very dense accumulation that was heavier than normal.

A Weekend Snowstorm For New England

A widespread snowfall occurred over much of New Hampshire this past weekend as low pressure developed off Cape Cod.  Snow began across the area between 11 AM - 2 PM on December 9th.  The snow continued through the afternoon and into the overnight before tapering off between 2 - 5 AM on December 10th.  Temperatures ranged 27 - 32 throughout the event.

Low Pressure Brings Overnight Snowfall

Snow developed across the area between 8 - 10 PM on February 17th.  The snow quickly became steady, then fell heavy at times overnight as snowfall rates reached 1" per hour.  It tapered off between 6 - 8 AM on February 18th.  Temperatures ranged 25 - 30 degrees throughout the event.

More Snow For Southern New Hampshire

A slow moving storm system produced another widespread snowfall across southern New Hampshire.  Flurries and some light snow showers fell during the late afternoon hours of January 16th, but a steadier snow developed 7 – 10 PM later that evening.  The snow fell at varying intensities (including some pockets of heavy snow) through the overnight and morning hours of January 17th before tapering off to flurries during the early afternoon.  A final “band” of snow moved through towards evening before exiting the area 7 - 9 PM later on the 17th.  Temperatures ranged 28 – 33 throughout the event.

A White Christmas For New Hampshire

Snow developed across the area between 11 PM on December 24th and 2 AM, December 25th.  The snow fell at varying intensities into the morning before tapering off 9 AM - Noon later on the 25th.  Also, additional snow showers fell across the area during the evening hours of the 25th.  Temperatures ranged 20 - 25 degrees throughout the storm.  Also, there was some blowing and drifting of the snow as the wind gusted over 30 mph, especially during the late morning and afternoon hours of December 25th.

Major winter storm on the 29th.

After a few flurries as early as 7 or 8AM, steadier snow arrived between 10AM - 12PM on the 29th with temperatures near 32 degrees. Light to moderate snow into the early afternoon resulted in a general 1 - 2" before turning to rain for a period between 3 - 6PM as temperatures rose to 33 - 36. This melted and compacted the snow. But by the evening, rain turned back to snow, becoming moderate to heavy at times with temperatures near 32 degrees again before ending by Midnight.

Totals are representative of snow that fell prior to and after the afternoon rain.

Another significant storm 12th to 13th.

Snow began between 9 - 11AM on the 12th, and quickly became moderate to heavy through the afternoon and evening. During the overnight snow lightened before mainly ending 6 - 9AM on the 13th, though flurries lingered at times during the day. Winds increased through the event and after, gusting 30 - 45 mph which resulted in prolonged blowing and drifting of snow. Temperatures during the event were in the low-mid 20s, then rose to 25 - 30 degrees on the 13th.

Long Duration April Fools Storm.

Snow began between 9 - 11AM on March 31st. Snow continued through the day, light to moderately as temperatures settled to 32 - 34 degrees. A steady snow continued into the overnight, and mixed with sleet at times, especially in southern areas. Any mixing turned back to all snow by 8AM on April 1st, and a steady light to moderate snow continued through the daytime. Snow lightened in the afternoon, and ended mixed with rain in spots by 7 - 9PM as temperatures rose to 34 - 36 degrees. Just a few flurries returned around Midnight as temperatures settled back to 32 degrees.

Very heavy snow on the 9th.

Snow began between 6 - 8AM on the 9th and quickly turned very heavy. Consistent snowfall rates of 1 - 3" per hour fell through the morning into the early afternoon, before lightening and finally ending 6 - 8PM. Temperatures during the event began 25 - 29 degrees, then settled to around 20 degrees for majority of snowfall before ending in the teens. Winds increased throughout this time, gusting to 20 - 30 mph in the afternoon, and up to 30 - 45 mph after snows end into the overnight. This resulted in significant and prolonged blowing and drifting of snow.

Strong Nor'easter For New Hampshire

A strong nor'easter produced widespread snowfall across New Hampshire.  After a brief period of flurries, snow developed over the area between 6 - 9 AM on January 4th.  The snow continued, heavy at times (snow rates peaked at 2 - 3" per hour), through the morning and afternoon before tapering off 7 - 10 PM later on the 4th.  Additional flurries fell during the overnight and into the early morning hours of January 5th.  Also, winds gusted over 40 - 50 mph creating blizzard-like conditions.  Temperatures ranged 20 - 26 degrees throughout the entire storm before falling into the teens by the morning of the 5th.

The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Major Coastal Storm March 7 - 8th

After a few flurries fell early on the 7th, between 12 - 4AM, a lull occurred most of the day. Steady snow built in between 2 - 4PM, quickly turning moderate to heavy. Snow continued through the night and into the 8th, with the peak of the storm between 5PM - 5AM where 1 - 2" per hour snowfall occurred. Snow lingered much of the daytime of the 8th, generally light to moderate intensity before ending 4 - 7PM. Temperatures during the event were mainly 30 - 32 degrees, then rose to 32 - 35 during the daytime of the 8th. Winds gusted to 25 - 35 mph at times.

Major March Nor'Easter brings heavy snow.

Snow began between 5 - 6AM on the 14th, and quickly turned heavy after 8AM with continual rates of 1-2" per hour through the day. By 7PM snow intensity lessened a bit, though remained moderate until ending as flurries 12 - 1AM on the 15th. Temperatures during the event began near 25 degrees, then held 28 - 32 degrees during most of the snow. Wind gusts were as high as 30 - 45 mph at times, resulting in blowing and drifting.

Another major coastal storm March 13 - 14th

Initial flurries and occasional light snow showers began late evening on March 12th with temperatures near 35 degrees. This transitioned to a steadier snow by 3 - 5 AM on the 13th, as temperatures settled below 32 degrees.  The snow quickly became moderate to heavy through the storm, with the peak between 8 AM - 8 PM as snowfall rates reached 2 - 4" per hour within the heaviest snow bands. The main area of snow ended by Midnight of March 14th, however, light snow lingered through the remainder of the overnight into the morning of the 14th before ending 9 AM - Noon. Temperatures held 28 - 32 degrees during snowfall and winds gusted to 20 - 35 mph.

Mixed rain/snow showers occurred during the PM of Nov. 20th thru the AM of the 22nd.

Periods of mixed rain to snow showers arrived between 1 - 4 PM on November 20th with temperatures in the upper-30s to low-40s. During the evening, temperatures quickly dropped into the mid-30s, allowing any rain and/or rain/snow showers to change over to all snow showers. These lake-effect light snow showers & flurries occurred periodically all the way through the early morning of the 22nd (ending between 2 - 5 AM), particularly across the Hartford River Valley & surrounding areas. Those within the Hartford metro area hovered between 32 - 37 degrees throughout this time period, while those in the higher elevations hovered around 32 degrees.

Note: Steadier bursts of snow did occur in far southwestern Hartford County during the Midday period of the 21st, then another burst of steady snow in sections of northwestern Tolland County from 4 - 7 PM on the 21st. Under these steadier bursts of snow, winds were able to gust to 25 - 35 mph.

A wintry mix of snow, sleet, freezing rain and rain impacted the area Dec. 6th-7th.

A light wintry mix of rain with pockets of sleet entered the area between 8 - 11 PM on December 6th with temperatures of 34 - 39 degrees. Particularly in the elevations and highest hilltops not long after the onset, steadier precipitation transitioned over to mainly snow with pockets of sleet, freezing rain, and rain as temperatures dipped to 32 - 35 degrees. Those within the lower elevations saw a rain, sleet, and wet snow mix with accumulations mainly on colder and elevated surfaces as temperatures hovered in the mid-to-upper 30s. Precipitation transitioned mainly to drizzle with pockets of freezing drizzle within the highest elevations before ending between 5 - 8 AM on the 7th.

Lake effect flurries & snow showers continued into December 9th.

Light flurries/very light snow with a narrower, localized band of a steadier lake effect snow shower moved into the area between 3 - 6 AM on December 9th. While additional accumulations became limited after 7 - 9 AM, flurries did continue all the way up through Noon, especially across extreme northwestern Litchfield county. Temperatures in the higher elevations held 28 - 32 degrees, while those in the lower elevations were near to just slightly above freezing.

Periods of freezing rain and drizzle returned overnight from December 17th-18th.

Periods of freezing rain moved into the area between 7 and 10 PM on December 17th with temperatures ranging from 29 to 32 degrees. Pockets of freezing rain and drizzle continued through 1 - 3 AM on the 18th across the southern portion of Hartford county as temperatures rose into the mid-to-upper 30s, but continued through 6 and 8 AM across the northern tier as it took longer for temperatures to rise into the mid-to-upper 30s to completely eliminate the icing threat.

Scattered snow showers & snow squalls began between 1 - 3 PM on December 30th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 3 - 5 PM. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event, with wind gusts of 25 - 35 mph.

Light mixture of sleet, freezing rain, and plain rain affected the region on Jan 2nd.

A few light rain showers with pockets of freezing rain and sleet pellets moved into mainly southern Hartford county between 10a - 1p on January 2nd. The light and scattered precipitation continued through much of the daytime and into the evening. It took until 6 - 9 PM for these scattered wintry mix showers to reach northern Hartford county before they exited completely. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees.

A few mixed snow, sleet & rain showers began between 5 - 7 PM on January 10th. The last of the showers exited from 7 - 9 PM. Although temperatures were 32 - 37 degrees, precedingly cold temperatures resulted in pavements being colder than the surrounding air temperatures.
Periods of light snow & flurries developed between 5 - 8 PM on January 14th. The last of the flakes ended from 8 - 10 PM. Temperatures held 25 - 28 degrees throughout the event.

Intermittent periods of flurries and light snow showers began between 8 - 11 AM on February 2nd. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 6 - 9 PM. Temperatures during the early morning and evening were 29 - 32 degrees, but were 33 - 38 degrees Midday and afternoon.

Brief shot of sleet, then icing from February 7th-8th.

A wintry mix of rain and freezing rain with a brief shot of sleet at the onset began between 6 - 8 AM on February 7th. While the southern half and lower elevations of Hartford county hovered at 32 - 37 degrees during the daytime, resulting in less pockets of freezing rain, the northern half and especially the elevations failed to warm above freezing, resulting in primarily freezing rain as temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees. During the evening in-between scattered rain and freezing rain showers, dense fog and freezing fog developed as all areas fell below freezing. The last of the periods of freezing rain and drizzle ended from 4 - 6 AM on the 8th.
Other than some scattered rain showers early on, a heavier squall between 6 - 10 PM resulted in a changeover to steady snow. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event.

Scattered snow showers & flurries occurred on March 3rd.

Other than a few flurries during the afternoon, better snow showers & flurries began between 5 - 8 PM on March 3rd. The last of the flakes dissipated not long after, between 8 - 10 PM. Temperatures at the onset of 27 - 32 degrees fell to 18 - 23 degrees by the end of the event (direct coastline a little warmer at 23 - 28 degrees).

Scattered flurries and light snow showers began between 9 PM - Midnight on March 10th. The last of the lake-effect snow showers & flurries dissipated from 1 - 4 AM on the 11th. Temperatures at the onset in the low-to-mid 20s fell into the upper single digits to low-teens.

Intermittent flurries & snow showers began between 9 AM - Noon on March 15th. The last of the flakes dissipated completely from 4 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 22 - 27 degrees during the duration of the snow showers & flurries.

Scattered wintry mix showers of snow, sleet, and rain occurred between 12-10 PM on March 18th. Temperatures at the onset were in the mid-30s, rose to late day highs in the upper-30s to low-40s, then settled back down to 32-37 degrees by the end of the event.

A burst of scattered snow showers & flurries moved through between 1 - 4 AM on November 20th. While temperatures overall were in the mid-to-upper 30s, under steadier snow showers, temperatures dipped to 33 - 36 degrees.

Some flurries and even a little wintry mix on the front and backside of a disturbance.

Intermittent flurries worked in between 12 - 2 AM on the 12th with temperatures around 32 degrees. Not long after daybreak, a steady rain moved in, with temperatures rising to 36 - 41 degrees. A bit of snow and sleet mixed in with the rain on the backside of the system before ending between 2 - 5 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event were in the mid-to-upper 30s.

Intermittent flurries & a brief band of very light snow occurred on December 16th.

Intermittent flurries began between Noon - 3 PM on December 16th with temperatures around 32 degrees. However, a slightly better band of flurries & light snow pushed through between 4 - 7 PM, with the last of any flakes dissipating by 8 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event settled to 29 - 32 degrees.

Low pressure brings a wintry mix, then long-duration icing event December 22-23.    

Intermittent light snow & sleet entered the area between 11 AM and 2 PM on the 22nd with temperatures of 25 - 30 degrees. The snow mixed with a bit of sleet and freezing rain during the evening as temperatures rose slightly to 27 - 32 degrees. Although there was a bit of a lull overnight, there were some pockets of freezing fog and freezing drizzle. Freezing rain returned to the area between 3 and 6 AM on the 23rd. The freezing rain continued through the afternoon, before ending 5 to 8 PM that evening. Temperatures rose to 32 - 37 by the end of the event. The long duration of freezing rain caused repeated periods of icing.
Scattered light snow showers occurred between 12 - 3 AM on February 1st. Temperatures held 26 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

Brief period of snow during the morning of February 6th

A band of snow showers moved across the area between 8:30 - 10:30 AM Feb 6th.  Most of the snow showers were light, but there were brief bursts of moderate snow. Temperatures were between 25 - 28 degrees during the event.

Scattered wintry mix showers of freezing rain with pockets of sleet & snow began between 3 - 6 AM on February 14th. The last of the showers dissipated from 6 - 8 AM. Temperatures at the onset of 27 - 32 degrees rose near to just above 32 degrees by the end.

Rain showes mixed with sleet and snow before changing completely over February 22nd.

Rain showers the morning of the 22nd mixed with sleet and snow between 11 AM and 2 PM. Any mixture quickly changed to all snow from 2 - 4 PM. The snow came to an end between 5 and 7 PM. Temperatures began between 34 - 39 degrees, but fell to 32 - 34 degrees by the end of the event. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Offshore coastal system was still able to produce snow showers from March 4th-5th.

What started as scattered rain showers during the late afternoon on the 4th quickly transitioned to snow showers from 4 - 6 PM. These periodic snow showers persisted into the overnight, dissipating completely from 7 - 9 AM on the 5th. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event.

Periodic scattered snow/sleet/rain showers began between 5 - 8 AM on March 9th. The last of the wintry mix showers dissipated completely from 4 - 7 AM on the 10th. Temperatures at night were 27 - 32 degrees, then rose upwards of 35 - 40 degrees during the middle of the day.
A rain, sleet, and snow mix developed between 4 - 7 AM on the 19th. The last of the wintry mix exited from 7 - 10 AM. Temperatures held 32 - 37 degrees throughout the event.

Snow squalls moved through between 7 and 10 AM on December 15th. After a brief break, a few isolated flurries & very light snow showers returned between 11 AM and 2 PM. Temperatures held 21 - 26 degrees throughout the event with wind gusts of 35 - 45 mph.

A potent low pressure system swept across the state on December 29th.

A period of steady snow moved in between 9 - 11 AM on December 29th with starting temperatures of 28 - 32 degrees in the elevations and 32 - 35 in the valley. While areas mainly within the valley and lower elevations quickly changed over to rain with a brief pocket of sleet midday, those within the northern tier and higher elevations remained primarily snow until changing to rain with pockets of freezing rain in the afternoon (1 - 3 PM) as temperatures rose to 33 - 38 degrees. While those within the valley were too warm and saw primarily rain with just a few pockets of wet snow mixing in on the backside, higher elevations changed over to snow before ending from 6 - 9 PM. Temperatures at the end of the event hovered 32 - 35 degees.

Note: Elevation was a driving factor in overall snowfall totals due to temperatures throughout the event and a resulting changeover to rain, if it all. As a result, variations within zip codes were witnessed during this event, and the total assigned is the most representative of that particular zip code.

A long-duration wintry event occurred from March 31st - April 1st.

Rain during the early morning hours on March 31st mixed with some pockets of sleet (mainly across northern Hartford county) between 5 and 8 AM with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s. Precipitation changed back to all rain Midday with temperatures hovering in the upper-30s. However, during the evening, sleet mixed back in from 6 - 9p across northern Hartford county, but it took closer to Midnight for much of southern Hartford county. Snow even mixed gradually from Midnight - 3 AM. Winds gusted up to 25 - 30 mph. Temperatures began to settle near to just above 32 degrees, resulting in pockets of freezing rain. This wintry mix of rain, freezing rain, sleet, and snow continued into the daylight hours before tapering off from Noon - 3p. Thereafter, the weather was fairly quiet, though there were a few spotty light snow showers & flurries as late as 4 - 7p. Temperatures by the end of the event rose back into the upper-30s.
Scattered light snow showers & flurries developed between 1 - 4 PM on February 9th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 PM. Temperatures held 27 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Scattered snow squalls & intermittent light snow occurred from March 14th-15th.

Scattered snow showers and squalls worked in between 3 - 6 PM on the 14th. Although the squalls exited completely from 6 - 9 PM, some lingering areas of intermittent flurries & very light snow persisted until 12 - 3 AM on the 15th. Temperatures fell from 34 - 39 degrees at the onset to near 32 by the end of the event.
