Snow mixed in with the rain on April 10th.

A snow/rain mix began between 5 - 7 AM on the 10th. While the lower elevations and city areas were more rain than snow, areas in the higher elevations in suburban & rural areas hung onto more snow. A transition to all rain occurred from Noon - 2 PM. Temperatures held 33 - 38 degrees throughout the event. Accumulations were confined to colder/grassy surfaces due to marginal temperatures.

A wintry mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain occurred on January 8th.

Light freezing rain and sleet within the river valley with more snow and sleet in the elevations developed between 2 and 4 PM on the 8th. All areas quickly changed over to light snow from 3 - 5 PM. The last of the flakes dissipated from 6 - 8 PM. Temperatures held 26 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

A steady lake-effect band of snow moved through between 10 PM on December 15th and 2 AM on the 16th. Temperatures gradually fell from the upper-teens to near 20 into the low-to-mid teens during the event. Winds gusted up to 30 - 40 mph, as well.

Rain gradually mixed with, then changed over to all snow February 1st - 2nd.

Periods of rain began to mix with some snow from 10 PM on the 1st - 1 AM on the 2nd as temperatures dipped to 33 - 36 degrees. A complete changeover to all snow occurred from 1 - 4 AM due to temperatures dipping near to just below 32 degrees. The last of the flakes dissipated from 5 - 7 AM. Temperaturs by the end of the event settled down to 26 - 31 degrees.

A cold fall storm brings the first measurable snowfall of the season October 27, 2016.

Between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM on the 27th, light to moderate snow pushed into the region with temperatures in the upper 30s. As the snow continued, temperatures fell to 32 - 33 with snow (occassionally mixed with sleet) falling moderate to heavy at times between 2 and 4 PM. The wintry precipitation transitioned to plain rain 4:00 - 7:00 PM as temperatures warmed into the mid 30s. The heaviest snow fell on hilltops and areas north of I-84.

Snow mixed with a few pockets of rain & sleet impacted the area on Dec. 5th.

Light to occasional steady bursts of snow arrived across the area between 4 - 6 AM on December 5th. A few pockets of sleet and rain mixed in between 9 AM - Noon within the valleys and cities before ending. Starting temperatures of 28 - 32 degrees rose near to slightly above freezing at the tail end of the event.

Very late season wintry storm impacted the northern half of the state April 15th-16th.

Scattered freezing rain and sleet showers with a few pockets of snow & plain rain began between 7 - 9 PM on the 15th. The last of the wintry mix was able to transition to all plain rain showers from 5 - 8 AM on the 16th. While temperature at the onset were 32 - 35 degrees, they dipped to 29 - 32 degrees for majority of the event, then rose back above freezing during the early morning on the 16th.
Periods of light snow developed between 9 - 11 PM on February 10th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 3 - 5 AM on the 11th. Temperatures held 19 - 24 degrees throughout the event.

A brief period of light snow impacted the evening commute on December 15th.

Light snow began between 4 - 6 PM on the 15th. The last of the flakes dissipated from 8 - 10 PM. Temperatures held 21 - 25 degrees throughout the event.

Clipper system brought some snow to the region on December 30th.

Light snow began between 8 - 10 AM on the 30th. During the early afternoon, snow became briefly moderate in intensity in southern Hartford county. The last of the flakes dissipated from 4 - 6 PM. Temperatures generally held 13 - 18 degrees throughout the event, however in the steadiest afternoon snow, did dip as low as 8 - 13 degrees.

Steady light snow transitioned to a brief wintry mix then all plain rain Dec. 11th-12th.

Light snow overspread the area between 5 - 8 PM on December 11th with temperatures of 26 - 31 degrees. Snow began to transition to a wintry mix of pockets of sleet, freezing rain, and rain (more rain in the urbanized areas, freezing rain within the elevations) between 3 - 6 AM on the 12th as temperatures warmed near to slightly above 32 degrees. Precipitation changed over to plain rain (perhaps just a few rogue sleet pellets) as temperatures rose safely above freezing from 6 - 9 AM.
Period of snow (mixed with rain at times) began between 8 - 11 AM on the 6th. The last of the wet flakes dissipated from 1 - 4 PM. Temperatures held in the mid-to-upper 30s.

Snow to brief sleet then a period of freezing rain occurred on February 7th.

Light snow began between 8 and 10 AM on the 7th with temperatures of 21 - 25 degrees. The snow fell briefly moderate to heavy at times during the midday hours before mixing with a bit of sleet, then changing over to all freezing rain from 1 - 3 PM. Freezing rain continued into the evening before ending as brief light snow & flurries between 9 - 11 PM. Temperatures rose to 29 - 32 degrees.

Due to the multiple precipitation types, accumulations were denser and therefore heavier than normal.

Light snow overspread the region between 1 - 3 AM on the 14th. The steadiest snow exited from 8 - 10 AM, with any lingering flurries tapering off by Noontime. Temperatures during the snowfall event held 21 - 26 degrees.

A complex wintry system brought snow to the area from January 16th-17th.

A few flurries and intermittent light snow began to work in as early as 9 - 11 AM on the 16th with temperatures of 23 - 26 degrees. However, the steadier snow took until 11 PM - 2 AM going into the 17th with temperatures of 29 - 32 degrees. The snow continued into the daytime on the 17th before exiting from 3 - 5 PM. However, a few flurries lingered as late as 7 - 9 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event hovered around 32 degrees.

A storm system clipped the north-central portion of the state from January 29th-30th.

Light to occasionally steady snow began between 11 PM on the 29th to 2 AM on the 30th with temperatures of 27 - 32 degrees. The light snow from the main system tapered off completely from 9 - 11 AM as temperature settled into the mid-to-upper 20s. While most areas were dry for the rest of the calendar day, those within the higher hills saw a few flurries or very light snow showers between 9 - 11 PM with much colder temperatures in the upper-teens to low-20s.

Periods of light to occasionally moderate snow occurred on January 6th

Light to occasionally moderate snow developed between 1 - 3 AM on January 6th. The last of the snow exited from 9 - 11 AM. Temperatures held 24 - 28 degrees throughout the event.

Coastal storm #4 clipped the region with some light snow from March 21st-22nd.

Light snow developed between 4 - 6 PM on the 21st. The snow fell intermittently at times before tapering off completely from 8 - 10 AM on the 22nd. Temperatures hovered in the mid-to-upper 30s during the entire event.

Nor'easter brought a wintry mix to the region from January 23rd-25th.

A few light pockets of rain & flurries began between 7 - 10 AM on January 23rd with temperatures of 33 - 36 degrees. A steadier wintry mix of rain & sleet with pockets of snow & freezing rain moved in from 6 - 9 PM. This storm was intensity-based, so that heavier pockets of precipitation fell as primarily snow & sleet, but as soon as it lightened up, would switch to primarily freezing rain and rain. Similarly, temperatures would fall to 31 - 34 degrees under the heaviest bursts of snow & sleet, then creep back to 32 - 36 degrees when it lightened and changed back to rain with pockets of freezing rain. The first main wave of precipitation exited during the pre-dawn hours of the 24th, giving way to more dry time than not during first half of the morning. However, another round of wintry mix showers returned from 8 - 11 AM. Winds gusted 25 - 35 mph. The last of the scattered wintry mix showers dissipated from 9 - 11 PM, with just a few isolated lingering light rain showers that persisted in southeastern Hartford county through 3 AM. Temperatures during the second round of precipitation on the 24th held 33 - 38 degrees.

Periods of snow impacted the state on March 10th.

Light snow began between 2 - 4 AM on March 10th with temperatures of 33 - 37 degrees. The temperature quickly fell near to slightly below freezing (27 - 32 degrees) as snow became steadier during the pre-dawn hours. Snow fell moderate to even briefly heavy at times during the morning hours, particularly across the southern half of Hartford county. While the main batch of snow lightened up and ended between 2 - 4 PM, a few localized flurries & even snow squalls continued through 5 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event were 32 - 35 degrees. However, winds increased going into the overnight, with gusts of 30 - 40 mph. As a result, blowing and drifting occurred well after the snowfall ended as temperatures plummeted into the teens.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to the preceding warmth and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less, and subject to considerable variations.

Periods of snow from a clipper system occurred from January 31st-February 1st.

Periods of light snow developed between 10 AM and 1 PM on January 31st. Localized moderate to heavy bursts of snowfall occurred during the afternoon, particularly across southern Hartford County. The last of the flakes dissipated from 3 - 5 AM on February 1st. Temperatures held 22 - 26 degrees throughout the event.

A winter storm and subsequent snow showers occurred on Christmas Day.

Light snow entered the area between 10 PM and Midnight on the 24th. The snow mixed with a bit of sleet and freezing drizzle before steadier snow developed from 2 - 4 AM on the 25th. The snow fell heavy at times towards and after daybreak. Snowfall rates reach 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands. Most of the steady snow tapered off from 9 - 11a. Temperatures held steady between 27 - 32 degrees. Intermittent snow showers returned Midday with temperatures of 32 - 37 degrees. The last of the flakes dissipated 7 - 9 PM as temperatures dipped back to 29 - 32 degrees. Winds became very gusty during the daylight hours of the 25th, with gusts reaching 30 - 40 mph.

Another potent low pressure system brought snow, ice to the area Feb 12th-13th.

Periods of light to moderate snow developed between 9 - 11 AM on February 12th with temperatures of 20 - 23 degrees. Snowfall quickly became heavy at times thereafter, with snowfall rates of up to 1"/hr through the early afternoon. As precipitation lightened from 3 - 6 PM, the snow mixed with and fluctuated between freezing rain & rain with pockets of sleet as temperatures rose to 26 - 29 degrees. After 7 - 10 PM, the light wintry mix tapered off to intermittent flurries & very light snow going into the 13th. While the last of any flurries dissipated completely from 7 - 10 AM, wind gusts of 50-60 mph resulted in blowing and drifting into the daytime. Temperatures by the end of the event were 27 - 32 degrees.

Third Nor'easter in a month impacted the state from March 13-14th.

Light snow developed between 12 - 2 AM on the 13th with temperatures of 33 - 37 degrees. The snow fell moderate to heavy at times beginning 7 - 10 AM, resulting in up to 1"/hr rates. The snow lightened up after 2 PM, but did not taper off completely until 7 - 10 PM. Temperatures fell to 27 - 32 degrees by the end of the event. Winds were gusty as well, at 30 - 40 mph.

A late season storm brought some snow on April 2nd.

Light snow began between 3 - 5 AM on the 2nd with temperatures initially in the mid-30s. Temperatures quickly fell below freezing (27 - 32 degrees), especially as the snow became steady to heavy from 6 - 11 AM. Thereafter, the snow lightened before ending completely from 11 AM - 1 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event rose back into the mid-to-upper 30s. Due to it being very late in the season, pavements generally were warmer, resulting in variability in accumulation on them.

A potent low pressure system brought periods of snow to the region on January 7th.

Light snow overspread the area between 10 AM and Noon on January 7th. Snow quickly turned steady thereafter, falling moderate to even heavy at times (especially across southern Hartford county) throughout the afternoon. Snow gradually lightened up during the early evening hours, wrapping up completely from 10 PM - Midnight. Temperatures held 18 - 22 degrees throughout the event. While winds were only 10 - 20 mph, due to the fluffy & powdery nature of the snow, minor blowing and drifting occurred and lingered into the 8th.

A thump of snow occurred from February 17th - 18th.

Light to moderate snow began between 6 - 8 PM on the 17th with temperatures of 32 - 35 degrees. The snow continued into the overnight hours before lightening and tapering off completely from 4 - 6 AM on the 18th. Temperatures by the end of the event settled to 26 - 30 degrees.

Heavy snow, then brief sleet & freezing rain showers occurred on December 17.

Light snow began between 1 and 4 AM on December 17th with temperatures of 19 - 24 degrees. Steadier snow arrived towards daybreak before becoming heavy after sunrise. The heavy snow lightened up around 11 AM, and mixed with a bit of sleet, then changed over to freezing rain across the southern portions of Hartford county (the northern portions remained snow). The steadier precipitation exited from 11 AM - Noon, but was soon followed by scattered mixed snow, sleet, and freezing rain showers through 2 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event hovered in the mid-to-upper 20s within the valleys, and to around 32 degrees within the elevations.

Note: Any freezing rain & drizzle that occurred during the evening of the 17th will be covered in a separate report.

First Winter Storm of the Season Occurred December 9th-10th.

Light to moderate snow began between 8 AM - 10 AM on the 9th with temperatures of 33 - 36 degrees. Once snow became steadier Midday, temperatures quickly plummeted below freezing (29 - 32 degrees), with even some bursts of brief, heavy snow. Going into the evening, snowfall was light but persistent before tapering off as flurries from 1 - 4 AM on the 10th. Temperatures by the end of the event settled into the upper-20s.

A potent winter storm impacted the state from January 4th-5th.

Intermittent light snow began between 1 - 3 AM on the 4th with temperatures of 16 - 19 degrees. A steadier light snow worked in thereafter, becoming moderate to heavy just after sunrise. Winds began to kick up with these heavier bands, as well, with gusts of 25 - 35 mph, resulting in blowing & drifting. Visibilities dipped to a quarter mile or slightly less at times. Snowfall rates of 1-3"/hr existed throughout much of the daytime. Temperatures rose to an afternoon high of 25 - 28 degrees. The heavier bands exited around sunset, resulting in a light and increasingly intermittent snow to continue as winds gusted to 30 - 40 mph. Light snow ended completely from 10 PM - 1 AM going into the 5th. Temperatures settled to 18 - 22 degrees. Winds continued to stay gusty into the overnight, resulting in blowing and drifting even into the daytime of the 5th.

The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Second coastal system in a week brought periods of snow from March 7th-8th.

Light areas of snow worked in between 2 - 4 AM on the 7th. Moderate to even heavy bands of snow finally pushed in from 11 AM - 1 PM, with snowfall rates upwards of 1-3"/hr occuring late afternoon into the early evening. Even lightning and thunder was reported at times under these very heavy bands. The snow lightened and tapered off to flurries going into the pre-dawn hours on the 8th before exiting completely from 4 - 7 AM. Temperatures during the entire event hovered between 32 - 35 degrees. It was windy, as well, with gusts of 25 - 35 mph.

A major winter storm took aim at Connecticut on February 9th.

Light to moderate snow mixed with a little sleet at the onset developed between 5 - 7 AM on February 9th with temperatures near to slightly above 32 degrees. Snow quickly became heavy thereafter, with numerous reports of thundersnow during the morning and afternoon hours. Snowfall rates of 2-4"/hr were common during this time period. Temperatures quickly plummeted into the 20s. Heavy snowfall combined with wind gusts of 30 - 40 mph resulted in visibilities dropping to 1/4 mile or less, along with blowing & drifting. Snowfall began to lighten up from 3 - 5 PM. The last of any lingering, light snow dissipated completely from 5 - 8 PM as temperature settled into the mid-teens. Gusty conditions continued into the overnight hours, resulting in prolonged and significant blowing and drifting long after the storm ended.

A potent Nor'easter swept across the state on March 14th.

Steady to heavy snow began between 1 - 4 AM on March 14th with temperatures in the mid-20s. Heavy snow occurred in the AM with 1-3" per hour rates. The snow mixed with and even changed over to sleet at times (particularly across the Hartford Metro area and on south) between 10 AM - 1 PM as temperatures warmed slightly to 28 - 33 degrees. These periods of steady to heavy sleet resulted in up to 1-2" inches of sleet accumulation. With sleet being generally three to four times more dense than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow/sleet pack relative to the overall accumulation. Precipitation lightened before ending as all snow from 8 - 10 PM. Temperatures by the end of the event settled back down into the mid-20s. Winds gusted up to 45 - 55 mph during the event, resulting in significant blowing & drifting of the snow pack.

Accumulation in the "Total" column are representative of combined non-compacted snow and sleet accumulation per standard snow measurement guidelines. Accumulation listed under "Ice" indicates any additional ice accretion from freezing rain only, if applicable.

Strong Cold Front changes Rain to Wintry Mix

With temperatures in the 40s, areas of rain developed during the evening on November 19th, 2016 as a potent cold front moved through the region. As colder air filtered in, rain mixed and changed to a period of snow and sleet, at times steady, betwen 12am-3am into November 20th as temperatures fell to 34-38 degrees. After precipiation ended, temperatures held steady in the mid to upper 30s overnight.

Disturbance Produced Snow Showers on December 30th, 2016

With temperatures starting in the upper 30s to lower 40s, scattered snow showers developed between 3-7pm on December 30th. After snow showers ended temperatures fell into the upper 20s to lower 30s overnight.

Morning Snow Showers on February 13th, 2017

With temperatures starting 32-35 degrees, scattered snow showers and flurries developed across the region between 8-10am on February 13th, 2017. Winds also became gusty, with gusts 20-30 mph. Temperatures held steady 34-37 degrees after snow showers exited.

Light Snow/Sleet Mix with System December 24th into 25th

As a system moved into the region, scattered areas of rain/snow/sleet developed between 7-10PM on December 24th. Temperatures started in the upper 30s but once precipitation began, fell to 33-36 degrees. Combinations of rain/snow/sleet remained overnight, changing to rain at times as temperatures held 33-36 degrees. The mix continued, most widespread between 4-7AM on December 25th. Scattered flurries remained through 9-11AM before ending, with temperatures rising into the mid-upper 30s for afternoon as winds increased and gusted 30-40 mph.

Disturbance Brings Wintry Mix on January 8th

Between 1-3pm, a mix of sleet and freezing rain arrived across the area with temperatures ranging 25-30 degrees on January 8th. The sleet and freezing rain mix quickly transitioned to snow after 3pm before ending between 4-6pm. Temperatures remained steady 25-30 degrees after precipitation exited.

Late Day Sleet on March 20th

With temperatures ranging in the mid-upper 30s, scattered areas of sleet moved into the region between 3-8pm on March 20th. Any lingering sleet diminished by the evening.

Snow Showers with Arctic Boundary Develop Early on December 15th, 2016

With temperatures starting 20-25 degrees, scattered snow showers with embedded heavier snow squalls developed across the area. This occurred from 7-11am on December 15th with wind gusts 25-35 mph. After snow showers exited, temperatures settled 15-20 degrees.

Late Afternoon and Evening Snow Showers on March 14th

With temperatures starting 37-42 degrees, scattered snow showers and flurries developed over the region starting 3-6pm. Snow showers continued into the evening hours, with some embedded steadier bursts as temperatures fell to 33-35 degrees. Snow showers exited between 9pm-12am with temperatures falling to 31-34 degrees overnight.

Wintry Mix Develops on February 12, 2017

During the pre-dawn hours of January 12, 2017 and with temperatures generally in the mid-30s, an area of light rain moved through the area. As light rain continued, temperatures gradually fell close to the freezing mark, generally between 5-8AM. After this time, a steady rain and sleet mix developed gradually turning to all steady sleet. Sleet persisted through the morning hours leading to dense accumulations on most surfaces. Around 11AM-1PM, steady sleet transitioned freezing rain showers and freezing drizzle which continued through the afternoon and evening leading to a significant ice accretion. During the evening and with the loss of daylight as well as continued drizzle, icy areas continued to develop with temperatures still hovering near or just below the freezing mark. Freezing drizzle then tapered off around 6-8PM while temperatures slightly rose to 32-34 degrees. Temperatures hovered 32-34 degrees tinto the early overnight as skies cleared. 

Note: Accumulation listed in the "Total" column is a combination of snow/sleet.
Accumulation listed in the  "Ice"  column is additional ice accretion from freezing rain.

Disturbance Brings Light Snow on December 11th, 2016

With temperatures in the upper 20s to lower 30s, a distrubance from the west moved into the area on December 11th, 2016. This produced flurries and periods of light to moderate snow between 4-8pm. Temperatures remained steady in the upper 20s to lower 30s after snow exited.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Snow, Rain and Wind

A very strong Nor'easter brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. A good portion of the precipitation fell as rain (which began late on March 1) with temperature beginning in the upper 30s to lower 40s. Starting 7-11 AM on March 2, rain mixed with snow and sleet with combinations of rain, snow, and sleet continuing into the afternoon. Precipitation tapered down to flurries and sprinkles before ending between 7-10pm. When wintry precipitation was falling, the temperature was between 34 and 38 degrees and held in that range after precipitation ended. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong. Gusts were frequently 40-50 mph, with some spots exceeding 60 mph at times.

Clipper System Brings Snow on December 30th

With temperatures ranging from 14-19 degrees, light snow and flurries developed over the region between 6-9am on December 30th as a clipper system moved through the region. Temperatures ranged from 17-21 degrees as light snow continued into the morning before tapering to flurries and ending 1-4pm as temperatures held steady between 17-21 degrees.

Coastal System Brings Areas of Snow January 30th

With temperatures starting in the mid to upper 30s, areas of light snow arrived between 12-3am on January 30th. Temperatures fell into the lower 30s as light to steady snow developed overnight and into daybreak hours. Areas of snow tapered to scattered and intermittent flurries and snow showers after 7am, which continued at times into the afternoon as temperatures rose to 33-37 degrees. Any lingering flurries and snow showers exited 4-7pm with temperatures falling into the 20s during the evening. Due to previous warmth, accumulation on paved surfaces was variable, and generally less than colder and grassy surfaces.

Mixed Precipitation Before Changing to Rain on February 7th

With temperatures starting 28-32 degrees, areas of snow and sleet developed between 6 - 9 am on February 7th. Snow and sleet became briefly steady before changing to freezing rain 10 am-12pm as temperatures held 30-32 degrees. Precipitation changed to plain rain 1 - 4 pm as temperatures rose into the upper 30s to lower 40s with rain continuing into the evening. The changing precipitation types made this a more dense accumulation that was heavier than normal.

Snow From Clipper on January 31st, 2017

With temperatures ranging from 28-32, light snow arrived between 8-10am as a clipper system moved into the region. Snow became steady at times before tapering to flurries between 2-5pm with temperatures remaining in the lower 30s. Any lingering flurries and snow showers ended during the evening with temperatures holding in the lower 30s overnight.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow on December 15

As a coastal storm developed out to sea, snow quickly developed between 1-3 PM on December 15th, and became steady during the late afternoon and evening rush hour, with intervals of moderate snow. At the onset of snow, temperatures were in the mid-upper 20s, but settled into the low-mid 20s as snow became steady. The snow came to an end between 6-8 PM. After snow ended, temperatures fell into the upper teens to lower 20s overnight.

Rain Changes to Snow During the Morning on January 17th

As a disturbance moved into the region from the west, areas of rain developed between 1-3am across the area on January 17th with temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees. Cooler air and more moisture from a developing low pressure system off the coast caused rain to mix then transition to snow between 5-7am. Snow became steady at times into the morning before becoming light and intermittent and ending 12-3pm. Temperatures remained steady as snow ended before falling to 28-32 degrees by sunset.

Coastal Storm Brings Snow Early on March 13th

With temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees, areas of mixed rain and snow showers which were around during the late evening on March 12th changed over to all snow between 1-4am into the early morning on March 13th. Temperatures remained 33-36 degrees, as snow continued through the morning hours, steady at times, with winds gusting 20-30 mph. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 11am-2pm with temperatures rising into the upper 30s to lower 40s during the afternoon.

Storm System Brings Snow on January 14th, 2017

With temperatures ranging from 28-32 degrees, areas of light snow developed between 11am-2pm on January 14th. Snow became moderate to heavy at times into the afternoon before tapering to flurries and ending between 7-10pm as temperatures remained steady between 28-32 degrees. After precipitation exited, skies cleared as temperatures fell into the 20s overnight.

Storm System Brings Snow on January 5-6, 2017

With temperatures starting in the upper 20s to near 30, light snow developed across the area starting 10PM-2AM on January 5th into the 6th. Snow became moderate to heavy at times before tapering to intermittent flurries and ending 7-10AM with temperatures remaining steady into the morning.

Snow with Clipper System Late December 13th into 14th

Starting 10pm-12am from December 13th into the 14th a clipper system brought snow into the region. Snow was light to moderate overnight as temperatures ranged between 22-27 degrees. Snow became intermittent towards pre-dawn, lulling to flurries at times. Any flurries and areas of snow exited 6-8am as temperatures held 22-27 degrees. After snow ended, temperature rose into the lower 30s during the afternoon with wind gusts 20-25 mph.

Winter Storm Impacts Area December 17th, 2016

With temperatures in the mid 20s, light snow developed over the area between 1-4am on December 17th. Snow increased in intensity and became heavy at times after 5am as temperatures held in the mid to upper 20s. As warmer air above the surface moved into the area, snow transitioned to a sleet and freezing rain mix between 9-10am. Eventually, any mix turned to rain showers and became light and very scattered between 10am-Noon. Areas of drizzle remained into the afternoon and evening with temperatures ranging from 32 - 35 degrees, thus continuing to allow for patchy ice. Because of the preceding arctic air mass, patchy ice was possible on ground surfaces even with air temperatures slightly above 32 degrees. Heading into the evening, it remained 32-35 degrees with areas of dense fog, returning scattered rain showers and drizzle. Then between 12-3AM on Sunday morning, temperatures quickly rose to 35-40 degrees ending any ice threat.

Morning snow with late-day squalls

Despite coming off a very mild stretch of weather with high temperatures in the lower-60s on the 9th, a winter system worked into the area during the pre-dawn hours of the 10th. Between 4-6 AM, snow developed across the area with temperatures falling quickly from the low-40s to near 30 degrees. Snow fell steadily through the morning hours with temperatures staying near 32 degrees during the event. The final steady band of snow exited the area and light snow came to an end between 10AM-1PM. Temperatures only rose into the upper-30s through the day with breezy conditions. A few additional snow showers traversed the area between 2-5PM with minimal additional accumulation, however sustained northwest winds of 10-18mph with gusts 25-30 ushered in very cold air and also led to some minor blowing and drifting snow.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces. Due to prior warmth, marginal temperatures during snowfall and the March sun angle, pavement accumulations were generally less, and subject to considerable variations.

Low Pressure System Brings Heavy Snow on February 17th

Snow arrived across the area between 4-6pm on February 17th with temperatures 32-34 degrees. As a low pressure system strengthened off the coast, areas of heavy snow developed quickly into the evening with 1-2"/hr rates as temperatures settled to 30-33 degrees. Areas of heavy snow tapered to flurries and light snow before ending between 11pm-1am with temperatures 31-33 by daybreak.

Coastal Storm Impacts Area on January 7th, 2017

With temperatures steady in the lower 20s for the entire period, areas of light snow moved into the area between 7-10am on January 7th. Due to the cold, dry airmass in place snow was of a dry and powdery nature. Snow then became moderate to heavy at times into the afternoon producing whiteout conditions and blowing and drifting as winds gusted to 20-30 mph. Snow tapered to flurries before ending 6-9pm as the coastal system exited east.

First Widespread Snowfall of the Season on December 9th

A coastal system moved up the coast and brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent pockets of light snow first began between 8-10 AM as temperatures fell from the mid 30s down to 30-34 degrees. Snow became steady between 10am-2pm and continued light to moderate through the day as temperatures settled and held 28-32 degrees. Snow generally turned lighter into the evening before completely ending between 10PM-Midnight as temperatures fell into the mid-upper 20s overnight. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

Early April Winter Storm

With temperatures starting in the mid-upper 30s areas of light snow developed across the area starting 3-6am on April 2nd. Snow continued through the morning, becoming heavy with 1-2"/hr snowfall rates, as temperatures settled 32-33 degrees. Snow tapered to flurries and ended 9-11am with temperatures rising into the 40s during the afternoon.

Powerful Winter Storm on March 7

Flurries and sprinkles during the late evening of March 6th transitioned to areas of snow between 12-3am on March 7th with temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees. Snow varied in intensity through the morning, even mixing with rain, as temperatures held steady. As a powerful coastal storm strengthened, snow became heavy between 12-6pm with embedded 1-2"/hr snowfall rates, thunder and lightning, and wind gusts 30-40 mph. Snow tapered to intermittent flurries and light snow between 6-8pm which lingered through 8-10pm before ending. Temperatures settled to 30-34 degrees overnight. The combination of a dense, wet snow and windy conditions led to downed trees and wires.

Major Coastal Storm Hits Area on February 9th, 2017

With temperatures starting 34-39 degrees, a mix of light rain, snow, sleet arrived across the region starting 1-3am. Between 4-6am, the mix transitioned to snow which became heavy and continued into the morning with 1-2" per hour rates. Winds also became quite gusty with wind gusts 25-35 mph as temperatures fell into the upper 20s to lower 30s. Heavy snow tapered to light snow and flurries between 11am-2pm before ending between 2-4pm with temperatures remaining steady in the upper 20s into the afternoon. Wind gusts increased to 40-50 mph after snow ended into the evening which caused prolonged and significant blowing and drifting of snow with temperatures falling into the upper teens to lower 20s overnight.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind January 4th

Initial sporadic snow developed as early as 12-3 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the mid-upper 20s. After a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady 6-9 AM as temperatures cooled into the low-mid 20s where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Moderate to heavy snow, which at times fell at the rate of 1-2 inches per hour, continued through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 2-5 PM before ending between 6-8pm. In addition to the heavy snow were winds during the event that gusted 40-50 mph at times. Winds continued to gust into the overnight as temperatures help steady in the low-mid 20s.

The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Snowstorm Brings Snow and Sleet to the Area on March 14th 2017

With temperatures starting between 28-33 degrees, a few flurries developed after 10pm late on March 13th. The main an area of snow entered the region between 12-3am heading into March 14th. Snow was steady to heavy overnight and into the morning with 1-2" per hour rates and near blizzard conditions for a time as winds gusted to 30-45 mph. The most impactful portion of the event came when warmer air aloft caused snow to mix and change to steady heavy sleet with temperatures hovering between 28-32 degrees. This extensive period of very heavy sleet amounted to approximately 2.5-3.5" inches of sleet. With sleet being generally three to four times denser than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow/sleet pack relative to the overall accumulation.  Temperatures remained 28-32 degrees as combinations of sleet mixed with snow at times continued. After noon, precipitation became scattered with an intermittent snow and sleet mix remaining into the afternoon. The mix changed back to light snow before ending between 3-6pm with temperatures still holding 28-32 degrees. Winds remained gusty overnight as temperatures fell into the 20s.

**Accumulation in the "Total" column are representative of combined non-compacted snow and sleet accumulation per standard snow measurement guidelines. Accumulation listed under "Ice" indicates any additional ice accretion from freezing rain only, if applicable.

Snow with Late Season Coastal Storm on March 21st

Temperatures started 33-36 degrees as areas of snow and sleet starting 3-6am on March 21st. Any mix quickly changed to snow 6-9am, which continued into the afternoon. Snow intensity was variable during the day, with embedded steady to heavy snow at times. As the coastal storm developed east, snow remained into the overnight hours as temperatures fell and held 30-33 degrees. Snow tapered to intermittent light snow and flurries between 2-5am before ending completely 5-7am on March 22nd with temperatures ranging from 32-35 degrees. In addition, winds gusted 20-30 mph during the event.

Fall System Brings Early Season Wintry Mix

Between 6:30-9am on October 27th an area of mixed snow and sleet moved into the region with temperatures ranging from 33-36 degrees. Snow and sleet were light to steady at times before mixing and changing to areas of rain between 10-11am as temperatures remained steady. Temperatures rose into the mid to upper 30s by the afternoon as areas of rain continued.

Wintry Mix Sandwiched Between Rain on December 6th and 7th

After raining for a short while, it became cold enough for rain to change to a mix of snow, pockets of sleet and very localized areas of freezing rain between 7PM-9PM on December 6th. The mix was consistent for a few hours. However, between 1030PM-1230AM on the 6th into the 7th, the mix turned to rain, ending the wintry weather. Temperatures were 33-37 degrees, during the event.

Two Days of Lake Effect Snow Showers on December 8th and 9th

Bands of light snow worked their way into the area between 9PM-12AM on December 8th.  Snow showers continued overnight and into the morning, with another round of widespread coverage between 11AM-2PM. After 2PM, flurries lingered into the afternoon. While there were snow showers, temperatures were 32-36 degrees, save during the morning of the 8th, when it was around 30 degrees.

PM Snow Showers on December 10th

From 230PM-730PM on December 10th, snow flurries / snow showers passed through the region. The snow was scattered, with temperatures 28-32 degrees.
Scattered snow showers and flurries fell between 6PM-1AM on December 13th into the 14th. Temperatures were around 32, during this time.

Thursday Morning Snow Squalls on December 15th  

Between 7AM – 10AM on December 15th, a band of snow arrived. The snow only lasted for an hour or two as it passed south throughout the area, which had snow squalls embedded in them. Winds were strong during the event, gusting at 25-35 mph. Temperatures were 20-24 degrees, during this time.

A Light AM Wintry Mix on December 22nd

With temperatures 27-31 degrees, precipitation arrived between 5AM-7AM on December 22nd. The precipitation was mostly snow, but sleet did mix in as well. Then, by 10AM, the light mixture moved out. Around 10AM, temperatures were 33-37 degrees.

Snow Starts Off Mainly Rain Event on December 29th

Between 8AM-11AM on December 29th, snow fell to start off what would turn into a rain event. The transition to rain started to occur as early as 9AM in spots, with freezing rain seen as well through 11AM. During the morning, temperatures were 33-36 degrees, rising to around 40 during the afternoon.

PM Snow Showers on December 30th

Between 1230PM – 230PM on December 30th, lake effect snow showers moved in from the Great Lakes. Temperatures were in the mid-30s while the snow showers began. Embedded in the snow were localized snow squalls, which brought brief gusty (25-30 mph) conditions along with a moderate to even heavy snow. Then, between 10PM-12AM, the loss of daytime heating helped to shut off the snow showers, completing the event. While the snow ended, temperatures fell below freezing, to 27-31 degrees.

Morning Wintry Mix on January 2nd

Temperatures were around 32 degrees as a system brought freezing rain showers, mixing with sleet initially. This occurred from 730AM – 1030AM on the 2nd. After 1030AM, temperatures warmed into the mid to upper 30s, enough to end the icy event.

Mixed Showers Follow Clipper System on February 1st

Snow showers, mixed with rain at times, began 12PM-2PM on February 1st. The showers did struggle to accumulate for the most part. However, snow squalls did pass through, bringing brief whiteout conditions into the afternoon and evening. Then, between 530PM-730PM, the showers departed the region. Temperatures while it were snowing was 34-38 degrees. However, in a snow squall, temperatures did drop to 32 degrees briefly.

Flurries, Light snow on February 2nd  

Snow showers began between 630AM-830AM on February 2nd. The snow was widely scattered throughout the daylight hours. During the afternoon rush hour, though, the activity subsided, with the event ending between 530PM-730PM. Temperatures were 25-29 degrees as the snow started, warming up into the mid-30s for the midday and afternoon. Finally, as day turned to night and the system stopped, temperatures fell to 28-32 degrees.

Mid-Week Icing on February 7th and 8th

While there was spotty freezing drizzle between 6AM-8AM on February 7th, the main area of freezing rain began between 9AM-11AM on February 7th. Temperatures were 29-32 at this time. Temperatures rose to around freezing during the mid-afternoon, staying there for the rest of the day as showers and sprinkles brought repeated icing on colder and shaded surfaces.  Temperatures continued to be around freezing during the evening with icing continuing overnight before warming to 34-38 degrees between 4AM-7AM on the 8th.

Small System Clips Area on February 10th

Snow showers and even a period of light snow fell between 8PM-11PM on February 10th. However, a few flurries were seen into the pre-dawn hours on the 11th. Temperatures during the evening were 23-27 degrees.

Embedded Brief Heavy Snow on February 15th

An area of precipitation arrived between 1PM-3PM on February 15th, with temperatures 32-35 degrees. A mix of rain and snow was seen. When it did snow, it was moderate in intensity and temperatures dropped to just below freezing where all snow occurred. Then, between 530PM-730PM, the mix completely exited the area, with a few flurries into the evening. Temperatures were still 32-35 degrees at the end time.

Flurries and Snow Showers on the Ides of March

While a few flurries fell during the pre-dawn hours, slightly more enhanced snow showers began between 8AM-10AM on March 15th. Temperatures were 17-21 degrees during this time. The snow sporadically fell throughout the day, as temperatures only rose into the mid-20s. Gusts of 25-30 mph continued the blowing and drifting snow. During the evening, snow tapered off. However, it would take until10PM-12AM for the remaining snow showers to end.

Wintry mix on December 12th

After a few flurries shortly after midnight on the 12th, mixed sleet, snow, and brief freezing rain in spots arrived 5 - 8 AM as temperatures held between 32 - 36 degrees. This continued into the morning, changing to all rain at times by mid-day and through the rest of the afternoon as temperatures warmed further into the mid-to-upper 30s. However, precip did change back to light snow as temperatures cooled to 30 - 34 degrees after 6 PM, eventually tapering off by 9 - 10 PM.

Early wintry mix on December 18th

Combinations of light snow and sleet moved through the region between 1 - 6 AM on the 18th. While the precipitation was in the region, temperatures were generally in the upper 20s and lower 30s.

Early freezing rain event on December 23rd

With temperatures between 30 - 33 degrees, a period of freezing rain and drizzle occurred between 2 - 8 AM as a system moved in from the south on December 23rd. This eventually changed to plain rain by 8 - 10 AM as temperatures warmed further into the mid-to-upper 30s, ending any icing threat.

Returning snow showers and flurries on December 25th

After a system departed early Christmas, flurries and scattered snow showers continued late morning into the afternoon with temperatures between 30 - 35 degrees and winds gusting up to 30 - 40 mph. A lull occurred by the mid-afternoon, before additional snow showers and flurries occurred between 5 -  9 PM. Flurries then lingered overnight with temperatures settling in the mid-to-upper 20s.

Morning Snow on February 6th

Areas of snow moved through the region between 6 and 11 AM on February 6th. While most of the snow was light to moderate, there were occasional bursts of heavy snow in spots which resulted in quick coverings of all ground surfaces. While snow was in the region, the temperature was in the low to mid 20s.

Brief wintry mix to rain on February 4th

A mix of snow, sleet, and brief freezing rain fell between 11 AM - 1 PM as temperatures cooled from the mid-to-upper 30s to between 32 - 35 degrees. Any wintry mix then transitioned to all rain after 3 - 6 PM as temperatures warmed back into the mid-to-upper 30s.

Early morning freezing rain on February 14th

An area of freezing rain and drizzle, mixed with sleet in spots, occurred between 3 - 7 AM on February 14th. Temperatures were between 28 - 32 degrees during the rain before warming into the mid-to-upper 30s after 9 AM.

Snow showers and flurries on March 4th and 5th

Snow showers and flurries began as early as 5 - 7 PM on March 4th, continuing intermittently overnight before dissipating by 2 - 4 AM on March 5th. Temperatures were generally between 33 - 38 degrees but cooled to 28 - 32 degrees during snowfall.

Late day flurries and snow showers on March 9th

After spotty flurries during the day on March 9th with temperatures in the upper 30s to 40 degrees, scattered snow showers briefly developed between 5 and 9 PM. Temperatures had settled between 32 and 37 degrees by the early evening. However, due to the marginal temperatures, most accumulation was found on colder/grassy surfaces

Morning snow showers on March 16th

Snow showers occurred between 6 and 10 AM on March 16th. Some of these became briefly heavy for a time. Flurries then continued to linger afterwards before diminishing during the early afternoon. Temperatures were between 29 and 34 degrees during the event, eventually warming into the mid-to-upper 30s by the afternoon.

Late season snow and rain mix on April 10th

Areas of light snow mixed with rain in spots occurred between 3 and 10 AM on April 10th. A few non-accumulating flurries then continued to linger into the afternoon. Temperatures were between 32 and 37 degrees during the event before warming into the 40s. Accumulations were confined to colder/grassy surfaces due to marginal temperatures.

Lake Effect Snow Moves in on November 21st and 22nd

Between 5AM-7AM on November 21st, snow from the Great Lakes began across the region, with temperatures 29-32 degrees. The snow was light for a few hours in the morning, as winds gusted 25-35 mph in spots. However, after 9AM, the snow showers became very light and intermittent, which continued for the rest of the day, as temperatures rose to 32-35 degrees. Then, between 12AM-2AM on the 22nd, another burst of heavier snow passed, with the event ending afterwards. During this time, temperatures were steady at 32-35 degrees.

Rounds of Light Snow on March 18th

With temperatures 32-36 degrees, snow, mixing with rain locally, began between 10AM-12PM on March 18th. The snow moved sporadically around the region into the afternoon and the evening, ending between 7PM-9PM. Temperatures remained 32-36 degrees, during this time.

Rain to snow event on February 2nd

Periods of rain developed during the evening on February 1st, with temperatures in the mid-30s. Rain then mixed and changed to a mainly wet snow by 1 - 3 AM on the 2nd as temperatures quickly cooled to 33 - 35 degrees. Snow was light but became moderate at times between 4 - 6 AM as temperatures fell below freezing. This then tapered off by 6 - 8 AM, with temperatures continuing to cool further into the mid-20s and winds gusting up to 30 - 35 mph.

Accumulating snow on February 9th

A light to moderate snow overspread the region between 11 AM - 1 PM on February 9th. Snow was steady into the afternoon with occasional bursts of heavier snow around sunset before tapering off to flurries by 6 - 8 PM. Temperatures were between 25 - 30 degrees during snowfall.

Wintry mix to snow on January 8th

A light mix of sleet and freezing rain began across the region between 12 - 2 PM on the 8th. This mix quickly changed to mainly snow within an hour of any precipitation that started. Light snow then continued before tapering off by 3 - 6 PM. Temperatures were in the mid-20s during the event.

Afternoon and evening snow showers on March 14th

Snow showers and flurries developed as early as 2 - 3 PM with temperatures in the mid-to-upper 30s. These continued into the evening as temperatures cooled between 30 and 34 degrees. A few showers became briefly steady and heavy at times. Snow otherwise diminished to flurries by 9 PM - 12 AM.

Disturbance brought accumulating snow on April 6th

Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 7 and 10 AM on April 6th with temperatures between 29 and 34 degrees. Snow briefly became heavy at times before temperatures warmed into the mid-to-upper 30s after 11 AM-12 PM, causing snow to mix and eventually changeover to rain in spots. All precipitation then quickly ended by 1 - 2 PM. Due to marginal temperatures, accumulations were confined to colder and grassy surfaces.

Two Bands on Snow on January 6th

A round of snow moved through between 1230AM-330AM on January 6th. A break then followed for a few hours (though a flurry was seen in spots), before a band of snow set up from 530AM-830AM. Within this time frame, places near the NY/CT border experienced the longest duration of snow. After 830AM, the event ended. Temperatures were 24-28 degrees, while it was snowing.

Heavy Band of Precipitation Brings Sleet on January 24th

Though rain showers fell for much of the afternoon, sleet mixed in between 630PM-1130PM on January 24th. After 1130PM, the rain and sleet ended, save for pockets of drizzle and mist that continued overnight. Temperatures during this time were 34-38 degrees, staying that way until the morning of the 25th. Winds gusted 25-30 mph at times during the event as well.

Coastal system grazed the area on January 30th

As a coastal system moved mainly to the east, the western edge of precipitation grazed the region on January 30th. Pockets of light snow and flurries developed around 12 AM with temperatures in the mid-30s, continuing through the pre-dawn with temperatures cooling between 28 - 32 degrees. While initially light, snow became moderate and steady through dawn before tapering off to flurries by 7 - 10 AM. Some sunshine returned after, warming temperatures between 32 - 36 degrees. Spotty flurries and brief showers continued otherwise, especially in the early afternoon and early evening. Snow eventually tapered off by 9 PM to just lingering flurries with temperatures falling back into the teens and 20s.

Rain turns to AM Snow / Sleet on November 20th

After raining for parts of the evening and overnight, it became cold enough for a transition of rain to snow and sleet. This occurred between 130AM-330AM, with temperatures in the mid-30s. The snow and sleet lasted for a few hours, with a couple of rain showers mixed in as well. Around 6AM, the precipitation moved out of the area, with just a spot flurry or sprinkle until 10AM.

NOTE: Snow falling later on the 20th will be covered in a future report.

Sleet Mixes with Largely Rain Event on January 23rd and 24th

Rain started to fall during the late afternoon on January 23rd. During this time, temperatures were in the upper 30s to near 40 degrees. Gusts were 30-40 mph, where they would continue until around midnight. As the rain became heavier, areas of sleet mixed in, starting between 10PM-1AM on the 23rd into the 24th. Sleet largely only mixed within the heavy precipitation, which was had for periods of time until 330AM. After 330AM, the precipitation lightened up, turning any sleet back into light rain showers and drizzle, with temperatures 34-38 degrees.

NOTE: Any wintry weather falling after 10AM will be covered in a future report.

Coastal storm brought accumulating snow on December 15th

Snow quickly developed between 2 - 4 PM on the 15th, and became steady for the evening rush hour, with some pockets of moderate snow. Snow did not last long, and tapered off between 7 - 9 PM. Temperatures were mainly in the low 20s during snowfall.

A Couple Hours of Snow on December 5th

Temperatures were right around freezing when snow began between 2AM-4AM on December 5th. The snow that fell was generally light, though there were a few bursts of moderate to briefly heavy snow. Between 7AM-9AM the snow ended. In its wake were flurries and mist that lingered until around 10AM. As the snow ended, temperatures were near 35 degrees.

Period of Wintry Mix follows Period of Snow on December 11th and 12th

Snow moved into the area between 430PM-630PM from the NJ/NY border on northeastward on December 11th. Snow took a break starting from 730PM-930PM, returning between 1130PM-130AM on December 11th into the 12th. However, this area of wintry weather had a mix of snow, sleet and freezing rain at the onset. This mix would then transition over to rain between 2AM-4AM. For the duration of the entire wintry event, temperatures were 28-32 degrees.

PM Snow on January 14th  

Snow began from the NJ/NY border, on north, between 2PM-4PM on January 14th. The snow was persistent until 7PM, when it became scattered. Then, between 730PM-930PM, the snow moved away from the region, ending the event. While it was snowing, temperatures were 25-30 degrees.

Clipper system on December 30th

As a clipper moved in on the morning of the 30th, light snow developed between 7 - 9 AM. This became steady through mid-day, especially between 10 AM - 1 PM with brief moderate bursts of snow. Snow then tapered off to flurries by 2 - 4 PM. Temperatures were initially in the low-to-mid 20s before rising to near 20 degrees during snowfall.

Light clipper system on December 14th

A clipper system brought snow between 12 - 2 AM on the 14th. Light to moderate snow then continued through the pre-dawn hours, becoming intermittent at times with just flurries. Snow eventually tapered off to flurries by 7 - 9 AM. Temperatures were generally in the low-to-mid 20s during the event. Winds also gusted up to 25 - 30 mph at times after snow ended, leading to some blowing snow.

Powerful Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind on March 2nd

A very strong coastal storm brought heavy precipitation to the region on March 2nd. The first portion of precipitation (which began late on March 1st) was in the form of plain rain. Starting as early as 12 -3 AM however, rain mixed with and changed to snow, which came down moderate to heavily at points as temperatures settled between 32 - 36 degrees. Some of this snow came down at rates of 1-3" per hour through the rest of the morning and afternoon. Precipitation finally came to an end between 7 and 10 PM, with a few additional flurries lingering overnight. Marginal temperatures led to variable snow accumulations between lower and higher elevations. In addition to the precipitation, winds were quite strong, frequently gusting between 35 and 50 miles per hour which resulted in blowing and drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Storm Brings a Half Days’ Worth of Snow on January 31st

Snow overspread the region starting 9AM-11AM on January 31st. The snow was light at first, but quickly turned into moderate snow for the midday, with snowfall rates of 0.5” – 1.0” per hour. After 2PM, the snow would lighten in intensity everywhere, but still fell consistently for much of the afternoon. Then, between 7PM-9PM, the snow pushed out of the area, ending the event. While it was snowing, temperatures were 24-29 degrees.

NOTE: Any snow falling later on the 1st will be covered in a future report.

Snow to wintry mix and rain on February 7th

Light to moderate snow overspread the area between 7 - 9 AM on February 7th. Snow was steady with temperatures between 25 - 30 degrees. Sleet then mixed in by 10 - 11 AM, with freezing rain also quickly developing toward noon. As temperatures held near 32 degrees, mixes of sleet and freezing rain then continued until 3 - 5 PM before warming above freezing in the mid-to-upper 30s, ending any icing. Marginal temperatures and mixed precipitation led to accumulations that were denser than normal.

Wintry mix on December 24-25

Scattered showers of snow, sleet, and even brief freezing rain in spots developed between 8 - 11 PM on the 24th. Temperatures were initially in the mid-30s before settling to 30 - 33 degrees overnight into the 25th. Showers continued until steadier precipitation of mainly snow and sleet moved in between 4 - 8 AM. A few flurries and snow showers then lingered until 10 AM as temperatures warmed back into the mid-to-upper 30s. Winds also gusted up to 30 - 40 mph through the morning.

A Half Days’ Worth on Snow on January 7th

Between 10AM-12PM, from south to north, snow began on January 7th. The snow fell for the rest of the daytime hours, with periods of moderate snow seen at times in localized spots, especially the further east in the state one was. Then, between 830PM-1030PM, the snow tapered off and ended. During the event, temperatures were 17-21 degrees.

Accumulating snow and wintry mix on January 16-17

Pockets of flurries and light to moderate snow developed between 5 - 9 AM on the 16th. This initial snow was brief, with temperatures in the low-to-mid 20s before being followed by a break in precipitation outside of a few spotty flurries or sprinkles during the day. A second batch of precipitation then fell as rain near midnight on the 17th but since temperatures warmed between 30 - 34 degrees, freezing rain and brief sleet developed in spots. Any rain or mix then changed over to snow by 6 - 8 AM, remaining light to moderate in intensity before tapering off to flurries by 1 - 3 PM.

Wintry Mix on February 12th & 13th

Between 4 and 7 AM on February 12, precipitation developed over the area. At the onset, it fell as combinations of snow and sleet, mixing with a few pockets of rain and freezing rain. Despite the mixture, most spots changed to all snow (moderate to briefly heavy at times) for at least two or three hours between 9AM to 12PM. Between 12 and 4 PM, precipitation trended towards mostly freezing rain as the intensity tapered to a drizzle. A steadier wintry mix of snow, some sleet and freezing rain then returned between 12 and 5 AM on February 13th before precipitation ended entirely. During the event, the temperature was mostly between 27 and 32 degrees, though a few spots briefly warmed to 33 - 34 during the afternoon.

Nor'easter brought accumulating snow on March 21st and 22nd

Flurries and brief sleet pellets began falling as early as the pre-dawn hours on March 21st with temperatures in the mid-30s. By 7 - 9 AM, steadier snow (some of which was still intermittent in spots during the morning) arrived with a nor'easter as temperatures cooled to 30 and 32 degrees and remained there through the rest of the storm. Snow was moderate to heavy at times by the afternoon and early evening. Snow eventually ended between 4 and 6 AM on March 22nd followed by a few lingering flurries.

Nor'easter brought accumulating snow on March 13th

Pockets of light snow began between 10 PM and Midnight on March 12th (which briefly mixed with rain in spots) before giving way to steadier snowfall after 12 AM on the 13th. Snow became moderate to even heavy at times toward dawn, with snowfall rates up to 1" per hour as heavier bands developed through daybreak. Snow then trended lighter after 8 AM, giving way to snow showers and flurries that lingered until 1 - 4 PM. Temperatures were mainly between 32 and 37 degrees during snowfall.

A Wintry Weather Smorgasbord on December 17th and 18th

With temperatures 21-25 degrees, areas of light snow began to fall between 1AM-3AM on December 17th. Snow became steadier for the rest of the night, with moderate (0.5” to 1.0” / hr) to even heavy (1.0”+ / hr) snow during the early and mid-morning. After 9AM, sleet mixed in with the snow and freezing rain would follow shortly after. Then, from 1030AM-1230PM, the steady precipitation ended. Afterwards, though, intermittent freezing drizzle and mist traversed throughout the region for the afternoon and especially the evening. Sleet mixed in locally as well. Temperatures were above 32 degrees between 130PM-330PM but even still, icing was a concern until temperatures lifted into the upper 30s between 1230AM-230AM on the 18th.

First widespread snowfall of the season on December 9th

A coastal system moving up the coast brought snow over the area on December 9th. Flurries and intermittent light snow first began between 8 - 10 AM. As snow quickly became steadier toward the late morning, it also became moderate (and briefly heavy) in intensity at times, especially between 10 AM - 4 PM. Snow then remained light and steady into the evening, eventually diminishing by 10 PM - 12 AM with just a few flurries lingering into the 10th. Temperatures were generally between 27 - 32 degrees during the event.

March Snow Storm

Low pressure brought snow to the region on March 10th. Initial snow developed between 4 and 7 AM, when temperatures were in the mid to upper 30s. Snow intensity increased to a moderate to heavy intensity fairly quickly, as temperatures settled to 28 - 32 degrees. Steady snow continued into midday, though transitioned to intermittent snow showers (still with pockets of heavy snow) from west to east between 12 and 1 PM, before all snow tapered off around 5 PM. Following the steady snow, the temperature rose to 32 - 35, but fell back below freezing during the evening.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to marginal temperatures and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less, and subject to considerable variations.

Fast last season system on April 2nd

Areas of light to moderate snow developed between 2 and 4 AM on April 2nd. Snow quickly became steady and heavy at times, especially around daybreak. Some of the heavier snow fell at up to rates of 1-2" per hour. Snow then tapered off between 10 AM and 12 PM. Temperatures were between 27 and 33 degrees during snowfall before warming into the upper 30s and low 40s in the afternoon.

Periods of steady, heavy snow fell on February 17 - 18

Snow developed between 5 - 7 PM on February 17th, quickly becoming steady and heavy into the evening. The heaviest fell at rates of 1-3" per hour, especially between 6 and 11 PM. Snow then became intermittent by midnight, with any lingering snow showers and flurries ending between 12 - 3 AM on the 18th. Temperatures held steady between 29 - 32 degrees during snowfall.

Powerful Storm Brings Heavy Snow

Initial sporadic snow flurries developed as early as 2 - 4 AM on January 4th, when temperatures were in the mid-20s. After a few hours of intermittence, snow became increasingly widespread and steady by 5 - 7 AM as temperatures cooled into the low 20s to near 20 degrees where they held through the conclusion of snowfall. Snow was moderate to heavy, which at times fell at the rate of 1 - 2 inches per hour through the morning into the early afternoon. Snow intensity and coverage generally diminished 4 - 7 PM with a lingering flurry in the evening. In addition to the heavy snow were strong winds which were sustained at 15 - 30 mph, but gusted 45 - 55 mph at times. The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Periods of Wind Swept Intense Snow on February 9th

Light to moderate snow began between 3AM-5AM on February 9th. The snow intensified to heavy snow after 5AM. Snowfall rates of 1”-2” per hour were common, as winds began to gust 25-35 mph toward midday. After 12PM, the snow lightened up, ending from west to east between 1PM-3PM. Temperatures were around 32 at the onset, falling to 25-30 while it was snowing. Temperatures then fell into the teens overnight. Blowing and drifting snow was significant, even after the event, as winds continued to be strong into the evening.

Long duration event featuring heavy snow on March 7th and 8th

A wave of precipitation on the morning of March 7th was followed by a coastal system that developed later in the day before exiting during the evening. The first batch of precipitation were pockets of light to moderate snow that developed shortly after midnight on the 7th (of which began as flurries late on the 6th mixed with some rain) before lulling at times toward dawn. Steadier precipitation then developed after daybreak with the coastal system, resulting in moderate to heavy snow falling by 10 AM - 12 PM. Snow fell at rates of up to 2-4" per hour under the heaviest of snow through the afternoon. This snow then quickly tapered off between 6 and 9 PM, although additional snow showers and flurries lingered until 3 AM on March 8th. Temperatures were mainly between 30 - 34 degrees during the event. Additionally, winds gusted up to 30 - 35 mph during the heaviest precipitation, which resulted in drifting snow. The combination of a heavy wet snow and high winds also led to downed trees and powerlines.

Intense Storm Brings Heavy Snow, Wind & Mixed Precipitation

Even though there were some flurries late in the evening of March 13, steadier, accumulating snow developed between 1 and 4 AM on March 14, when temperatures were in the upper 20s and lower 30s. Starting 6-8 AM, pockets of sleet mixed in with the snow as precipitation intensified and temperatures settled into the mid and upper 20s. Following snowfall rates of 1-3”+ per hour, many locations turned to a very heavy sleet for a few hours during the early afternoon…… Precipitation changed back to all snow 2-4 PM. The steadiest snow end 5-7 PM, but occasional pockets of snow lingered until nearly 10 PM in spots. In addition to the precipitation, winds were frequently 15 – 30 miles per hour, with gusts above 40 miles per hour at times, leading to significant blowing and drifting of snow as well.

A disturbance produced a wintry mix across the area on January 14

Between 1 and 4 PM on the 14th, scattered flurries, light snow and sleet fell with temperatures in the mid-30s. Any accumulations remained on colder surfaces. Areas of light rain and drizzle developed towards sunset and then dissipated during the evening. Temperatures slowly settled to 28-32 degrees overnight.

A disturbance produced snow showers on March 3

With temperatures between the upper 30s and low 40s, flurries and scattered snow showers developed over the area from 1-4 PM on the 3rd. A few of snow showers contained bursts of heavy snow; however, most accumulations remained on colder surfaces. Temperatures cooled down into the lower 30s while the snow was falling. During the event, winds increased and gusted to 30-40 mph at times. By 6-8 PM, the last of the flurries and snow showers tapered off. Temperatures cooled to 20-25 degrees at night.

Early morning December 11th snow showers

Flurries and snow showers moved through the area on the morning of the 11th, between 3 - 5 AM. Temperatures during the flakes were 31 - 35. After snow showers exited, temperatures rose into the upper 30s to low 40s during the afternoon.

System brings snow/sleet December 24th into 25th

Light snow and sleet showers moved in on the evening of December 24th between 6 – 8 PM, however these showers quickly began to mix with rain, and became completely rain by 9 – 10 PM with temperatures that were 34 – 38 degrees. Then following overnight rain, another batch of mixed snow/sleet moved through between 4 – 6 AM. Finally, as the system exited flurries and scattered snow showers moved through on the morning of December 25th between 7:30 – 9 AM with temperatures that had dropped to 32 – 35 degrees. Winds following the event were quite strong, with gusts 40 – 50 mph.

A quick-moving system produced a wintry mix on January 8th

Light sleet and freezing rain moved in on the afternoon of January 8th between 1 – 3 PM with temperatures that were 29 – 31 degrees. Any sleet that mixed in initially quickly changed over to all freezing rain which continued through the evening before ending 8 – 10 PM. Temperatures that were steady during the event slightly cooled overnight to 26 - 30 degrees.

Flurries and light snow showers on the morning of January 16th

With temperatures 27 - 31 degrees, intermittent flurries and light snow showers moved into the area between 3 – 6 AM on the early morning of January 16th. This activity came to an end by 8 – 10 AM the same day with temperatures that gradually rose into the low-40s by the afternoon.

Any additional accumulations from the storm overnight into January 17th will be handled in a separate report.

Cold front brings rain and snow February 1 - 2

Overnight February 1st into the 2nd between 3 - 6 AM temperatures dropped to 34 - 37 degrees as a few flakes mixed with the rain as the front exited. In the wake of the front, flurries and intermittent snow showers began to affect the area between 5 - 7 AM. This activity came to an end by 10 AM - 12 PM on February 2nd with temperatures that had further fallen to 25 - 28 degrees.

A late season storm brings a mix of snow, sleet, and rain April 2

Rain on the early morning of April 2nd began to mix with sleet and snow by 4 - 7 AM with temperatures that were in the mid-upper 30s. The snow, sleet and rain mix became primarily snow and sleet around 9 AM with temperatures that remained above freezing. The event ended soon thereafter by 9 - 10 AM with temperatures that peaked in the mid 40s during the afternoon. Due to marginal temperatures, pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

Periods of Light Snow and a few Heavier Snow Showers on March 15th

Flurries and occasional light snow developed 3-6 AM with temperatures 17-23 degrees. It was not until 11 AM - Noon when snow became widespread. It snowed for the afternoon with temperatures in the 20s and while most of the snow was light, there were a few heavier squalls that moved through. The snow showers tapered by early evening and ended completely 6-9 PM. Winds during the event were gusty, at times reaching 20-35 MPH out of the Northwest

Brush with a coastal storm brings a mix of rain and snow on March 12 – 13

Intermittent rain showers on the evening of the 12th began to mix with wet snow starting 10 PM – midnight with temperatures that were 33 – 36 degrees. This light, but steady mix of rain and snow became all snow by 3 – 4 AM before ending between 8 – 10 AM with temperatures that remained just above freezing.

Storm brings a wintry mix February 7th

Snow and sleet showers moved into the area on February 7th between 5 – 6 AM with temperatures that were 27 – 30 degrees. Any snow/sleet was short lived as the precipitation changed over to steady freezing rain between 6 – 8 AM. As the freezing rain progressed temperatures gradually warmed above freezing by 10 – 11 AM, bringing an end to additional ice accretion. Following the end of freezing rain, periods of moderate to heavy rain continued through the early evening with temperatures that climbed well into the 40s.

Storm brings rain, then snow on January 17

Intermittent rain showers changed over to snow on the early morning of January 17th between 2 - 4 AM with temperatures that were 32 - 36 degrees. The snow continued at light to moderate rates through the morning as temperatures dropped below freezing. Snow ended between 9 - 11 AM with temperatures that had dropped to 26 - 30 degrees and remained below freezing for the remainder of the day.

Brush with a coastal storm and daytime disturbance January 30

Rain began to mix with snow on January 30th between 1 - 3 AM with temperatures that were 34 - 37 degrees. The rain-snow mix tapered off between 4 - 6 AM, before returning light to moderate snow arrived 7 - 10 AM with temperatures that remained just above freezing. Snowfall was steadiest during the early afternoon, before coming to an end between 4 - 6 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 27 - 30 degrees.

Due to warm antecedent conditions pavement accumulations were variable and generally less than colder surfaces.

A storm system produced a wintry mix across the state on December 17

Flurries and scattered areas of light snow began as early as 1-4 AM on the 17th with temperatures that were in the mid-20s. Soon thereafter, the snow became steady for a brief time before changing to sleet and then freezing rain towards daybreak. Periods of freezing rain continued into the early daylight hours before tapering off between 11 AM and 2 PM with temperatures that warmed to 32-34 degrees. For the remainder of the afternoon and into the evening, areas of fog and patchy drizzle developed. Intermittent rain showers were observed as well. Despite temperatures warming into the mid-30s in most locations, outlying areas stuck at 33-34 degrees continued to observe icy areas on colder ground surfaces that resulted from a preceding arctic air mass. The icing threat ended during the pre-dawn hours on the 18th as temperatures quickly warmed into the 50s.

Snow showers and squalls on January 30

Between 12 and 2 PM on the 30th, flurries and scattered snow showers began with temperatures that started from 35-40 degrees. A few of the snow showers, particularly between 3 and 7 PM, produced brief bursts of heavy snow that quickly accumulated. Temperatures also cooled into the upper 20s and lower 30s during steadier snow showers. From 7-10 PM, flurries and snow showers that lingered into the evening tapered off for good. Temperatures settled into the mid-to-upper 20s overnight.

A disturbance produced a quick shot of snow across extreme southeast Pennsylvania on December 14-15

Between 10 PM on the 14th and 1 AM on the 15th, snow fell briefly with temperatures that ranged between 30 and 35 degrees. Localized areas received a burst of moderate to heavy snow during the period. After the event, temperatures dropped to 25-30 degrees towards daybreak.

Wintry mix on March 20 with some significant sleet accumulation

Snow moved into the region between 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM on March 20th.  Moderate snow at the onset quickly changed over to a wintry mix of snow, sleet, and patchy freezing rain through midday. There were some significant periods of sleet during the afternoon, which led to a dense accumulation on all surfaces. The wintry mix continued into the evening hours until the precipitation mostly moved out of the area between 8:30 – 10:30 PM. Any patchy drizzle that lingered was very brief and isolated. Temperatures started 33 – 36 degrees and then fell to 28 – 32 during the majority of the wintry precipitation. This report covers precipitation that occurred through midnight March 21st, an additional period of precipitation occurred on March 21st that will be covered in a separate report.

Morning snow followed by afternoon and evening snow showers/squalls on March 10

It was a mild overnight from the 9th heading into the 10th with temperatures falling from the 60s on the 9th down to 38-43 degrees by 6 AM on the 10th. It was between 7-9 AM that light rain quickly developed into steady snow across the area while temperatures fell to 32-36 degrees. Steady snow persisted through the morning hours before winding down and ending between 12:30-1:30 PM. Temperatures settled to 30-32 degrees thru the end of the event, and once the event ended, only rose back into the mid-to-upper 30s with breezy conditions. Close on the heels of the snow and generally between 3 and 9 PM, additional snow showers and squalls impacted the area. Some of these squalls produced heavy snow for a brief period and led to additional accumulations, generally between a coating-0.5". Increasing northwest winds that gusted to 25-30 mph ushered in very cold air dropping temperatures into the upper teens and lower 20s at night.

Note: The snow totals contained in this report are representative of official snow measuring surfaces (a white snow board). Due to marginal temperatures and March conditions, pavement accumulations were generally less and subject to considerable variations.

Clipper brings snow on December 13 – 14th

Light snow overspread the area on December 13th between 8 – 10 PM with temperatures that were in the mid-upper 20s. The snow increased in intensity and became moderate at times quickly following the onset of snow. Later the snow became a bit more intermittent and showery in nature during the early morning hours on December 14th, before ending as a final steady round of light to moderate snow which pushed through 5 – 8 AM with temperatures warming to 30 – 33 degrees.

Clipper brings snow on December 30th

Snow overspread the area between 4 – 7 AM on the morning of December 30th with temperatures that were 16 – 20 degrees. Not long after starting, between 7 – 8 AM the snowfall rate became moderate to heavy. The moderate to heavy snowfall rates quickly tapered off to lighter snow by 8 – 9 AM. A brief burst of moderate snow returned 10 – 11 AM, before finally tapering to intermittent snow showers and flurries. Intermittent flurries and brief/light snow showers exited between 4 – 7 PM on December 30th with temperatures only rising to 26 – 30 degrees. Temperatures overnight on the 30th into the 31st dropped to 13 – 18 degrees.

A period of moderate to heavy snow the evening of February 17th

Between 4-6 PM, a mix of rain and snow arrived, quickly turning to all snow. The snow fell at a moderate to heavy intensity for a portion of the evening before it tapered and ended between 10 PM and Midnight. As the snow ended, it mixed back with rain in spots. Temperatures throughout the event were 32-35 degrees.

A disturbance produced light snow on January 5-6

Periods of light snow began between 7 and 9 PM on the 5th with temperatures that ranged from 27-32 degrees. The snow fell steady at times through the overnight hours into the 6th before dissipating between 3 and 5 AM. Temperatures had settled into the mid-to-upper 20s by daybreak.

Quick hitting snow on December 15th

On the early afternoon of December 15th, steady snow quickly overspread the area between 12 – 2 PM, with temperatures that were 25 – 29 degrees. Soon after starting, the snow rapidly increased in intensity, with moderate to heavy snow impacting the area during the afternoon. Subsequently the snow quickly exited the area 5 – 7 PM with temperatures that had dropped to 22 – 26 degrees.

Powerful Nor’easter Brings Rain, Snow and Wind on March 2nd

Overnight rain subsequently changed over to snow, between 10 AM and 12 PM as the potent coastal storm developed on March 2nd with temperatures near 40 degrees. The snow fell steady to heavy at times during the early afternoon prior to tapering down to lighter snow and flurries by the evening, before completely ending between 10 PM and midnight. While wintry precipitation was falling, temperatures fell marginally to 33 - 36 degrees. The storm brought long duration, damaging wind gusts commonly 40 - 50 mph, with a few gusts over 60 mph.

A winter storm produced snow on February 9
