Periods of rain that began after midnight eventually mixed with a bit of sleet and then changed to snow between 4 and 7 AM on the 9th. Temperatures that began in the mid-40s cooled to 32-34 degrees once the transition to all snow was complete. The snow was moderate to heavy at times for the next few hours with snowfall rates up to 1 inch per hour before ending from 9-11 AM. Temperatures that leveled off around 26-30 degrees during the daylight hours continued to cool between the upper teens and low 20s at night. Winds increased thru the end of the event with gusts of 30-40 mph during the day and overnight. This produced some areas of blowing and drifting snow into the 10th.

A coastal storm produced snow on January 7

Between 7 and 9 AM on the 7th, a dry and powdery snow began with temperatures between 20 and 25 degrees. As snow became steadier during the morning, temperatures settled to 18-21 degrees and held there for the remainder of the storm. Moderate-to-heavy periods of snow were observed into the afternoon before the snow tapered off between 3 and 6 PM. After the snow ended, temperatures cooled into the low-to-mid teens overnight. During and after the event, winds gusted at times to around 20 mph.

Potent Nor’easter brings wind and snow on January 4th

Light, intermittent snow overspread the area between 12 – 3 AM on January 4th with temperatures that were 26 – 29 degrees. The snow gradually increased in intensity to moderate rates by 5 – 8 AM, with periods during the late morning reaching 0.5 to 1.0” per hour. Moderate snow tapered back to lighter rates during the afternoon, before ending 4 – 6 PM aside from a few stray flurries, with temperatures that had fallen to 23 – 26 degrees. Wind gusts increased to 35 – 45 mph during the day producing significant blowing and drifting snow that lasted well after snow had ended.

The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

A potent early season winter storm on December 9th

Flurries and intermittent light snow developed on the morning of December 9th between 8 and 10 AM with temperatures 32 – 35 degrees. The snow subsequently became steadier, and fell at a moderate rate through the early afternoon with temperatures that quickly fell below freezing, specifically 27 – 32 degrees. The snow continued into the evening between light and moderate rates, before ending completely between 10 PM and 12 AM, with temperatures that remained below freezing. Pavement accumulation was variable and generally less than colder surfaces during the daytime.

A significant coastal storm produced heavy mixed precipitation on March 13-14

With temperatures starting from 28-32 degrees, light snow developed over the area between 10 PM and Midnight on the 13th. Over the next few hours, snow became steady with snowfall rates up to 1.0 inch per hour before transitioning to combinations of sleet, freezing rain and rain between 2 and 430 AM on the 14th. With temperatures that generally remained steady, this wintry mix became increasingly heavy towards daybreak as winds became strong with gusts to 30-40 mph. From 7-10 AM, precipitation changed primarily back over to a mixture of snow and sleet, which then lightened and became scattered thru 10 AM-12 PM. Any lingering precipitation ended as snow between 3 and 5 PM as the temperature slightly warmed to 30-34 degrees. Winds remained gusty overnight as temperatures fell into the upper teens and low 20s. During the extended period of heavy mixed precipitation, sleet amounted to 1.0-3.0 inches. With sleet being generally three to four times more dense than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow/sleet pack relative to the overall accumulation. Further weight was added to this overall accumulation on the ground with the addition of the rain and freezing rain.

Accumulation in the "Total" column are representative of combined non-compacted snow and sleet accumulation per standard snow measurement guidelines. Accumulation listed under "Ice" indicates any additional ice accretion from freezing rain only, if applicable.

Nor’easter brings intense, wet snow March 6 - 7

Rain on the night of March 6th began to mix with and then quickly changed over to wet snow between 10 PM and midnight. The snow fell steadily at moderate rates during the early morning hours of March 7th. The wet snow tapered back to lighter rates during the morning, even mixing back with rain in spots, before changing back to all snow as rates dramatically increased between 11 AM and 1 PM. During the afternoon, the snowfall rates became very heavy, reaching 1-3” per hour, even producing lightning and thunder. This intense snow band tapered back to lighter snows by 4 - 5 PM, before completely ending by 5 - 6 PM. Temperatures that were 33 - 36 degrees for the duration of the event slightly fell to 32 - 34 degrees at night. Due to the wet, heavy snow, there were numerous downed trees and power outages. Also, banding of snow and small differences in elevation were important factors in the significant variability of snowfall totals.

Late-season coastal storm produced some heavy snow March 21st – 22nd

A light mix of intermittent rain and sleet developed across the region between 12 – 3 AM the 21st.  Rain and sleet changed to a mix of snow and sleet before becoming all snow through mid-morning.   Snow continued through the day, falling at rates of up to 1 inch per hour.  The intensity of snow decreased shortly after sundown, with light snow tapering off to a few lingering flurries between 1 – 4 AM on the 22nd.  Temperatures started at 34 – 37 during precipitation onset, falling to 30 – 32 during snowfall (coldest during heavier snowfall).

Late November Snow Showers

Intermittent snow showers moved into the area between 4:00 and 7:00 PM November 20th. These snow showers and flurries continued off and on through 3:00 to 6:00 AM November 21st. Temperatures began 33 - 36, but fell into the upper 20s by the end of the event. Northwest winds were very strong at times, gusting to 35 - 40 mph.

Periods of Freezing Rain and Drizzle

Periods of freezing rain moved into the area between 7:00 and 10:00 PM December 17th with temperatures ranging from 26 to 30 degrees. Pockets of freezing rain and drizzle continued through 6:00 and 8:00 AM December 18th, before changing to plain rain with temperatures in the mid to upper 30s.

Weak Storm System Brings Snow Showers

A few snow showers moved through the area between 9:00 AM and 12:00 PM December 22nd. Temperatures ranged from 32 - 35 degrees throughout the event.

Snow and Sleet Changes to Rain

A mixture of snow and sleet fell between 7:00 and 10:00 AM December 24th, before precipitation changed to rain. Temperatures ranged from 32 - 35 during the snowfall, but rose into the upper 30s by the afternoon.

Brief Mix of Rain/Freezing Rain

A few rain showers moved through the area between 2:00 and 7:00 PM December 26th. With temperatures hovering near 32,  some of these showers froze on contact. Temperatures rose into the mid to upper 30s later that evening, changing any wintry precipitation to plain rain.

Brief Snow Squall Moves Through the Area

A snow squall moved through the area between 12:00 and 2:00 PM December 30th. The snow was briefly heavy. Temperatures began in the mid to upper 30s, but fell to near 32 during the snowfall.

Brief Mix of Rain and Snow

A mixture of rain and snow fell between 8:00 PM December 31st and 3:00 AM January 1st with temperatures ranging from 33 - 37 degrees. Once the precipitation ended, temperatures fell below 32.

Few Scattered Snow Showers Move Through the Area

A few snow showers moved through the area between 12:00 and 4:00 AM December 31st. Temperatures were in the lower 20s.

Rain Changes to Snow Showers

Rain ended as a bit of wet snow from 6:00 to 10:00 PM January 4th. Temperatures began in the mid 30s, but fell to near 30 degrees by the end of the event. The snow mixed with rain and sleet at times, especially in the lower elevations.

Snow Showers and Flurries January 8th

Snow showers and flurries moved through the area between 4:00 and 8:00 PM January 8th. Most of the snow was very light with temperatures ranging from 17 - 20 degrees.

Brief Shot of Wintry Precipitation January 10th

A mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain moved through the area between 5:00 and 9:00 PM January 10th. Temperatures ranged from 28 - 32 degrees.

Periods of Rain and Sleet

A mix of rain and sleet moved through the area between 4:00 and 8:00 PM January 17th, before precipitation changed to plain rain. Temperatures ranged from 33 - 35 degrees during the event.

Long Duration Winter Storm Impacts the Areas

A mix of snow, sleet, and freezing rain entered the area between 7:00 and 10:00 AM on February 7th. The precipitation quickly changed to all freezing rain by the late morning and early afternoon hours. Periods of freezing rain and drizzle continued through 4:00 to 7:00 AM on February 8th. Temperatures were steady between 29 - 32 degrees throughout the event.

Snow Showers and Snow Squalls March 3rd

A few snow showers and squalls moved through the area between 4:00 and 8:00 PM March 3rd. Some additional snow flurries continued through the overnight, but these flurries were very light and short-lived. Temperatures began near 32, but fell into the lower 20s. Strong northwest winds gusted to 35 - 45 mph at times.

Snow/Sleet Changes to Rain March 24

A period of snow and sleet moved through the area between 11:00 AM and 2:00 PM March 24, before changing to plain rain showers during the afternoon. Temperatures ranged from 34 - 38 degrees.

Storm System Brings Wintry Mix December 12th

Light snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM December 12th with temperatures ranging from 28 - 30 degrees. As warmer air moved into the area, the precipitation changed to a mix of freezing rain and sleet after 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM. Temperatures climbed to 34 - 35 degrees by 2:00 - 3:00 PM, changing any wintry precipitation to plain rain.

Low Pressure Brings Long Duration Icing Event December 23rd

Freezing rain entered the area between 5:00 and 7:00 AM December 23rd with temperatures in the mid 20s. The freezing rain continued through the afternoon, before ending 5:00 to 7:00 PM that evening. Temperatures rose to 32 - 34 by the end of the event. The long duration of freezing rain caused repeated periods of icing.

Brief Mix of Rain and Freezing Rain January 22nd

A brief mixture of rain and freezing rain moved through the area between 12:00 and 4:00 AM January 22nd with temperatures near 32. Any precipitation during the mid to late morning hours fell as plain rain with temperatures in the mid 30s.

Periods of Light Snow February 9th

Periods of light snow moved through the area between 1:00 and 7:00 PM February 9th. Temperatures ranged from 26 - 30 degrees.

Rain Mixes with Sleet and Wet Snow March 2nd

A mix of rain, snow, and sleet moved into the area between 12:00 and 2:00 AM March 2nd with temperatures in the mid 30s. Any mixture quickly changed to all rain between 5:00 and 7:00 AM that morning as temperatures rose into the upper 30s. As the precipitation exited during the afternoon and evening, the rain mixed with a bit of wet snow between 2:00 and 6:00 PM that same day. Strong northerly winds gusted to 45 - 55 mph at times during the storm.

Scattered Snow Showers and Flurries March 9th

A few scattered snow showers aand flurries moved through the area between 7:00 and 10:00 AM March 9th. After a break in the snow, another batch of snow showers and flurries moved through between 3:00 and 6:00 PM that evening. Temperatures were in the mid to upper 20s for the first batch of snow showers, but rose to 32 - 35 during the second batch.

Brief Snow Shower/Flurry March 25th

A few light snow showers and flurries moved through the area between 5:00 and 8:00 AM March 25th. Temperatures were in the upper 20s.

Period of Snow, Sleet, and Rain

A mix of light rain, snow, and sleet moved into the area between 10:00 PM December 6th and 1:00 AM December 7th. The light wintry mix continued through 6:00 to 8:00 AM that morning. The precipitation was primarily snow across the higher elevations, and mostly rain/sleet across the lower elevations. Temperatures began 36 - 38, but fell to near 32 by the end of the event.

Quick Hitting Storm System Brings Snow

A mix of sleet and snow entered the area between 1:00 and 3:00 PM January 8th. Any mixture quickly changed to all snow, before ending between 4:00 and 6:00 PM that evening. Temperatures were steady between 25 and 30 degrees.

Warm Front Brings Brief Period of Snow 

A period of snow moved through the area between 12:00 and 3:00 AM February 1st with temperatures ranging from 27 - 30 degrees.

Another Late Seasonal Snowfall Impacts the Area

A period of light to moderate snow (mixed with sleet and rain at times) moved through the area between 6:00 and 11:00 AM April 19th with temperatures ranging from 32 - 34 degrees.

Snow Showers and Snow Squalls

A steady snow entered the area between 9:00 and 11:00 AM February 7th with temperatures in the low to mid the 20s. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times before changing to sleet and freezing rain between 1:00 and 3:00 PM that afternoon. Freezing rain persisted through the afternoon before mixing with some plain rain during the evening as temperatures rose to 33 - 36 degrees. At the very end of the event, the precipitation changed back to a brief period of light snow, before ending between 9:00 and 11:00 PM that evening. The changing of precipitation types made this a very dense accumulation that was heavier than normal.

Periods of Snow Change to Sleet and Freezing Rain

A steady snow entered the area between 7:00 and 10:00 PM December 11th. The snow was fairly light to start, but gradually became heavier during the early morning hours of December 12th. The snow changed to a mix of sleet and freezing rain between 5:00 and 7:00 AM, before ending 9:00 to 10:00 AM that morning. Temperatures began 26 - 29, but rose to 32 - 35 by the end of the event.

Strong Coastal Storm Brings Long Duration Wintry Mix

Scattered snow showers developed between 12:00 and 3:00 AM January 23rd. These snow showers continued off and on through the daytime hours on the 23rd with temperatures in the low 30s. Some of the snow showers were briefly moderate. During the evening hours that same day, the snow became steadier and heavier, with periods of snow continuing into the overnight. The snow mixed with some sleet and freezing rain at times, but completely changed to sleet/freezing rain between 6:00 and 9:00 AM January 24th. The wintry mix changed to plain rain for most areas between 12:00 and 3:00 PM that afternoon. However, some areas continued to have freezing drizzle through the evening hours on the 24th.Temperatures were steady between 31 - 34 throughout the event.

Steady Snowfall January 17th

A steady light to moderate snow entered the area between 12:00 and 2:00 AM January 17th. The snow continued through the morning hours at varying intensities, before tapering off between 4:00 and 6:00 PM that evening .  Temperatures were steady between 28 - 30 degrees throughout the event.

Strong Storm System Brings Rain and Snow

A steady light snow entered the area between 9:00 and 11:00 AM December 29th. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times by the afternoon, before mixing with rain and sleet between 4:00 and 7:00 PM. The precipitation changed back to snow before ending 8:00 to 10:00 PM that evening. Temperatures began in the upper 20s, but rose to 33 - 35 degrees by the end of the event.

Strong Low Pressure System Brings Long Duration Wintry Mix

A mix of rain and snow entered the area between 6:00 and 9:00 AM March 31st. Any mixture quickly changed to all snow with temperatures ranging from 33 - 35 degrees. The steady snow continued into the afternoon, before mixing with, and changing to sleet, rain, and freezing rain. A wintry mix of sleet, rain, and freezing rain continued through the overnight hours, with temperatures holding 30 - 33 degrees. This extended period of sleet led to 1.0 - 2.0" of sleet accumulation. With sleet being generally three to four times more dense than snow, this led to an extremely heavy and dense snow/sleet pack relative to the overall accumulation. The precipitation changed back to all snow between 7:00 and 10:00 AM April 1st. A steady light to moderate snow continued through 5:00 to 8:00 PM that evening with temperatures holding steady in the low 30s.

Christmas Day Snowstorm

Light snow entered the area between 12:00 to 2:00 AM December 25th. A steady light snow continued through the early morning hours, becoming heavy at times between 5:00 and 8:00 AM. Snowfall rates reach 1-2" per hour in the heaviest bands. Most of the steady snow tapered off by late morning, but intermittent snow showers and flurries continued through 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM. Temperatures were steady in the mid 20s throughout the snow. Northerly winds became very gusty towards the end of the event, with gusts reaching 30 - 40 mph.

Coastal System Brings Moderate to Heavy Snowfall

A steady snow entered the area between 10:00 AM and 1:00 PM January 7th. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times, before ending 12:00 to 2:00 AM January 8th. Gusty winds of 20 - 30 mph caused some minor blowing and drifting. Temperatures ranged from 16 - 19 degrees during the snowfall.

Period of Moderate to Heavy Snow Changes to Wintry Mix

A steady snow entered the area between 2:00 and 4:00 AM December 17th with temperatures in the teens. The snow became heavy at times after sunrise, before tapering off between 12:00 and 2:00 PM that afternoon. The snow ended as a light freezing rain and sleet mixture for most areas. Temperatures began in the mid teens, but rose to 22 - 26 by the end of the event. 

*The second batch of freezing rain that occurred overnight will be included in a separate report.*

Periods of Moderate to Heavy Snow February 17 - 18th

Steady snow entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 PM February 17th. The snow quicky became moderate to heavy at times during the evening, with rates reaching 1" per hour. The snow continued through the overnight, before ending between 4:00 and 6:00 AM February 18th. Temperatures ranged from 26 - 30 degrees throughout the event.

Coastal System Brings Heavy Snow

A steady snow entered the area between 9:00 AM and 12:00 PM February 12th. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times during the afternoon. Periods of snow continued through the overnight, before ending between 3:00 and 6:00 AM February 13th. Northwest winds became gusty by the end of the event, which caused some blowing and drifting snow. Temperatures were steady between 23 - 28 degrees throughout the event.

Coastal System Brings Widespread Snowfall December 9 - 10th

A steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM on December 9th, quickly becoming moderate to heavy at times during the afternoon, with snowfall rates reaching 0.5 - 1.0" per hour. The snow lightened up a bit after sunset, but continued to fall steadily through the evening hours. Most of the snow tapered off between 1:00 and 3:00 AM December 10th, but a few flurries lingered through sunrise. Temperatures ranged from 27 - 31 degrees throughout the event.

Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow February 9th

A steady snow entered the area between 6:00 and 8:00 AM February 9th. The snow quickly became heavy at times during the late morning, with snowfall rates reaching 2 - 3" per hour in the heaviest bands. In addition, strong northwest winds of 35 - 45 mph cause some blowing and drifitng of the snow. The snow lightened up during the late afternoon, before tapering off between 6:00 and 9:00 PM that evening. Temperatures began near 30, but fell into the upper teens and lower 20s by the end of the event.

Major Nor'easter Brings Blizzard Conditions

A steady light snow entered the area between 3:00 and 6:00 AM March 14th with temperatures in the low 20s. The snow quickly became heavy by late morning, continuing through the early evening with temperatures rising into the low 30s. Snowfall rates reach 2 - 4" per hour in the heaviest bands. The snow mixed with a bit of sleet during the evening, before tapering off between 9:00 PM and 12:00 AM March 15th. Temperatures fell back into the 20s by the end of the event. Strong northerly winds of 50 - 60 mph caused significant blowing and drifting snow.

Major Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow March 7 - 8th

After a few early morning snow showers and flurries, a steady snow entered the area between 8:00 and 10:00 AM March 7th. The snow quickly became moderate to heavy at times, with snowfall rates reaching 2 - 3" per hour during the evening. The snow lightened up a bit after midnight, but a steady light to moderate snow continued through 11:00AM to 2:00PM March 8th. Temperatures were steady between 29 - 33 degrees throughout the event. A final period of intermittent flurries returned during the early evening of the 8th.

Strong Coastal Storm Brings Heavy Snow and Wind

A steady snow moved into the area between 3:00 and 5:00 AM January 4th. The snow quickly became heavy at times during the late morning and early afternoon hours, with rates reaching 1-2" per hour. As the snow became heavier, northwest winds began gusting to 45 - 55 mph, causing significant blowing and drifting snow. The steady snow and strong winds continued through the evening hours, before tapering off between 9:00 and 11:00 PM. Blowing and drifitng snow continued through the overnight hours, well after the falling snow ended. Temperatures were steady in the upper teens and lower 20s throughout the event. 

Note: The combination of strong winds, heavy snow and a long period of cold weather made this a high-impact storm. Winds in particular led to significant blowing and drifting, which resulted in substantial variability of snow accumulation and higher-than-normal drifts.

Another Major Coastal Storm March 13th.

Intermittent flurries began as early as 10PM on the 12th, before becoming a steadier snow 1 - 3AM on the 13th. Snow quickly turned moderate to heavy through the majority of the event, particularly between 10AM - 5PM where 1 - 3" per hour snowfall rates occurred. By the evening, snow turned lighter, and completely ended 2 - 5AM on the 14th. Temperatures during snowfall settled to 28 - 32 degrees, with wind gusts of 25 - 35 mph at times.
